PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1.The majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian national flag.

2.We therefore request that the Senate ensures that the Australian national flag, as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, is not changed or replaced without first being voted upon and approved by the people of Australia in a national poll.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Archer (from 19 citizens), Senator Crichton-Browne (from 24 citizens) and Senator Reid (from 20 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Australian Labor Party should return to its traditional support for the Constitutional Monarchy as represented by Messrs Chifley, Evatt and Hayden and reject support for an Australian Republic being promoted by Mr Hawke and Mr Keating.
Your petitioners therefore request that:
The Senate call on the Australian Labor Party to return to its traditional support for the Constitutional Monarchy.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Bishop (from 374 citizens) and Senator Reid (from 12 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:-

Grave concern regarding an Act of Parliament to create a new Australian flag, and to this country becoming a republic. It is our desire that the monarchy be retained as it has been for 200 years as it is our heritage.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned draw to the attention of the Senate:
We are proud to fly the Australian Flag and will oppose any changes to it.
We support the Constitutional Monarchy and will oppose any moves to turn Australia into a Republic.
We believe in loyalty to the Crown and Nation, pride in the National Anthem and respect for our existing Australian Flag.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia, who are believers in the Lord Jesus Christ and seek to practice the teachings of Jesus Christ and His apostles, draws to your attention that the practice of abortion as generally carried out in Australia is:

PETITION.PARA: 1.Sin against God (Job 1 v21); God gives life and alone has right to take it.
2.Sin against His word as contained in the Holy Bible (Exodus 20 v13);
3.Against the welfare of this nation (Proverbs 14 v34);
4.A contradiction of the Parliamentary Prayer (Matthew 6 v10).

PARA.TAB: Abortion as generally performed is murder to destroy life, not to save it. No nation can usurp or defy God's rights with impunity. For the Government to continue supporting this wickedness is to invite God's righteous indignation and judgement upon our nation.

Abortion is not just a political, social or economic issue. It is a serious moral issue. Your petitioners therefore, as in duty bound, pray and ask the Honourable House, that, as a matter of righteousness and urgency, Medicare funding of abortion be terminated as soon as possible. Medicare funding of any procedure is tantamount to Government's approval.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia who are believers in the Lord Jesus Christ, who fear God and seek to practice the teachings of Jesus Christ and His apostles in the Holy Bible, draws to your attention that:
(1) Abortion in Australia is generally performed to terminate unwanted pregnancy and is;
murder and in utter contempt of the unequivocal Word of God, "Thou Shalt not kill" (Exodus 20 v 13),
in absolute defiance of God's sovereignty and rights in the giving and taking of life (Job 1 v 21);

(2) the prosperity of this nation depends upon the recognition of God and the maintenance of righteous laws as provided by the Parliamentary Prayer. Disregard of God's laws will surely invoke His judgement.
(3) Government subsidising this wanton shedding of blood stands morally condemned and its cessation is a prime Governmental responsibility.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore as in duty bound pray and ask the Honourable House, that Medicare funding of abortion be discontinued without delay.
To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Prime Minister, Mr Keating should be condemned for his disgraceful public attack on our national flag in a foreign country. The petitioners note that his public remarks
discredited our proud history and unique culture
degraded the efforts of all servicemen and women
insulted and embarrassed proud Australians
damaged our international reputation as a united and patriotic democratic nation
Your petitioners therefore request that:
Mr Keating apologise to the Australian people for his demeaning behaviour in a foreign country.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:
We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia should retain the current National Flag which has flown over the country since Federation. This flag
symbolises the world's oldest democracy
represents our history, our culture and our language
enjoys the support of the vast majority of the Australian people
symbolises the sacrifice of our armed servicemen and women
Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should retain the current national flag.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Antarctica: Huskies
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled, we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that there is no scientific evidence which shows that huskies are:
1.A threat to Antarctica's fauna including seal and penguin colonies.
2.Linked to disease among other animals in the region.
3.Disease carriers because of a failure in the strict quarantine methods used when introducing a new dog.
4.Inferior to fuel driven vehicles in terms of efficiency of transport and impose greater damage on the environment compared to fuel driven vehicles.
Australia's signature on an international agreement will end a significant Australian tradition of using husky dogs in Antarctica by requiring the removal of all huskies presently in Antarctica.

Recognising that since 1898 huskies have supported Antarctic expeditions, have continued to be of value to scientists carrying out research and are an intrinsic part of the Australian presence in Antarctica your petitioners call upon the Government to reverse its decision concerning the huskies in Antarctica and allow them to remain in Antarctica.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Withdrawal of Russian Armed Forces from Estonia
PETITION.PARA: Canberra Eestlaste KoondisP.O. Box 3,
Canberra EstonianLyneham,
CommunityA.C.T. 2602
To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

On behalf of the Estonian Community in the ACT, we the undersigned request the Australian Parliament and the Government to support international efforts to have the Russian Government implement a genuine program for withdrawing its armed forces totally from the independent nation of Estonia.
Honourable Members, in calling for the complete removal of Russian forces and their armaments we point out that:
.there are tens of thousands of fully armed and equipped Russian forces and their dependants in Estonia, only the Russian Government knows the exact number;
.the Russian Government is making no genuine effort to remove the forces, indicating that it could take from five to seven years;

.the commanders of the Russian forces frequently issue unveiled threats to use force to maintain their presence. This could be particularly dangerous if the current Russian Government is replaced by one in which the military is dominant;
.large areas of Estonian sovereign territory are occupied by these forces and local authorities are entirely excluded from these areas;
.Russia has indicated its intention to retain some military bases in Estonia;
.the destabilising presence of the forces seriously affects the morale of the indigenous population and undermines social, economic and political development;
.the Estonian people cannot feel their nation is independent while a very large and visible occupation force postures its might; and
.as long as Russian forces remain in Estonia many foreign companies have stated that they are reluctant to risk much needed investment in Estonia.

We request that Honourable Senators urge the Australian Government to give increased emphasis in its relations with Russia, and in the United Nations, to supporting all efforts to bring about a speedy and total withdrawal of Russian armed forces from Estonia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of The Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: This humble petition is from the undersigned citizens of Australia who are believers in the Lord Jesus Christ and who hold the Holy Bible as God's word, having absolute authority and guidance.

Your petitioners draw to the attention of the House that the Family Law Act completely disregards the specific instruction of adultery being the essential basis of divorce and no specific allowance is made for this for those who would need to use it.

Where the marriage bond is understood in its full responsible and moral nature the only real basis for divorce is adultery, as the following scripture shows. The Lord Jesus said "Whosoever shall put away his wife except for fornication, and shall marry another, commits adultery and whosoever marrieth her which is put away committeth adultery" (Matt 19 v 9).
Therefore your petitioners humbly pray that the Family Law Act be amended to re-introduce adultery as a ground for divorce.

PETITION.TITLE: Quarrying at Exit Cave
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned, noting that the Australian Democrats have introduced a Bill into the Senate to ensure that no further blasting at Bender's Quarry is permitted without the consent of both Houses of Parliament, respectfully call upon the Federal Government to support the Bill.

PETITION.TITLE: ABC: Sponsorship and Advertising
PETITION.PARA: "The ABC is not a business. It is a service, paid for by taxpayers, with the great privilege of editorial and programme independence, free from commercial pressure"—Quentin Dempster, ABC Board Member.
We the undersigned agree with this statement and strongly oppose sponsorship and advertising on the ABC.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that General Business notice of motion No. 1190 be taken as formal. Leave not granted.
—I seek leave to move that motion.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—May I just inform other senators of the situation. Maybe it is the fault of a number of us here that Senator Harradine was not aware of the motion. But I think it has been on the Notice Paper.
—No, formal—

—Could I just explain, Mr President. In one of the Estimates committees an issue was raised that concerns a number of us, particularly me. We asked for information to be given to the Committee and it was not given to us because, we were told, it would hinder a Federal Police investigation. We were told that we could have a private briefing. I did not think that a private briefing was appropriate; I thought there should be something on the record, and members of the Committee agreed with me. So we asked that the Estimates Committee meet in camera so that we could have that information presented to us without prejudicing the investigations or charges that possibly would be laid against people. Since there were allegations of misappropriation of taxpayers' money, we felt that the Committee ought to know the circumstances. We have asked that the Committee meet in camera. There has been a precedent for this, and we would appreciate very much being given that opportunity by the Senate so that we can make a judgment about the situation.

—by leave—I thank Senator Patterson for her explanation. I am aware of the motion. I believe it should not be taken as formal because it proposes to take what is a very grave step indeed; that is, an Estimates committee going into camera. I will leave more detailed argument to the debate, but I maintain that this matter should not be presented in a formal manner, thus preventing debate on it; it should be dealt with in a few minutes time when the opportunity occurs.

—by leave—I just want this statement on the record: it is a very important matter that we are dealing with here and, having gone back in the Hansard and looked at the original debate when the Estimates committees were established, I think it is important that we understand and have on the record that this is an important step that is being taken and that it is being taken in the most extraordinary circumstances.

PARA.TAB: I think Senator Patterson has made out her case, but it is important that this is not a precedent that is followed in any manner of means as being a normal course of action to take in Estimates hearings. The whole value and importance of the Estimates procedure is that it is an open scrutiny of the public accounts. The value of people knowing that it is all on the public record is most important. The people 20 years ago, in framing the outline in which the Estimates committees would work, noted that there should be an opportunity if, in the most extraordinary and serious circumstances, it was considered necessary—and it had to be considered necessary by the Senate deliberating upon the matter as a whole—that that should occur. I think it is important to have it on the record that the case can be made out, and indeed Senator Patterson has made out her case, but it in no way should become a precedent that it should be an easy course of action to ask for evidence to be taken in camera in Estimates hearings. If we deliberate on the issue in that light, then we can reach a sensible conclusion without prejudicing in any way the very significant and important point that Estimates hearings are always, except in most serious circumstances, conducted in full public view.

TALK.START.PARA: —The situation, as I understand it, is that if leave is refused the matter will not be called on for debate, but if it is moved by leave it will be brought on for debate. But leave was refused, so at the moment it will not be brought on for debate.

—Mr President, on a point of order: I refused leave for the matter to be dealt with as formal. That was the reason I refused leave. I am not refusing leave for the matter to be debated, quite clearly, because I want it debated for the reasons that have been outlined. This is a very serious step.
—As I understand it, Senator Zakharov then sought leave, which would have brought it on for debate, but leave was again refused. Perhaps Senator Zakharov might move the motion again.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Zakharov)—by leave—proposed:

That Estimates Committee D be authorised to meet in private session to take evidence from the Department of Social Security in relation to the estimates of expenditure referred to the committee on 20 August 1992, for the purposes indicated in the special report of the Committee presented on 3 November 1992.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there is a great deal of need for further comment. It is no good Senator Zakharov getting up and just moving the motion for the Estimates Committee to go into camera to take evidence from the Department of Social Security. What for? I quote from the special report of Estimates Committee D to the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: It considers that the matters which concern it are sufficiently serious and have potential revenue implications which warrant the leave of the Senate to enable the Committee to consider them in more depth in an in camera hearing.

If there are potential revenue implications, that is a matter for the open public record. The matter should not be considered behind closed doors unless the Senate feels other considerations should be given to the matter. But we are not told these considerations. In addition to the Hansard of 17 September, all we have to go on is the special report of Estimates Committee D consisting of half a page. I quote again from the report:

During its consideration of the estimates for the Department of Social Security on 17 September 1992, the Committee was refused certain information pertaining to the reported use of departmental printing facilities for personal purposes, on the grounds that Australian Federal Police investigation and court action were in train. The associated disciplinary action under the Public Service Act that the Department had taken was also not disclosed fully.
That is by the Department. It continues:
The Hansard transcript of evidence of 17 September 1992 . . . refers to the matter.

2. The Committee is not satisfied that the Department conveyed to it a full and frank picture of the matters surrounding this issue. However, the Committee does not wish to jeopardise possible legal proceedings dealing with the matter. It considers that the matters which concern it are sufficiently serious and have potential revenue implications which warrant the leave of the Senate to enable the Committee to consider them in more depth in an in camera hearing.

3. The Committee will therefore be seeking the leave of the Senate to reopen its examination of the estimates of the Department of Social Security in private session on Thursday 5 November 1992 at 9.30 a.m.

This Senate regards its Estimates committees as a very important tool in bringing to account the Executive Government through the Minister and officers of the various departments. We are talking about revenue matters and, in the words of the Committee, `serious questions of revenue'.

PARA.TAB: It is a duty of this Senate to ensure that the Estimates committees are not, as it were, muzzled. The function of the Estimates committees is to ensure that the details relating to the appropriations for various departments are put on the public record. After all, we are dealing with taxpayers' money and the taxpayers are entitled to know what is happening with their money in the particular departments. It is not sufficient for a department to say, `We are not going to give you the information in public session so that the taxpayers can hear what is going on; we are not going to give it to you because it might jeopardise possible legal proceedings'. To my mind, that is just not good enough.

There is a serious suggestion that departmental printing facilities have been used for personal purposes. The question asked by senators on behalf of the taxpayer is: Why? What is the situation here? The Department has indicated that it is not going to give the answers because it might jeopardise possible legal proceedings. Furthermore, the Department says that it is not going to give the details of associated disciplinary action that has been taken under the Public Service Act. It is not going to give that to the Parliament. The only reason that is given is that it might jeopardise possible legal proceedings.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are missing the whole point.
—If I am missing the whole point, then Senator Zakharov should have explained it instead of getting up and saying there is no need for further comment.
—Senator Patterson explained it.
—I heard what Senator Patterson said and what she was indicating. I read what is said here, in the report of Estimates Committee D, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Committee was refused certain information pertaining to the reported use of departmental printing facilities for personal purposes, on the grounds that Australian Federal Police investigation and court action were in train.
How far are they down the track?

TALK.START.PARA: —If you read the Hansard you will find out.

—I have the Hansard here and there is nothing in this Hansard which suggests to me that this is a matter of sub judice. If it were a question of sub judice, that would be another matter, but where in this Hansard report is there a suggestion of sub judice? There is no suggestion of sub judice. If there were, that would put another light on the matter and we would have to be seriously concerned about the giving of public evidence under those circumstances. But that is not the case.

PARA.TAB: In the absence of that, I believe that for the Senate to agree to this request would be setting a very disconcerting precedent which would be taken up on innumerable occasions by various government departments. I remember, in respect of the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, that the Committee had questions about mismanagement, and a great number of questions about actions by various departmental officials. Investigations by the Australian Federal Police were taking place. Nobody raised this question at that stage because the Department of Foreign Affairs gave the information openly before the Senate Estimates Committee. That is how it ought to be given; it ought to be given openly.

Also, when one is dealing with something in camera it could, and would, under Standing Orders, exclude other members of the Senate who wish to ask questions of a department. I ask the members of Senate Estimates Committee D, particularly Senator Patterson, to reconsider the question. This is a very serious matter. I, and the Democrats, cannot attend all Estimates committees because we do not have the gift of bi-location, and many other senators may say, `Thank God for that'. We can only attend one Estimates committee at a time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Praise be.

—Yes, I acknowledge that interjection from Senator Crowley. It may well be that we have a particular concern about the activities of the Government. It may well be that we have the necessary knowledge to get the matters on the record and question a particular department about matters sufficiently serious to have potential revenue implications. We might be the ones to do that.

PARA.TAB: If department officials want to get rid of Senator Bell or Senator Harradine from a committee, and they are not members of that committee, all they need to say is, `We have that matter being investigated by the Australian Federal Police with a view to court action, and we are not going to give you that information'. That is all they have to do to exclude Senator Bell and Senator Harradine because, under Standing Orders, we cannot attend Estimates committees which are not held in public. That is a neat way for a department—and one particular department I can think of—to get out of a very difficult situation.

I will end on this, but I am very concerned about it because it has very grave implications and I believe that the matter should be adjourned so that these implications can be reviewed. If any member of Estimates Committee D can show me and the Senate that there are sub judice implications, that is another question, but the information available, including the Estimates Committee Hansard and the Estimates Committee report to the Senate, do not indicate that that is a consideration at this stage.

I appeal to the members of Estimates Committee D to think about this once again—to think about what is likely to happen and what precedents they are setting now. I ask the Government to do so as well. The Government might be in opposition one day. Surely it would not like this precedent to be invoked when it is hot on the trail of serious matters which have serious revenue implications.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Standing Orders say that a senator who is not a member of a committee may attend and participate in its deliberations and question witnesses, unless the committee orders otherwise, but shall not vote. I believe that the Committee has been told that this also applies to in camera meetings and therefore it would not stop any senator attending the in camera meeting.

—by leave—Mr President, might I raise that matter again? Mr President, it is most unusual for your intervention in such a manner. It indicates to me that the standing order is clear that the matter of our attendance at Senate Estimates committees and, indeed, standing committees is at the particular discretion of the committee itself. We can attend the public sessions of standing committees. That is what the Standing Orders indicate. But I make the point that, irrespective of what interpretation is made by you, you have intervened now in an argumentative manner, without any matter being raised with you as a point of order. However, what I said about the sub judice implications of the matter is the most important question to be considered. It is clear, in my view, on a reading of the Standing Orders, that the intention is for persons who are not members of committees to be present during public sessions.

—In reply to Senator Harradine, I do not believe that I intervened in an argumentative way. I was telling senators what I believe the Committee had been informed. That is all. I did not want to enter the debate.

—by leave—Through you, Mr President, I would say to Senator Harradine that both of us have the same concern ultimately that the examination of that Department's appropriation of taxpayers' funds be undertaken in a way that justifies the spending of that money. Whether there has been misappropriation of that money needs to be highlighted and brought to public attention. I would think that Senator Harradine would agree with that.

PARA.TAB: Our point of disagreement is the way in which that should be achieved. I suppose that I could have pursued the matter during the Estimates hearings. However, I was told that there were reasons why it would not be appropriate for me to do that, and in fact I think that in some way I was impeded. I have sought legal advice on the answers I was given at Estimates and I was told that in fact the Department could have provided me with more information than it did at the time. I was concerned about that, but was equally concerned about the fact that if the investigations of the Senate in any way prejudiced the Federal Police inquiries or the outcome of any charges that would be laid, that would be counterproductive. That was not what I wanted and I presume that that is not what Senator Harradine would want either.

The Committee got together and suggested this as an option. I can understand that people are concerned that it is a precedent and that view was expressed to me by members of my own Party. I can see that we have to balance out the two issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not sub judice, is it?

—I do not know; I am not a lawyer. I do not know whether it is sub judice, but I would presume as a matter of logic that if information is provided which in some way could prejudice the case—it was indicated to me that it could do so—and therefore charges may not be laid with the effect that people would not be prosecuted and dealt with appropriately, that would be counterproductive.
—On whose say-so?

—Mr President, I do not think I can have a discussion across the chamber with Senator Harradine. It may be more appropriate for this matter to be referred to a standing committee. That would delay it in some way, but perhaps that would be the more appropriate way to go. Perhaps I should adjourn the debate to a later hour this day. It may be there is an alternative way to achieve the goals that we all have in mind. I hope that in this way we will get to the bottom of this issue without prejudicing the investigations or the laying of charges, if there are charges to be laid. I move:

PARA.TAB: That the debate be adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my remarks on this legislation during the previous sitting week of Parliament, I was dealing with the necessity for infrastructure reform, particularly in the transport arena. I made the point about the impact of the flow-on effect of payroll tax and fuel excise. I wish to enlarge on that and will use Treasury estimates to highlight the impact of these taxes.

PARA.TAB: Under Fightback the abolition of payroll tax will save the transport industry $121m per year, and the abolition of fuel excise will save $679m per year. The abolition of wholesale sales tax will save $408m per year and the net flow-on impact of the GST payment would cost $58m. This is a total saving of $1.15 billion. To get down to the nitty-gritty, the impact on the transport industry is a saving of $1.20 per tonne or 1.34c per tonne kilometre. Of course, one can easily calculate that that is on an average haul of 90 kilometres, which I believe is an underestimation of the average haul throughout most of Australia.

The previous Prime Minister acknowledged on a number of occasions that the road transport industry in particular—and the transport industry in general which includes rail—pays excessive tax in comparison with other industries and other aspects of the economy. In fact, it has been estimated that the tax burden on the road transport industry is three and a half times the average of other industries in this country. When one looks at the figures and at the way that indirect tax hits the road transport industry, one can see that that is very close to the mark. The challenge for the current Government was to do something about this, but it has not. In fact, it has done the dead opposite. It has increased fuel excise and has given notice of that. In addition, it is reducing expenditure on roads by some 30 per cent.

If we compare that with the Opposition's proposals under Fightback—and this is crucial as far as the transport industry is concerned—firstly, we will abolish the various direct taxes, but in our first term of government we will not put in place a road user charge. Of course, that will bring very significant benefits to the road transport industry.

An example of the cost of transport in this nation can be seen if we look at the costs incurred by a bogey drive triple axle truck or semi-trailer. If such a vehicle travels 130,000 loaded kilometres per year, the overall saving for that operation will be some $44,000 a year. If that is taken further, the National Transport Association has told me that one of these trucks needs to travel 250,000 kilometres a year to break even, and the saving under our proposals for that operation will be of the order of $80,000 a year.

This will have significant benefits to all Australians—producers, consumers and those people who utilise goods and services in their daily lives. It is a measure which will go a long way towards addressing some of the fundamental problems in this country, problems that cannot be ignored. These problems are measured by two horrible statistics. The first is unemployment which has now reached a figure of one million—and this has been stated many times—and the second is the number of bankruptcies as a result of which some 30,000 companies have gone broke in Australia in the past two years.

In the last financial year, we saw once again under this Labor Government an increase of 28.2 per cent over the record level of bankruptcies of the year before. During the term of this Government, particularly in the last four or five years, the level of bankruptcies has increased by in the order of 20 per cent to 25 per cent per year over the record levels of the previous year. That is an indictment of the Government's failed policies and of its inability to address the fundamental issues in Australia today.

In the time remaining, I want to refer to some aspects of industrial relations in New Zealand, about which I gave notice at the beginning of my speech. With the complete reform of New Zealand's taxation and industrial relations systems, that country has gained a 25 per cent competitive advantage over Australia. The question to be asked is: what has New Zealand done to make companies such as Heinz Global invest in New Zealand to service the Asian market with horticultural products? In short, it is because the New Zealand Government has reformed public infrastructure, government administration and the labour market. Secondly, and very importantly, the New Zealand Council of Trade Unions has now resolved not to return to a national award system or to compulsory unionism.

The result—and Heinz is a classic example—is that companies which should be continuing to operate in Australia have moved to New Zealand because of the very competitive advantage of doing business in that country. There have been some other beneficial results: the participation rate in employment in New Zealand has gone up; and real wages have increased by 1.3 per cent in recent months, as against the fall in wages in Australia of 2 per cent in real terms during the life of this Government.

Until such time as the Government grasps the nettle of these issues—I have already mentioned transport, and the necessity for taxation reform and real labour market reform—we will not see substantial falls in unemployment in Australia or a change in the trends of company bankruptcies. The two go hand in hand. It is obvious that if that number of companies and small businesses are going out of business in Australia, employment opportunities must fade away. That is the terrible legacy this Government has brought upon the Australian people.

One of the best summaries of the disaster route we are on comes from the Government's own papers. In the One Nation program the projected Budget deficit figure from 1991-92 to 1995-96 was $18 billion. In the Budget that was brought down just three days short of six months later, that estimate went up to $50 billion. What a debt-ridden disaster! It is a legacy this country will carry for a long time, and future Australians will cop the burden of paying most of it back. One must target one particular person for the financial management of Australia over the 10 years—the former Treasurer and current Prime Minister (Mr Keating). He has managed to take this country's foreign debt, in gross terms, from $23 billion to about $190 billion or, in net terms, $150 billion. It would be fair to say that Mr Keating has `debtitis' as well as `recessionitis'.

Mr Keating has destroyed the aspirations of more businesses by sending them bankrupt than any other Treasurer or Prime Minister in the history of this nation. He has put more people out of work and on to the unemployment list—one million—than any other person in the history of this nation. I am glad that Senator Cook is in the chamber because he is also well aware of the number of underemployed people in Australia today.

The Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training heard evidence last week in Perth, Western Australia—the State from which both Senator Cook and I come—that 35 per cent of Western Australian youth are unemployed, another 33 per cent are underemployed and about 31 per cent have a full time job. That is the legacy that this man—Mr Keating, the current Prime Minister and the failed Treasurer—has left this country.

As the previous Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, said in about 1982, anyone who leaves a legacy of the order of one million unemployed people has no right to govern this country. I am sure that, on the basis of that figure, the bankruptcy figures, the blow-out in our national debt, the fact that our current account is totally out of control—we are going into debt at about $1.3 billion to $1.4 billion a month; and last month it was $1.7 billion—the Australian people will judge very succinctly the fact that this Prime Minister has failed this nation miserably.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in debate on the Appropriation Bills. I am sure that all members of the Senate would agree with me, as would the majority of people in Australia, that the most important problem facing this country at the present time is jobs or, rather, lack of them.

PARA.TAB: I know we have the Victorian Loan Council cover-up and other problems, many of which Senator Crane outlined in the speech that he has just completed. But most Australians are concerned about the high level of unemployment in our country at the present time. This problem is far and away the most important political and economic challenge facing all of us who represent the people of Australia. Every single issue that we discuss in the media and in Parliament and every debate in which we engage ought to relate to what contribution we might make to solving Australia's unemployment problem.

Of course, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is no stranger to the art of misrepresentation. Not so long ago he told us that the recession was over. I have not seen very much sign of that happening. He is no stranger to deliberately distorting facts in an argument. He is no stranger to sweeping aside the relevance of fact and the relevance of truth when it comes to confronting a political or an economic issue in this country.

On the subject of unemployment, the Prime Minister has actually stood in the Federal Parliament and said, `Unlike other countries, the Australian Labor Government does not use the unemployed as a buffer at the end of a railway track'. I want to look for a little while at what happens in those other countries. If Australians were asked to nominate four nations with which we could compare our economy, most of them would instinctively say America, Japan, Britain and Germany. Others might have a different mix but the majority of Australians, when they think of international comparisons, would probably still grab at those four countries.

What is the unemployment level in Japan? It is 2.1 per cent. What is the unemployment level in the United States? It is 7.2 per cent. What is the unemployment level in Germany? It is 6.8 per cent. What is the unemployment rate in that dreaded Thatcherite Britain or, I suppose now, Major Britain—the scorched earth relic of all these terrible policies that the Labor Government complains about? The unemployment rate in the United Kingdom is 9.8 per cent, as against Australia's 11 per cent, with almost one million unemployed. In other words, the nation of Australia, whose Government does not use the unemployed as a buffer at the end of a railway track, has a lamentably worse employment record than countries such as Germany and Japan; a worse unemployment level than the United Kingdom; and a much worse unemployment level than the United States.

If we look at the scale of world comparison, we see that the Prime Minister of this country is the world's greatest unemployer. He really takes the cake, the prize, for having put more people out of work, comparatively, than any other country with which it is reasonable to compare the Australian economy. The Prime Minister can talk all he likes about participation rates and he can talk all he likes about growth figure comparisons, just as I can talk all I like about the number of unemployed people in Australia.

Those of us who represent Australians in the Federal Parliament would know quite well that, as well as the 11.1 per cent of our fellow countrymen and women who cannot get a job, probably another 8 or 9 per cent are working a two-day week, a three-day week or a four-day week as an alternative to losing their jobs. The true unemployment and underemployment rate in this country is probably around 20 per cent, or one in five. That is the measure of the despair and achievement of our greatest unemployment creating Prime Minister.

The Government is trying to take away the focus of the Australian people from the fact that a Labor government of almost 10 years standing has presided over the worst unemployment level in this nation since the years of the Great Depression. That is something that would make Labor predecessors such as Curtin and Chifley turn in their graves. It is an achievement of which anybody who is dedicated to the interests of working men and women in this country would be ashamed. Rather than confront it, rather than try to debate the issue in an intelligent fashion, rather than try to explain to the Australian people why 180,000 people in the private sector have lost their jobs over the past 12 months, rather than try to explain to the Australian people why there has been a decline of 4.2 per cent since the middle of 1989—which I would say was the employment peak—in the number of people employed in the private sector and rather than try to acknowledge and attempt to embrace some long term policies to improve the Australian economy, the Government is, to its great shame, washing its hands of the issue.

How else could we describe the Prime Minister's statement recently that the recession was over? He is doing all this in the name of diverting the gaze. The old injunction about bread and circuses is very true about the Prime Minister and this Government. We have had lots of circuses but probably not a lot of bread over the past 12 months. We have had flag, republic and constitutional debates. All of this is being done in the name of diverting public gaze from headlines about private employers losing 180,000 jobs and from the fact that the Government's unemployment record is disgracefully worse than the unemployment record of countries with which it is fair to make comparisons.

The Government deserves to be condemned not only for the slump in private sector employment but also for destroying the hopes of millions of Australians and sending them to the depths of dismay and despair through its reckless economic policies. It does not try to solve our economic problems; it only services them. It does not create real jobs; it just hides people off the unemployment queues. I believe those job subsidies and job creation schemes just do not work. They do not create real jobs. Yes, they give people shovels and line them up with the local councils, but those jobs stop and the shovels disappear when the money stops. They are not real jobs; they are mickey mouse jobs.

What about the Labor Party's training scheme? The Government will have people trained but there is no link to the workplace. Australia will end up with the best trained and best educated dole queues in the world. It does not solve the problem. It hides people away from the unemployment role in training schemes. It puts money into government buildings, yet we have a glut of office space in Australia. It does not deal with the problems; it only services the problems. The Labor Government is not about job creation; it is about vote creation. It is about vote creation by spending money it does not have to buy those votes.

In August the Government presented a Budget that will not bring home our bacon. It was simply a Budget that was designed to save the Prime Minister's bacon. I am not really talking about his private business interests when I say that, either. It is not a document for the future; it is a document by a government that has no future.

If we think back to the period when we were growing up, to some of the circumstances that existed and to what were our hopes and aspirations in this country—I suppose one could say that it is a long time since I was at the stage of growing up, but there are quite a number of younger senators in this place—never would we have contemplated the possibility that we could have one million Australians unemployed. We would never have contemplated the possibility that the number of unemployed could reach one million. We would never have contemplated the possibility that this nation could be almost $200 billion in debt. We would never have contemplated the situation in which hospital queues were getting longer, or the situation where 50,000 or 60,000 young people could not get into university, as was the case this year.

Think of all the job and education opportunities that were available when we were leaving school. One would never have contemplated the possibility that so many Australians would actually feel like strangers in their own country—that they would feel excluded or thrown outside the system in their own country. But that is how so many Australians feel today in the circumstances of the worst recession in 60 years.

In those days, who would have thought that when we grew up and had children we would be looking down the gun barrel of leaving our children a lower standard of living than we have enjoyed ourselves? But that is the bottom line of what is happening in Australia today. If anyone had suggested to me even 20 years ago that countries such as Hong Kong, Singapore, Taiwan and even Japan could have out-performed us significantly in the course of the period in which we grew up and ultimately matched our living standards, I would genuinely have thought them out of their mind. Japan's standard of living was two-thirds that of ours in 1970; it passed Australia's in 1980. Now, in the 1990s, we have less than two-thirds of its standard of living. Hong Kong, Singapore and Taiwan—places that do not have a lot of natural advantages in an economic sense—are about to match our standard of living in this decade. Madam Acting Deputy President, you would not have contemplated that, and nor would I, but that is where Australia is at present.

I think it is important that we stop and ask ourselves why this has happened. Why is it that a country so well placed and so uniquely placed and with such an abundance of natural resources and so many opportunities has squandered those opportunities in the course of this current generation? I think the principal difference between the Labor Party and the National-Liberal party coalition relates to the increasing role of government and the influence of government in the country over that period. Government and bureaucracies have got bigger and bigger over this period. They have got more intrusive and more regulatory. There is more participation in business and more control over the lives of average Australians—and that more than anything else has had the fundamental effects that we are observing in our economy today.

Government has significantly reduced the private sector's capacity to create wealth and jobs. We believe that the private sector is the essential mechanism by which jobs are created in this country. Real jobs and real wealth are created in the private sector. The continual growth of government and the squeezing and the suffocation by government have driven the private sector backwards and are destroying its capacity to create wealth and to create jobs.

Then, of course, I think of union control and the demands of unions upon employers. The pervasiveness of government has squashed individual incentive, it has restricted individual freedom and it has restricted individual capacity for choice. Just think about how tough it has become for someone to start a business, for example. Dozens of approvals, licences and forms have to be dealt with in order to get a business under way. The stifling effect of increasing government and increasing government regulation have done the job. Here I might mention that, even as far as hostels and nursing homes are concerned, there is a tremendous amount of paperwork that has to be done. During the last fortnight's recess I visited quite a number of nursing homes and hostels during my touring around Queensland, and I heard so many of them saying that these days so much time is given to filling in the papers that are required by governments to keep their hostels and nursing homes going that they do not have enough time to give to the care of their people. That to me is a very sad state of affairs.

If we look at some other effects of the size and the influence of government, one of the most disturbing is the increased dependence that has emerged on government. Welfare dependency today is roughly double what it was in the early 1970s in Australia. Nearly four million Australians are on some sort of welfare assistance at present—a major impact in terms of dependency not just for individuals but for businesses. Most disturbingly, it has had a very significant effect on our attitudes. People are constantly being led to accept less than the best.

The National-Liberal Party coalition believes that real wealth and real jobs are created through the private sector; they are not created by building another bureaucracy. They are not created by spending money that you do not have because, ultimately, that money has to be paid for. Ultimately, that expenditure has to be funded, and that can have a very significant effect on the total supply of jobs and wealth in this country.

The key difference between the Labor Government and the coalition is that we believe in the private sector; we believe in individual Australians; and we believe in the forces of the market and the forces of competition. The Federal Government instead believes in the big brother, the big, overbearing, suffocating government that is supposed to provide all the answers. That is why we put our emphasis on average Australians. We believe that Australians are able to match and able to beat the best in the world. Why are we not doing it with our economic performance at present?

The coalition believes in setting a government framework that provides the mechanism whereby the private sector can carry the main task which it is good at, at what it can do, which is generating wealth and generating jobs. The tragedy in this country today is that the Government tries to reduce everyone to the lowest common denominator. Government suffocates the process. The private sector is driven out backwards. Jobs are permanently lost, and we are left with major social and economic trauma in this country. We want to reverse that process, to put our faith back in individual Australians, to give individual Australians choice. We want to give them the opportunity of getting greater control over their lives. On this side of the Senate we are for less government and more focus on business, cutting business costs, giving businesses the scope to get out and do what only they can do, which is create wealth and create jobs by matching the best in the world.

The Government does have a responsibility to look after the disadvantaged, and we take that seriously. We do it in a way that targets that money very effectively and we set out to increase the assistance given to those who are genuinely disadvantaged while creating the circumstances where people can actually get out there and get a job, generate wealth and rebuild this country to the potential that we all know it really has.

For far too long the Government has tried to make people believe that people can be taxed to the hilt without destroying incentive. The Government has adopted the attitude that everyone can be granted the same wage rise without destroying initiative. For far too long we have kidded ourselves in this country that government money can be thrown at every single social problem without destroying self-help and self-respect. For far too long in this country the Government has loaded business with red tape, green tape, black tape and a host of cost disadvantages and tried to pull the wool over our eyes by saying that it would not destroy the national wealth. Perhaps most importantly to a lot of Australians for far too long the Government has constantly knocked our country and denigrated our flag with the aim of trying to destroy our national pride. These are matters I feel very strongly about and why I have brought them to the attention of the Senate in this debate today on the Appropriation Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bjelke-Petersen and Senator Crane have raised the very important matter in this debate on the Appropriations Bills of where the money goes. As Senator Bjelke-Petersen said, the Government is spending money that it does not have. We have seen plenty of examples of that in recent days. We have seen the loans scandal in Victoria. We know as Australians that we have a $150 billion overseas debt. If there is one thing that the Labor Party has always been good at, it is spending other people's money.

PARA.TAB: The appropriations debate and, more particularly, the Senate Estimates committee system, provide members of the coalition with the opportunity to get a true picture of what is happening in government departments. In recent times, I recall some huge amounts of Government waste. I also recall some examples of waste of government money which are not so large in amount but are equally as important. I remember the $8m that was spent on a munitions factory at St Marys in Sydney which never produced one shell or bullet. It is going to be bulldozed and a new factory is going to built at a greenfield site somewhere else. That is just one little example.

Through the Estimates committees one has an opportunity to highlight various areas of waste and to research what has happened. It seems to me that over recent years a trend has emerged of a blow-out in the use of consultancies by government departments without a corresponding decrease in the number of public servants. The Commonwealth is very good at making State governments cut back on their expenditure. From what we have seen over the last few years, apart from one or two departments it seems that there has been no effort by the Commonwealth to cut back on expenditure. I notice that Senator Bolkus's department seems to be cutting back on its expenditure in certain areas. But, generally speaking, there does not seem to be any great effort to try to save money.

For example, in August it was revealed through the Commonwealth Purchasing and Disposal Gazette that the Attorney-General's Department had spent $278,212 of taxpayers' money to promote its changeover to a user-pays system. As you would know, Madam Acting Deputy President, the majority of the clients of the Attorney-General's Department are government departments. So, in effect, the Attorney-General's Department spent over a quarter of a million dollars promoting itself to a closed group of clients—a captive audience.

Just for the record, some of the expenditure is quite unusual. The Attorney-General's Department spent $26,000-odd on special key rings and mugs for its employees to mark the event. It spent $3,921 on a client liaison function for other government departments at the old Parliament House. A client liaison function is more effectively known as a drink or two, I suspect. On top of that, it spent another $4,111 for a two-day hire of a conference room at the Lakeside Hotel for meals and further talks.

Then it spent another $34,000 for a national satellite television hook up. It spent $100,000 for design and printing of a corporate device and style manuals. It spent $21,900 on marketing and training, another $34,000 on market research consultancy services, and another $8,776 on a marketing strategy. It topped that off with $20,000-odd on the printing of a legal practice brochure, $10,700 on a contract list brochure, and another $13,500 to engage an outside consultant to coordinate the production of its annual report.

As Senator Tate would know, I raised these matters before Senate Estimates Committee E. I was quite amazed by the number of consultants that were used. In order to promote itself to other government departments, which are going to use it anyway, the Attorney-General's Department used Reark Research, Tarqin Ralph, who is an in-house consultant, Bowden-Sexton, Robert Poulton, Kelly Parkinson, Marje Prior and Gattorna Chorn. All these different groups were used to make sure it did everything correctly.

On top of that, we found that the person who produced the Attorney-General's annual report was none other than Mr Nihill, the press secretary to the former Prime Minister, Mr Hawke. In addition, it appears that the Attorney-General's Department has kept 400-odd mugs. Officers of the Department have told me that the mugs will be held in reserve and handed out to new staff as more are employed.

An amount of $3m was spent by the Attorney General's Department on consultancies during the year; only five consultancies were publicly advertised. It seemed quite unusual to me that the Attorney-General's Department would spend almost $40,000 in order to conduct an inquiry of government departments as to the value of services provided by other government departments. Quite frankly, I would be surprised if there were no officer within the Attorney-General's Department who could undertake that exercise.

We went on a bit further and found that the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission employed 40 consultants at a total cost of $1m, with only two of those consultancies having been publicly advertised. I know it will be said that there is a selective tendering process and a list of names. But once that list of names has been compiled, is one then on it for ever and a day, and what hope does anyone else have of obtaining a place on it?

One of the worst examples of the Department's closed shop approach to the tendering process was the awarding of a $242,000 tender over a period of four months to Admiral Computing to assist the Department—only to `assist'—in selecting tenders for the law enforcement access network; that is $60,000 a month. The company concerned is based in the United Kingdom and it appears that no-one from the Department of Administrative Services or the Attorney-General's Department even bothered travelling to the United Kingdom to negotiate the details of contract with the company. At the end of the Estimates hearings, the Committee was left in a lot of doubt as to what had been the role of Admiral Computing, and even whether its work had been completed. Representatives of Admiral Computing have gone back to the UK and, as far as I am aware, the tender for this particular network has not even been let.

It became very apparent from the evidence placed before Estimates Committee E that there is a complete lack of control over the use of outside consultancies. Accordingly, it is very difficult for the Government or any particular department to claim that the best person for the job gets the job, nor can they claim that the exorbitant rates paid by the Australian taxpayer are justified. The other day I noted that Dr Anne Summers received the princely sum of $86,000-odd for a three-month consultancy within the Prime Minister's Department.

TALK.START.PARA: —For three months?

—Yes, for three months. One can discover these things only by questions on notice or through questions at Estimates; they are not generally available to the average politician, unless he or she does a bit of digging. But the closed shop mentality of the Attorney-General's Department is demonstrated by the fact that only five of a total of $3m worth of tenders were advertised. It seems that there is this growing trend to use consultants without any challenge, and it would appear that some consultants are lining their pockets at the expense of the taxpayer while those on the outside are not even being given the opportunity to tender.

PARA.TAB: I was interested in some of the costs of consultancy incurred by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. There was a massive $1m blow-out from the 1990-91 Budget to the 1991-92 Budget; a figure of just on $3m was reached by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. Included in that sum was a consultancy of $68,800 to obtain advice on architectural and building services in relation to the Lodge. That means that in just two years $165,000 has been spent on obtaining technical advice on both Kirribilli House and the Lodge—just advice, nothing else. Not one nail has been driven, not one piece of plaster fixed up. I repeat that a sum of $165,000 has been spent just on obtaining technical advice on Kirribilli House and the Lodge.

Over the last two years $1m has been spent—Senator Newman, I think, raised this one—on a study to determine the work and living standards of Australians. One would have to query that expenditure of $1m. One has only to go down to the dole queue—Senator Bjelke Petersen mentioned this—to work out what the living standards of Australians are at the moment. There is one program in this area you would be most interested in, Madam Acting Deputy President. The sum of $8,100 was spent on a health and fitness program which even included cooking demonstrations. I do not know whether they made any of your pumpkin scones, Madam Acting Deputy President, while they were at it.

The Waste Watch Committee, of which I am Chairman, also revealed that the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services spent $54,000 on a project to conduct a needs analysis of the transsexual population of Australia. It spent a further $188,000 to conduct a needs assessment of female partners of bisexual men. Only last year I criticised the expenditure by the Film Finance Corporation of $270,000 to assist in the funding of a movie that has had a fair bit of publicity in recent weeks, a sex movie starring American porn queen Annie Sprinkle. I think even Phillip Adams got into the act and criticised the funding of that film.

I note with some interest that funding has been cut for a group of people called the students' initiative in community health. They had spent over $1m of taxpayers' money on such bizarre things as recommending student prostitution as a means of working one's way through college. I am pleased to see that the Minister, after some letters from me highlighting this matter and other suggestions the group made regarding anti-social behaviour, cut their funding. Nevertheless, $1m of taxpayers' money went in that area.

One of the things that really interests me is the amount of money that has been spent on upkeeping Government House, Admiralty House, the Lodge and Kirribilli House. There have been huge increases over the last few years. No doubt these places have to be maintained and the gardens have to be kept in good order. In regard to the Lodge, in the period from 1975 until 1982, when Malcolm Fraser was there, a total of $1.3m was spent, or an average of $166,000 a year. Since then, from 1983-84 until the present day, a total of $4.5m has been spent, or an average of nearly half a million dollars a year—an average increase of 195 per cent per annum.

With Kirribilli House, in Fraser's days a total of $61,500, or an average of $7,600 a year, was spent on upkeep. In the time of former Prime Minister Hawke and the present Prime Minister, a total of $500,000, averaging $55,000 a year, or an increase of 621 per cent a year, has been spent. For Government House the gross figures are staggering. I know the place might be falling down, but since 1983 until today a total of $9.487m has been spent on Government House in Canberra. A lot of money has been spent on this new Parliament House, but for goodness' sake, for $9.5m one could just about build a couple of new Government Houses. For Admiralty House, $2.7m was spent between 1983 and 1992. There is no doubt that this Labor Government is very good at spending taxpayers' money and other people's money.

I have just glanced through some of our research grants. I often get criticised by some of my academic colleagues on this side of the House, without any criticism from the other side of the House, but when one looks through some of these grants one sees that one item that I highlighted last year and the year before is still going along very nicely. It is a grant of $25,000 for a continuing study of early celtic art.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is wrong with the Irish?

—As a matter of fact, for the last two years there has been a total of $75,000—and I notice another $40,000 this year—for a case study of parliamentary development involving the eighteenth century Irish Parliament at work. We are to spend $31,000 of taxpayers' money on visual representations of witchcraft in early modern Europe. I am sure that will have a lot of benefit to Australians.

PARA.TAB: I notice that George Bernard Shaw gets another mention. I do not know how many biographies there are of George Bernard Shaw, but there are going to be another two at a cost to the taxpayer of $41,400 and a chronology of George Bernard Shaw at a cost of some $40,000. I think everyone would be very pleased to know, too, that we are going to spend $15,500 on a study of the cultural and social role of the Stawell Easter Gift. I am sure that Senator Kemp, as a Victorian, will be most impressed with that.

The one that really gets to me—I suppose it must have some relevance to Australia and to the taxpayer—is that $20,000 will be going to a professor at the University of Western Australia to study the history of tourism in fascist Italy. The accompanying notes state:

SPEECH.PARA: To write a history of tourism in Fascist Italy will be significant because it will raise many questions of historiographical dispute—the level of nationalisation, fascistisation or `totalitarianisation'. Fascism's cultural and economic policies, the survival of non-Fascist attitudes and behaviours in Italian society. Finally the `success' and refinement of the Italian tourist industry ought to provide an interesting base for a later study of tourism in Australia.

Quite obviously they believe that our present Prime Minister and this present Government are going to stop here because, if tourism is going to continue in the vein of fascist Italy, obviously we are going to have a fascist government. As I say, obviously it is of great value to the person who is doing the research, but I have to question whether this or a lot of the other waste that I have identified this morning is really the way we should be going when we have a million people out of work, an overseas debt of $150 billion and all we ever see lately are huge cover-ups by this Government of the economic waste, the lack of direction, the lack of planning and the lack of leadership shown by this present Labor Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Industrial relations is a great issue facing Australia in the 1990s. The questions that arise are on the following lines. How are employers and employees to deal with each other? What attitude will each group adopt towards the other? Will it be adversarial or conciliatory? Will the relationship be one of master and servant characterised by how things were in the nineteenth century and which some claim are a thing of the past? Will it be based on cooperation of everybody present in the workplace? What assumptions will determine the answer to those questions? Will it be that management must command and workers must obey no matter what; that employers should be allowed to negotiate on their own; that the individual matters and never the group; that production is all that matters; that unions are always bad; and that workers matter less than managers?

PARA.TAB: We have heard this morning speeches attacking the former Government in Victoria, and I want to come to that because it is an example of what may well happen were a coalition government to be elected. It is all very well for the coalition to attack the Government, as one would expect it to do—after all, that is what oppositions are for—and it is to be expected that it would attack unions because unions have been chosen by the coalition as the traditional scapegoats for the ills of the nation. One can understand that, but one cannot understand why the coalition's prescription to cure what it sees as the faults of the Labor Party and the unions is not so much to attack them as to attack the workers. That concerns me. It concerns me that people should be attacked not because of what they have done but because of what others have done.

If one looks at what has happened in Victoria, one can see the merit of what I say. When that Government was in opposition it attacked the then Labor Government—which, as I said before, is the purpose of an opposition—and it attacked the unions, who are the traditional enemies of the Opposition. However, when the coalition got into government in Victoria, it attacked the ordinary workers, the people who go about their business and who may well have voted for it. These people have done nothing but lead decent, ordinary lives, but they are saddled with what in effect is a poll tax—a $100 tax on a house, no matter what the size, locality or worth.

In Victoria, if a person had an injury he could issue proceedings to exercise his common law rights, which the Opposition has often proclaimed as sacred. Now, if that person wants to exercise his common law rights in Victoria and has spent money to get his case ready to go to court, that action is wiped out. Why should people who have nothing to do with the ALP—in fact, many of them may have voted against the ALP—who are injured through the fault of their employer, through the fault of others, and have been made to leave work because they have not been fit to go on, have their right to sue taken away? Up until 3 October they had that right, but it was lost in the weeks following that date.

It is a matter of concern that the objections that are put against the present Government and the unions should result in outcomes not against those two bodies—not against the union movement or the ALP—but against ordinary people. It gets worse than that, because people are now expected to negotiate their own workplace agreements—I do not like to talk in these terms; the labour market is very much against it—without any adequate protection. That has certainly happened in Victoria, and it is proposed that it should happen here. I will give an illustration of how harsh this could become.

For example, people who are working under shocking conditions may not be members of a union. Nevertheless, they may be so overcome by their surroundings that they want to stop work. A declaration can now be made in Victoria stating that their workplace is a vital industry. The employees will then ask, `Why are we declared a vital industry?'. The legislation that is being considered says, `It is a vital industry because the Governor-in-Council has declared it to be a vital industry'.

It might be an industry which any reasonable person who was looking at it would say is not, in the circumstances, a vital industry. But once it is declared to be a vital industry, it is a vital industry simply by that definition. Within the terms of this legislation, it could be a local milk bar, a hotel or a factory making Easter eggs. These are all situations which a reasonable person might say would not attract the title `vital'. But if the Governor-in-Council declares that the chocolate factory producing Easter eggs is a vital industry, it becomes a vital industry. Once that happens, the people working in that situation, be they members of a union or not—and they well might not be—have to continue working and not raise objections to the situation. Indeed, if they raised objections, if they interfered, induced or attempted to interfere with the facilities of that factory, they would be guilty of a criminal offence.

People from the coalition will be following me in speaking in this debate. I simply ask why ordinary people, who, as I say, may not be members of a union—for the purposes of my argument, they are not members of a union—who might not like unionism and who have always voted for one of the parties in the coalition, should be placed in a situation where they can be made criminals by the fact that they want to protest about the way in which they are asked to work, simply because it is up to the Governor-in-Council, that is, a government, to declare their industry vital.

Mr John Howard is a person who is entitled to great respect as a shadow Minister and parliamentarian. Nevertheless, he is coming forward with a program which causes great concern. He is saying, `We are now going to set up a system which in effect promotes the common law as the basis for industrial relations'. It sets aside a legislative framework such as now exists, and brings in the common law to resolve disputes. Mr Howard says that there will be no need for unions because there will be an office of the employees' advocate.

What does this mean? It means that if a person wants to sue his or her employer, the management, at common law that person can go to the employee advocate and does not have to pay for the services of that advocate. But does that cure the problems? It certainly does not cure the ills of the common law—and I want to come to them—nor does it overcome the problem of getting on in court, and there are plenty of cases waiting to be heard in the common law court. Nor does it overcome the problem that, if he or she, the worker, loses the case, he or she has to pay the costs of the other side. He or she might claim $800 wages and has to go to common law. He or she could be told by the employee advocate that is the correct course but at the same time he or she could be threatened with a bill of $1,500 or $2,000 if he or she loses the case.

The problem with the coalition's approach in this area is that it is based on a wrong philosophy. It is the philosophy of the individual, that the individual matters, no matter what. It is the philosophy of the marketplace, that the marketplace determines all, no matter what. It is the philosophy of the strong against the weak. I understand that philosophy, and it is a choice that will be put to the people of Australia. But, as I have said before on other occasions in this place, it is not the philosophy that I adopt and it is not the philosophy that people like the present Pope adopts. He makes it quite clear that the free consent of the parties, the bargaining in the marketplace, is not what should guide the reaching of a just wage. In his encyclical, Centesimus Annus, talking about an earlier Pope, Pope Leo XIII, he immediately adds another right which the worker has as a person:

SPEECH.PARA: This is the right to a `just wage', which cannot be left to the `free consent of the parties', so that the employer, having paid what was agreed upon, has done his part and seemingly is not called upon to do anything beyond.

That is exactly the sort of thing that we agree with as far as the Pope is concerned but which the other side does not agree with. The Opposition agrees that there ought to be free consent of the parties—as long as a deal is struck with the employer, that is enough. The other thing that has to be remembered is the importance of the union movement, which again is not given its proper place by those opposite. The Pope had this to say:

Finally, `humane' working hours and adequate free-time need to be guaranteed, as well as the right to express one's own personality at the work-place without suffering any affront to one's conscience or personal dignity. This is the place to mention once more the role of trade unions, not only in negotiating contracts,—
I repeat that—

not only in negotiating contracts, but also as `places' where workers can express themselves. They serve the development of an authentic culture of work and help workers to share in a fully human way in the life of their place of employment.

The point about all this is that the argument, the debate, in this place on the Appropriation Bills, as far as I have heard, and I have not heard them all by any means, seems to be intent, as far as the Opposition is concerned, on attacking the Government and unions. That is all right, but why then bring forward policies, which I have touched upon in the short time I have available to me, to some extent—there are others I could certainly mention—that attack people who go about their ordinary tasks, who are simply trying to live a decent life, to bring up their children in a decent way and to enjoy some of the fruits of the earth? Why will those people be punished for what, the Opposition says, are the faults of governments and the faults of unions?

PARA.TAB: Why should the Opposition adopt a free market individual no matter what philosophy when other people in the world of great moral persuasion come to other conclusions? Hopefully, those sorts of questions may well be answered by those who follow me in this debate.
I want to quote a great adage, a great statement and a great saying that was taken from a group of small nations in the United Nations. Its original form was not English but when translated it says:

SPEECH.PARA: It is just as unjust to treat unequals as equals as it is to treat equals as unequals.

A policy which declares that an individual employer and an individual employee can fairly negotiate directly on wages and conditions ignores the profound truth of that proposition. When there is a marked contrast in negotiating strength, any proposition that says that people ought to be allowed to negotiate freely is wrong and should be condemned and moved away from.

PARA.TAB: Yet that is what is contained in the industrial policy that is proudly promised by the Opposition. The Opposition has a policy which relies heavily on the common law—a law which has never, as Senator Tate touched upon the other day, helped the workers. It is a law which gives great weight to the sanctity of contract and the freedom of trade but not to the needs of employees in respect of minimum wages and conditions. There are no common law principles that limit the hours that might be worked per day or which provide for holidays, sick leave or meal breaks. There is no minimum level below which pay must not fall. Indeed, the coalition understands this and would introduce legislation in this respect.

I have been asked to limit my speech, so I will. I again ask those senators opposite who will follow me in this debate to tell me whether they consider that negotiations can be conducted fairly between employers and employees. If they say that the marketplace ought to determine wages and employment conditions, why do they feel that there is a need to put in minimum conditions? Why have minimum conditions if they are so convinced that negotiations can be fair? If negotiations are fair, there will be no need for minimum conditions. If they want to introduce some minimum conditions, why not go further and ensure that there are fair conditions? There is a difference between minimum conditions and fair conditions. Why be so conscientious about minimum conditions and not conscientious about fair conditions?

If there is a need to legislate to ensure that there are minimum conditions, why does not the coalition need to legislate to ensure that there are fair conditions?
