Fair conditions could be achieved by perhaps legislating or by perhaps leaving the present system as it is and allowing people to negotiate individually. There are organisations such as unions that can ensure that minimum conditions and wages are not only negotiated but also that they are fair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is an old saying that one learns something new every day. I have just listened intently to what Senator Cooney had to say, and I am not sure that I have learnt something new. But I did note with interest that he spent almost 20 minutes talking about the coalition's policies, and that would perhaps indicate that Senator Cooney, along with many of his colleagues, is resigned to the fact that they are the policies that he will be debating again immediately after we have the next Federal election.

PARA.TAB: A few weeks ago I certainly learned something new, though. I learned something that none of my colleagues on this side of the chamber knew; I learned something that nobody in my home State of South Australia knew. What I learned, much to my amazement, was that the recession was over, and not only was it over but it has been over for some time—a year or so in fact! Who was responsible for this little gem of information? It was none other than the person who told us that this was the recession that we had to have in the first place—the Prime Minister, Mr Keating.

I am sure that the recession is over for the Prime Minister because he is not even trying to survive on a pension or unemployment benefits. When he loses his current job, as he most surely will, he will not have to support a wife and three kids on the average male wage of about $28,000. Mr Keating can be glad he is not in this average category because otherwise he would also be relying on handouts from the Salvos or any number of other charitable organisations that are under so much pressure at the moment. Why? It is because, as a result of Labor's policies, it is not just the low income earners that need help these days; it is the middle income earners as well. These are people who years ago would never have dreamed of getting help from charity; people who are embarrassed and angry that they have been forced into a position of dependency for the first time in their lives. The Prime Minister really would not know what a recession was if it hit him right between the eyes.

A recession really means that the family's sole breadwinner's job has been lost; mortgage repayments cannot be met; children go to school inadequately dressed, sometimes without lunch; families can no longer afford the small luxuries in life, like going to the movies; housewives are trapped in the suburbs because they cannot afford the public transport; the phone, electricity and gas bills go unpaid; and parents cannot afford to support their kids through TAFE and universities. And so the list goes on. Really, what would the Prime Minister know about this? When was the last time he could not afford to buy a basic necessity of life?
I am not as amazed as some that Mr Keating says the recession has ended. After all, he has a record of saying absurd, careless and even heartless things. In 1983 when our

SPEECH.PARA: foreign debt was a mere $23 billion—mere compared with current standards—the then Treasurer, Paul Keating, said:
. . . 1983-84 holds promise of a considerable improvement in economic performance.
In 1984 when our foreign debt jumped by almost $5 billion to $27.9 billion, he said:
Tonight I am proud to be able to tell the Australian people that we now have strong economic growth, many more jobs, a substantial fall in inflation and declining interest rates.
Then, in 1985, our debt had almost doubled in the space of one year to $51 billion and Mr Keating said:
The Government's strategy . . . builds upon our very significant success and puts further behind us the despair and economic failure of the former Government.

I could go on and on but I am sure honourable senators get the picture. Suffice it to say that, now that our foreign debt has blown out from $23 billion in 1983 to a disastrous $150 billion in 1992, the Prime Minister said:
The Keating Government's economic strategy is to accelerate recovery from recession and, at the same time, build a stronger Australia.

I think Mr Keating should hark back to his statement in 1985 about the despair and economic failure of the former Government. Who does he think he is kidding? Who has caused the most despair and economic failure since the Great Depression? If the Prime Minister has a conscience, I urge him to examine it and admit to himself and to the public that it is this Government, not a Liberal government, that has caused so much suffering for average Australians.

PARA.TAB: What has Labor done in this 1992 Budget to fix this recession that we had to have? Has the Government created any real long term jobs? Has it created any real employment at all? Has it lessened the personal income tax on low and middle income earners or made health care more affordable? Has the Government done anything to lower our foreign debt? Has it done anything to encourage small business to prosper or for our farmers to stay on the land?

Of course, I would be naive to say that the Government has not accomplished anything at all. After all, Labor has become so bereft of policy ideas in recent years that it is inevitable that its policies in some areas would start to mimic some of ours. But there is no point in going only some of the way or halfway—and that is what this Government has done: gone halfway and got half-baked results.

Australia's one million unemployed are not thanking Labor for its half-baked policies; nor are the 6,000 South Australian farmers who have left the land in the last six years. What about the tens of thousands of students who have been denied tertiary and TAFE places and the hundreds of thousands of Australians on the dole queue? What about my constituents, South Australians, who will be paying well into the next century for the $3 billion that the Bannon Government used to prop up the State Bank?

No, the recession is not over and this 1992 Budget will not help one iota. The Government knows it has lost the battle. It knows its only hope is to buy votes and hope its traditional supporters will not desert a sinking ship. This is why if we examine the Budget handed down in August it is easy to see that the Government has decided to help only some Australians out of the recession—and those people live in particular areas of Australia.

This most discerning Government recognises that unemployment is indeed a major contributor to the current disastrous state of the economy and has set up a job creation scheme, which is most commendable. This scheme is aimed at creating opportunities for up to 30,000 people, which is only about 3 per cent of the one million unemployed, by funding capital works programs in local council areas. The scheme is known by the grand title of `Working for the Future' and to justify the importance of its aims it has been allocated $345m to be spent by the end of 1993.

Unfortunately, when the pieces of pie were distributed the lucky recipients turned out to be teacher's pets. Once again the Government has played favourites with its Budget bribe. The lucky ones are virtually without exception located in key marginal electorates currently held by nervous Labor members who see their tenure on very shaky ground, as was amply demonstrated on 3 October in Victoria.

Let me give some examples of this selective form of distributing funds which sees 502 out of 914 or more than 50 per cent of councils miss out on funds completely. In my state of South Australia, in Federal electorates such as Kingston, Makin and Grey—which the Government is hanging on to by a thin thread—there are some prime examples: Whyalla, nearly $1m; Port Pirie, $583,000; Port Augusta, $540,000; and Port Lincoln, $473,000. Where are those councils? They are all in the Federal seat of Grey which requires a swing of just over 2 per cent for Labor to lose that seat. Does the Government not know it? The Labor candidate for Grey has been in panic mode for months. Why? Because the voters in places such as Port Augusta, people who have voted Labor all their lives, are telling the Liberal candidate, Barry Wakelin, that for the first time in their lives they will be voting Liberal.

Returning to the Budget bribes, at least eight metropolitan councils did not receive any funding at all whilst Salisbury got $4.2m and Noarlunga $3.3m. Honourable senators may well ask who holds the electorate covering Salisbury. It is none other than the Minister for Social Security, Dr Neal Blewett. It may interest honourable senators in passing that the corresponding State electorates covering Salisbury are held by the Labor Premier, Lynn Arnold, and his employment Minister, Mike Rann. Where is Noarlunga? It is in the seat of Kingston, currently held by the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, Mr Bilney, with a margin of just over 4 per cent.

One might also ask: are there no unemployed in Mitcham or Burnside or any other of the seats that missed out on funding? The answer is a resounding yes, the Mitcham Council area has 2,700 unemployed and Burnside has 1,275. South Australia has the worst youth unemployment in the country, with 12,000 15- to 19-year-olds out of work. The official youth unemployment statistic for the State rose to a staggering 40.3 per cent in September. What will happen in November and December, when another 20,000 young South Australians leave school? How many of them will get long term jobs? Will this Government think up another quick fix scheme, costing another few million, to try to stop the inevitable blow-out in the unemployment figures?

South Australia is not exceptional. With some exceptions, nearly all of the $345m to be distributed Australia wide through this working for the future scheme will be spent in marginal and Labor-held electorates. The Government claims that funding allocations are based on the number of unemployed in each region or local government area. If this Government had workable policies that created long term jobs, it would not have to buy back votes at all. This Government has created a monster in the form of an unemployment disaster across Australia that it cannot control. The irony is that it is traditional Labor Party voters who will put the coalition into government at the next election, and they know that this Government is trying to buy their votes.

What about the 502 electorates that did not receive any funding at all? I suppose this Government believes there is no value in buying votes in safe Liberal electorates. That is a cynical, hard-hearted belief. Every electorate is suffering unemployment. The pain of one unemployed person is the same as that of another, whether that person is in a Labor-held electorate or a coalition-held electorate. For instance, in Port Augusta the council intends to use its $540,000 on four short term projects, including building a club room, redeveloping Gladstone Square and constructing a boardwalk and car parks. What happens when these projects are finished? What is the Government going to do in the meantime to create some long term employment? Does this Government have a long term plan to help revitalise some of these regional towns? What plans does it have to develop tourism in these areas? Does it even know what tourist developments are proposed for the areas? There are times when I doubt it.

I do not think the Government has a clue what is going on in rural and regional Australia. It is too caught up in the cities and the mass work force there to know or care about people who earn far less than their union mates in the cities. Labor says that it is the party of the working class, but I do not believe it would have a clue what work is or what real poverty is. There are a number of people in rural and regional Australia, particularly in primary production, who know what real work is, and what real poverty is.

It is estimated by the Bureau of Agriculture and Resource Economics that this financial year the average broad acre farmer in Australia will lose $25,700. I wonder what would happen if we suddenly turned things around and gave farmers an income of $30,000 a year—which is not unreasonable, given the long hours they work and the wealth they generate for Australia—and some workers in the cities, such as waterfront workers and those in other industries, lost $25,000 a year. Would the union members put up with it or would they work harder in the hope that `She'll be right mate; things will get better'? Would they stand by and watch as their homes were sold from under them because, no matter how hard they worked, they could not earn enough to break even, let alone make a profit?

The Prime Minister tells us that the recession is over. He should ask the primary producers. The Government should take a long hard look at rural Australia if it is really fair dinkum about getting Australia out of recession. It has to ask itself why every year a thousand farmers in South Australia alone are closing the farm gate and walking away. A few weeks ago, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Crean, actually admitted that more Australian farmers are in trouble, particularly in the wheat industry. While it was very big of Mr Crean to make that admission, it is too late; it is not enough. They are not just in trouble, they are courting disaster.

Minister Crean says that we are also going to lose jobs in agricultural industries, and yet this never gets to the front page of our newspapers. I wonder why the Government is not jumping up and down and talking about the loss of jobs in the rural sector, or is it because it considers that the jobs in manufacturing industries in the cities are more important? For example, in the car industry where efforts have been made to protect those jobs and ensure they are kept, it is very difficult to argue that that industry employs more people. I can tell honourable senators that direct employment in the car industry is approximately 65,000. That is equivalent to the meat and dairy industry alone at 60,000, without counting the grain farmers, the woolgrowers, the fruit and vegetable growers, the vegetable processors, and so the list goes on. I cannot see why these jobs are any less important than those in manufacturing industry—a job is a job, and a recession is a recession.

Just a few weeks ago the President of the South Australian Farmers Federation, Tim Scholz, put forward a plan to rebuild rural Australia. The item he ranked of highest importance was the reduction of farm costs. So what is this Government doing to reduce imposed costs in order that our farm sector can improve its competitiveness? He also ranked the removal of several layers of marketing groups between the farmer and the market and the provision of commercial finance by the banking sector as very important. As he points out, the Government has its priorities wrong. Why have the interest rates on housing loans been much cheaper than on loans for the wealth-creating rural sector? Why have farmers been penalised for wanting to produce goods for our domestic market and for seeking to earn valuable export dollars?

I would be the first to agree that houses are important as are jobs in the housing industry. However, the bottom line is that we cannot export our houses to earn any foreign revenue whereas, on the other hand, a domestically and internationally competitive farmer can make a positive and continuing contribution to our balance of payments—or rather they would do so if they were given half the chance. Instead, primary producers are leaving the land and joining unemployment queues. In fact, rural Australia's population decreased from 21.8 per cent of the national total some 30-odd years ago to 13.5 per cent in 1986.

I am aware of the time constraints that we are putting on this debate and I close by making a couple of other comments. This 1992 Budget will do absolutely nothing to arrest the decline of the rural sector or to stop farmers selling up and joining unemployment queues. Why is that? It is because farmers and people in primary production are not traditional Labor voters and they certainly are not protected industry workers.

At least on this side of the chamber we know, following extensive consultation with the rural sector, that we have the policies that will keep farmers on the land and enable them to plan their futures with a degree of certainty and confidence. Some of the initiatives that will ensure this are the doubling of the family allowance for families with incomes of less than $30,000, of which there are plenty in the rural sector, and smaller increases for families on higher incomes; a 6 per cent increase in family allowance supplement; tax credits for low income families who take out private health cover; the abolition of the assets test for assistance for isolated children; the suspension of the assets test for Austudy payment for families suffering hardship; an increase in the dependent spouse rebate; no assets test for retirees living on the family farm; and personal income tax cuts. That is not to mention the abolition of the petrol excise which has a profound effect on people who live long distances from the metropolitan areas.

In fact, under a coalition Government, farm businesses will, on average, be $8,000 a year better off. What better endorsement for the introduction of the coalition's Fightback package could there be than that resounding one from the National Farmers Federation. If all these measures were combined, we would have the makings of an economic recovery which might start this country up again and ensure the future of all Australians and their families. The stage is set and our policies are in place. For Australia's sake, I call on the Government to bring on polling day to ensure that we are given the opportunity to make it happen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, look forward to polling day because we will again see the re-election of a Labor Government. This Budget is good news for people in Australia, particularly those living in rural areas, despite what Senator Ferguson would have us believe. It contains some far-reaching initiatives in the areas of rural health, environment and conservation, and the area that concerns us all here—jobs, particularly jobs for young Australians and the long term unemployed.

PARA.TAB: Let me deal with health first because that is an issue of great personal interest to me. A big impact on rural areas is the fact that we have difficulty getting facilities, services and doctors to move to country areas. This Budget moves to redress that situation. We have moved to redress the shortage of general practitioners in rural and remote areas with the introduction of a comprehensive incentives package. It is more than just offering practitioners money; it is offering them the ability to access locums, to attend in-services and to keep their skills at the levels necessary to deal with the very broad range of medical problems and emergencies that arise for those doctors practising in rural areas, particularly where they may be some distance from large hospitals.

If there is a serious motor vehicle accident, doctors in rural areas have to provide the emergency first aid and stabilise the patients before they can be moved off by road ambulance, air ambulance or the Royal Flying Doctor Service. In some cases the nurses have to stabilise the patients while they wait for the Royal Flying Doctor Service. This is an important issue, but we do not hear anything about it from the Opposition. It is ignored.

We have also introduced measures to provide more flexible and innovative services which better meet the diverse range of needs in small communities. We have introduced measures to ensure that people who need greater levels of care, such as those with a disability or the frail aged, do not have to leave their communities to get access to health care and community services. We have also introduced action to assist those waiting for elective surgery, particularly those in rural and remote communities who are significantly disadvantaged because of their physical location.

The measures outlined above have been taken to reduce the disadvantages faced by many Australians due entirely to where they live. We aim to make health and related care accessible to everyone who needs it and affordable both to the local community and the nation as a whole and have it delivered in a way that is acceptable to a wide range of rural communities.

Other important changes introduced in the Budget which will benefit average and low income earning Australians include an increase in the age pension from next January, combined with the extension of availability of the pensioner health concession card and an increase in rent assistance. Families will benefit through changes in the way family allowance supplement is paid. Under the Opposition's scheme we would see the raising from 60 to 65 years of the eligibility age at which women can claim the age pension.

We would also see eligibility for a sole parent pension change. Instead of being eligible for a sole parent pension and support until the child is 16, the Opposition plan is to remove that support once the child hits 12. I do not know very many parents who feel happy suddenly having to leave 12- to 16-year-olds at home to their own devices. It is an age where children still require, if the parent has decided that he or she wants to parent full time, some supervision and guidance. Supervision is a strong word, but children certainly require guidance from their family, from their parent. This Opposition is going to remove that choice from the sole parents of Australia.

An issue related to health is that of access to a reliable and clean water supply. That is probably the first element in health care. I am pleased to be able to point to the expenditure in this Budget of $17m on the national Landcare program which will enable Landcare groups in western New South Wales to expand their involvement in land and water resource management, and more effectively address the serious problems of environmental degradation in the western region of New South Wales. All of those senators who take an interest in rural areas would be aware of the level of interest in land care, and public awareness of the issue is still expanding at a great rate. I know that the Government is keen to support this trend and ensure that our funds effectively support on-ground activities, encourage landholder participation, and build the capacity of landholders to manage their properties in an economically viable and environmentally sustainable manner.

The strategy used by the national Landcare program has been to promote activity by local landholders and to target funds to areas of greatest need. Programs associated with the national Landcare program include the national soil conservation program, which received a total of $26.2m this year. Over $1m of this funding has been committed to various projects in western New South Wales. The country towns water supply and improvement program has been allocated between $2,000 and $167,000 for upgrading of the water supplies in towns such as White Cliffs and Murrami. The Murray-Darling Basin program includes the allocation of $495,000 to complete the rehabilitation of the Nyngan levees. No longer will we be facing the prospect of helicopters evacuating people from Nyngan as the Bogan River comes over the levee banks. There is also $125,000 for a land and water management program at the Jemalong and Wyldes Plains areas. These are all important issues for the people of rural Australia.

In this Budget, the goal of the Government has been to achieve a more integrated approach to addressing important issues in resource management and to encourage more effective and efficient solutions. A new national Landcare program framework to encompass land, water and related vegetation activities has been developed and will be progressively put in place over the coming year. The programs I have outlined that are contained in this Budget are a measure of the Federal Government's commitment to this plan and to rural Australia.

Another program that has been widely commented upon is the local government capital works program. I am pleased to say that $105m of that was made available to New South Wales under this program. A number of councils in western New South Wales have received significant funding, and I would reply to Senator Ferguson's allegations that these funds have gone to Labor areas by saying that that is an absolute furphy—the greatest load of garbage and hogwash I have ever heard. I suggest that he go and talk to Mr Cobb and Mr Hicks and to other people to whose electorates some of these programs have gone—to Mr Anderson in Gwydir, in Parkes, for example. Broken Hill Council received in excess of $700,000 because that area has a high unemployment rate. That is currently in the electorate of Riverina-Darling, which is a strong National Party seat. Senator Ferguson said that the money has gone to Labor areas. That is rubbish. It has gone to areas in need, and that is vitally important.

I will shortly take some time to look at what the Opposition would do to employment, what it would do to discourage and not to assist local councils or the CES and the Department of Employment, Education and Training in doing something about having effective programs in place.

It became very clear to this Government that local government has a very important role to play in these programs. That was borne out at the youth summit, where local government could actually say `We have programs ready to go', and they have demonstrated that. The funding under the capital works program will enable councils to implement important local economic, civic, tourist and cultural infrastructure projects and will provide an important stimulus to the local economy as well as worthwhile permanent assets.

I really cannot get past what a Dr Hewson-led coalition government would do to local government. Local government funding would be cut three ways by Dr Hewson and it would be taxed. Direct funding to local government from the Federal Government would be cut, local government funding from the States would be cut, and funding for programs administered by local government would also be cut. Then, of course, a large number of its services would be subject to the goods and services tax or, should I say, the consumption tax—anything the Opposition deems to be a commercial service. That covers things such as rates, electricity, water supply and sewerage. The list goes on and on; it depends on the services local governments offer. These are all going to attract an extra tax of 15 per cent where currently they have no tax upon them. That is the sort of thing the Opposition would do in government, and I warn people to think very carefully about that.

We have also introduced many labour market programs. In this financial year we are spending $1,150m which will assist more than 400,000 job seekers. We are building on the February One Nation statement. We are increasing the Jobskills program—$110m will be spent to increase that program. I should tell those people who were complaining that councils did not have access to government assistance that those councils in western New South Wales who did not receive capital works funding and those who did receive it have made very good use of the Jobskills program. They have used that program to enable them to undertake a number of projects which are already of benefit to their community. They are a twofold benefit to the community because the facilities are being built, repaired or maintained and jobs are being provided. This is totally forgotten by the Opposition.

The sum of $29m will go to the Office of Labour Market Adjustment. We never hear a thing about that from the Opposition. We are giving money to vocational support and the landcare and environment action program. The list goes on and on. We are looking at and caring about this problem because we have a history of doing so.

In addition, we should look at what the Opposition would do and make a comparison. Firstly, the Opposition would abolish the Commonwealth Employment Service and transfer its activity testing to the Department of Social Security. That is fine, but I start off by saying that there are 53 fewer Social Security offices in Australia than CES offices. I am not talking about small communities. There is no Department of Social Security office in places like Singleton, Cooma, Bowral, Cowra, Young—and the list goes on. These are not small communities. They have populations of nearly 10,000 and the shires have populations of between 12,000 and 13,000. These offices will be abolished and there will be one less government service to the people who live in rural areas. Fifty-three areas will miss out.

The coalition does not tell us how it plans to conduct the activity testing if these 53 CES offices of the Department of Employment, Education and Training are removed. Some National Party members have suggested that they do see a role for the local employment committee, which I will turn to later. That is an issue that the coalition has totally overlooked.

The coalition would transfer the administration of labour market programs to local employment boards. It would contract out employment placement functions and abolish the Jobsearch allowance after nine months. These changes would impact greatly on those living in country areas. Part of the coalition's change concerns activity testing and those who are unemployed for more than six months and less than nine months will be required to provide fortnightly letters from two employers, plus have proof that they have contacted four other employers, saying that they have actually gone looking for jobs.

In small rural communities there might only be six businesses which employ people. What will the people do? They will be forced to keep revisiting these businesses once a fortnight to get their piece of paper and after nine months they totally lose their Jobsearch allowance. We are told that those in need will be able to apply for special benefits. Of course, the criteria to qualify for special benefits will be tightened up. Any senator whose constituents have attempted to access special benefits these days would be very much aware that this benefit is very difficult to get. The Opposition totally disregards that issue.

I turn now to local employment boards, which is another one of the Opposition's plans. The Opposition will abolish the CES and have volunteer bodies coordinating local employment strategies. I suggest that this concept is flawed because there will be no national coordination or approach to job creation or training. It means that each local area will be able to do what it wants to do and be a law totally unto itself. Therefore, people in the same circumstances would find themselves treated differently depending upon where they live. The quality of help would depend upon the time and the energy of the volunteers.

There would be potential for favouritism, and personalities, family ties and obligations could play an inappropriate role in the decision taken in individual cases. We already have the situation in small rural communities where everybody's business is known by just about the whole community. But this would just expand upon this lack of privacy and increase the loss of privacy and confidentiality that people feel that they should be entitled to if they are unemployed and if they are seeking assistance. I feel that these boards have the potential to divide the community. There is more than a hint in this program of deserving and undeserving poor or unemployed. It reminds me somewhat of the workhouses in England of the last century which were governed by local boards.

I also have grave concerns about the contracting out of employment functions in rural areas. I do not know how it is going to work. Employment agencies—those that offer their services—have to be profit making; they have to make money to survive. I do not see the economic rewards being there to encourage them to set up in rural areas.

It is an added impost on business because the service has to be paid for by the employer, and it is usually related to the annual salary package of the employee; it is about 10 to 20 per cent of the annual salary. Then, of course, on top of that we have to add the 15 per cent consumption tax because that is a service and it attracts the consumption tax. That is all an added impost to business. It is an impost that it has not had before.
I have also mentioned that the Opposition is going to attack the sole parent pensions, and it is going to raise the age for women's age pensions.

—We have heard some interjections here about payroll tax. I remind people that small business, on the whole, does not pay payroll tax. The State of New South Wales requires that employers have a wages or salary component of half a million dollars before they have to pay a payroll tax, which means that most small businesses do not pay payroll tax.

PARA.TAB: A lot of the people that I have spoken to are already concerned about the impact that the GST is going to have upon their businesses. We go from having 70,000 wholesales sales tax points of collection to nearly one million points of tax collection under the GST. This means a lot of extra work for small business and a lot of extra costs in compliance time. I can do nothing more than quote Ruth Richardson as reported in the Australian Taxpayer, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Ruth Richardson, now Finance Minister in New Zealand, told me that as a politician she was committed to a GST—but as a woman she was concerned that the `wives of small businessmen' would have to spend Saturdays or two nights a week doing the bookwork.
This is from the people in New Zealand who have actually introduced this and now are living with the problems.

PARA.TAB: I know of a supermarket owner in western New South Wales who has never in his life voted Labor. He is a National Party supporter, possibly a National Party member. He has done his figures and estimates that his business will have to find an extra $100,000 with the introduction of the consumption tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is all paid back, you silly little thing!

—Senator McDonald says that it will all be paid back. What the Opposition fails to recognise is that this requires people to do paperwork. Small business has much more to do with its time than spend it on non-productive paperwork. The reforms that we have taken and the new measures outlined in the Budget provide a clear alternative between a Federal Labor Government committed to working with the community to repair the damage caused by the recession and build on the considerable reforms already made in previous years, and an Opposition which would walk away from these responsibilities and leave the community at the mercy of the unregulated market forces.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —With the 1992-93 Budget, the Government has yet again presented to the people of Australia an economic plan which, for the fifth time in 18 months, has failed to address the fundamental problems that are facing this country. The Senate will recall the failed attempts of the Government previously to get the economy back on track, including the May 1991 economic statement, the 1991 Budget, the November 1991 jobs statement, the One Nation statement and this Budget.

PARA.TAB: Ever since I entered the Senate in February last year, this Government has been trying to get the economy back on track, having previously created the situation where Australia was the first country to move into recession. The net result of all these attempts to solve the economic problems that the ALP Government created in the first place with the recession that we had to have has been record unemployment, record bankruptcies, skyrocketing overseas debt and Budget debt, lower real income levels over 10 years, decreased savings, an inefficient tax system, record interest rates for most of its term in office and micro-economic reform which is moving at a snails pace, particularly in the labour market area. Having created this economic mess, this Government has now presented a Budget for 1992-93 which will once again tinker at the edges with no lasting solutions and certainly no vision for the future of Australia.

Essentially, this Budget is a dishonest Budget. It is a cynical and blatant attempt by this failed Government to try to buy its way back into office. Unlike the coalition's visionary Fightback package, the measures contained in this Budget are simply not financed. As Senator Short said in his opening comment to this debate on the Appropriations Bill, this is a Budget bought on Bankcard.

Max Walsh, a noted financial journalist, commented directly after the release of the Budget that what Mr Dawkins has really done is bring down the largest peacetime Budget deficit in Australian history. The stated Budget deficit is $13.4 billion. If this were converted to $1 coins and these coins were placed in a line, they would stretch eight and a half times around the world. Even this shocking result was achieved only by a $1.6 billion asset sale to reduce the Budget shortfall.

The net figure of $13.4 billion, however, is also rubbery. It is based upon a number of dubious financial assumptions including the predicted profits from the Reserve Bank, the manipulated dividend from AOTC and the clever removal of one Public Service pay period from this financial year to the next. All up, we really have a Budget deficit of $20.3 billion—I repeat, $20.3 billion. The projected forecasts of the flow-on effect of the Budget are $50 billion, accumulated in deficits that are unfunded.

The longest serving Labor Prime Minister of this country, Bob Hawke, has also canned this Budget. He has questioned its credibility and the credibility of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Treasurer. The Budget does not deal with the fundamental underlying problems facing the country. It does nothing about economic growth, which ultimately creates jobs.

This Budget does not offer any solutions to economic problems; it only services them. It does not create real jobs; it just hides people away in make-work schemes and training schemes to keep them off the unemployment queues. Throwing funds around so that the youth of Australia can go out and paint white rocks is not a way of solving the unemployment problems that face this country. It certainly does not do much for their future prospects either.

Contained in this Budget is a pathetically transparent attempt at pork-barrelling as Labor tries to buy its way back into government. Despite what Senator West said, the funding made available under the employment scheme for local government areas is quite clearly targeted to marginal Labor seats around the country, with the local government area in the Prime Minister's seat gaining the largest slice. That is bad luck for a person who happens to be one of the long term unemployed in Turramurra in Sydney. Because of the rather peculiar way that this Government distributed the funding, that person's council will receive no additional money under this scheme.

Real job creation is about productive long term jobs that do not finish when the Budget money runs out. Job creation also involves removing the restrictions on the private sector, removing the red, black and green tape that so ties up business in this country and letting businesses get on with the job of running business. It involves giving incentives to people to work hard, allowing people to reap the rewards from their work and not putting them in a position where they give most of the money back to the Government through either direct or indirect hidden taxes.

The main thrust of Fightback is about giving back choice to individuals rather than letting them be told by Federal bureaucrats what is best for them. Our alternative Budget would have created a smaller, less regulatory government and it would have allowed the private sector to breathe, grow and flourish and, in the process, create the jobs that this country so desperately needs. Under Fightback, seven taxes will be removed, the labour market will be reformed and there will be a reduction in the cost disadvantage to business by 20 to 50 per cent.

Fightback is the most aggressively pro-business and pro-growth policy produced by any political party in Australia's history. A growing private sector will allow business to employ people. It will allow business to take our youth off the unemployment queues, away from white rock painting and into real jobs. A growing private sector will give back to our youth the chance to make the most of their abilities and to seize the opportunities to reap rewards from their work. Fightback will create the economic environment to bring them out of despair and it will give them hope for the future. The Salvation Army said in its submission to the Government on the preparation of the 1992-93 Budget:

SPEECH.PARA: No matter how good our welfare provision is, it can never take the place of work which enables people to provide proper care for themselves and their families.
Secure employment for all must be the central plank of Government policy. Only by this means can we insure against the rise in poverty that we have experienced in recent years.

Linked to this need for the creation of job opportunities is the need for proper support in education and training so that our young people will have a fair chance to compete for the jobs that are available. The training policies of this Government over the last 10 years have been a disaster.

PARA.TAB: When the Australian experience is compared with that of our OECD competitors, it is obvious that we are falling behind. Our most successful competitors, such as Japan, Germany and the United States, have post-compulsory participation rates that are more than double our own. At a time when Australian competitors are placing an increasing emphasis on education and training and students in other countries are receiving enhanced educational opportunities, the availability of education of world class standard to our young people has diminished.

Years have been wasted by this Government, which has totally neglected vocational education and training for young people in both quantity and quality. It has had a great preoccupation with participation rates in schooling and hiding people on dole queues. Belatedly, after 10 years, this Government has discovered vocational education. Almost 30 years ago, Donald Horne, in his landmark book, The Lucky Country, warned that Australia would have to train its work force to a more highly skilled level if we were to adapt in a more competitive world.

—Is the Minister for Industrial Relations aware of a report produced in the Department of Industrial Relations entitled Making Time—Flexibility in the Workplace? Does this report show that a wide range of companies are using the Government's industrial relations system to introduce more flexible working arrangements? Does the report show that the Government's managed system of workplace bargaining provides companies with the flexibility they need to become internationally competitive?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —This report demonstrates that John Howard's characterisation of industrial relations in Australia as rigid, overly centralised and inflexible is totally wrong; it is just not true. This is the report referred to: it is a report I have released today. It has been prepared by a visiting officer to my Department, Mr John Keily, who in his normal life is the group industrial relations manager of Shell Australia. He was on secondment to my Department from Shell Australia in order to complete this study.

PARA.TAB: This report is a study of the flexibilities in the Australian labour market, taking as case examples a number of companies. The Australian and New Zealand Bank is one, and the report shows that the staff hours are flexibly altered to meet customer demand.

ICI at Botany is another example, which shows that a composite annual salary has been developed which replaces the old base rate, overtime and all the other allowances. The Sheraton Southgate Towers Hotel is another of the case examples undertaken in this study. This is the agreement negotiated by Mr Macphee and attacked by Mr Howard. It is a flexible agreement which has produced one all-up rate rather than a series of penalty rates. The South Australian Farmers Union has developed an agreement with its unions in which there is time off in lieu of overtime. Southern Cross Machinery has developed a situation in which there are longer working hours during the season but shorter working hours in the off season so that the annual outcome is the same but the hours have been flexibly adapted.

This is further evidence that the Opposition's allegations about alleged inflexibility in the Australian labour market are wrong and misleading. This is evidence of considerable flexibility, both sideways and upwards. The only flexibility this does not demonstrate, as Senator McKiernan will know, is flexibility to cut wages, make workers worse off and provide no protection and no safety net. That is what the Opposition wants to do. That is the Opposition's whole policy and there is no guarantee or protection at all.
We have had glib words and honeyed phrases from the Opposition about minimums and protections. Its leader, Dr Hewson, cannot explain it. The Opposition spokesman, Mr Howard, obfuscates the point—

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr President. The Minister concluded answering the question he was asked some time ago. He is now getting into the realm of discussing our policy, which is outside the Standing Orders, and beyond the question that he was asked. I ask that you bring him to order.

—On the point of order, Mr President: I am discussing flexibility and a study. The Opposition has made allegations and has participated in this debate on flexibility. It is relevant, in the discussion of flexibility in the answering of this question, to refer to the Opposition's cost cutting, low wage inflexibilities in the context of a decent safety net and real flexibilities.
—Order! I listened carefully to the Minister's answer and I think it was in order.

—I conclude by saying that I commend this study to Australians interested in the real facts of life in industrial relations. If they read this, they will not fall for the PR offensive being mounted by the Opposition to delude Australians into thinking that there are real guarantees.
