—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Can the Minister confirm that it is the Government's intention to maintain the taxation concession rate for business research and development at the rate of 150 per cent? Can the Minister provide the Senate with details of the growth in business R&D in recent years and the intrinsic importance of the tax concession to that growth?

—Senator Loosley has always taken a keen interest in these matters, and this is important. From the inception of this Government, we have, in terms of manufacturing and service industries, attached a great deal of importance to innovation. That is why in 1985 we introduced the 150 per cent tax concession for research and development. That policy is now paying off in terms of export figures for highly sophisticated and transformed manufacturing products. That decision in 1985 was an important part of the increase in expenditure by Australian firms on research and development. We have seen through the 1980s a 14 per cent growth in real terms in business or private sector R&D. Over the same period, patent applications overseas by Australian residents were higher than in any other country from the OECD. In this year's Budget the Government announced that the 150 per cent tax concession would be extended indefinitely, recognising the importance of R&D to international competitiveness.

PARA.TAB: I must say I was somewhat amused today to see the coalition has caught up with the Government on this issue. The shadow Minister for science and technology, Mr Peter McGauran, has put out a `me too' press release in which he says that a coalition government would maintain the tax concession rate at 150 per cent. It was only on 20 August that Mr McGauran ruled out any change. He said, `The game is over; 125 per cent is what you are going to get'. Now he has announced a change which will introduce an additional shortfall of between $110m and $125m in a Fightback package which already has a $6 billion black hole in it. So another $125m can be added on to that as a result of Mr McGauran's statement. So those opposite can always throw a few dollars when they want to.
What he tried, of course, was the Ian McLachlan line in August: 125 per cent is the same as 150 per cent. That is just not right.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Is this relevant to the question that was asked, or is it discussing our policy? I also draw to your attention that it seems to be discussion on a matter that is before the other House, if not this House, and I wonder whether that is appropriate as well.
—It is not a point of order. I think Senator Button was just developing an argument. I think so far it is in order.
—I was simply making the point that in terms of a lot of these issues—

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Mr President, in February 1987 you ruled that a Minister cannot be responsible for, or comment on, what the Opposition's policies are or are supposed to be. I put it to you that that was your ruling. Question Time has been constantly abused by Ministers by being used as a forum to attack the Opposition's policy, and I ask you to bring Ministers to order.

—I might speak to that point of order. This is an example of the totally disruptive conduct in respect of Question Time. I had said nothing after the last point of order before Senator Kemp was up making another point of order.

—Order! I say to Senator Kemp that there have been many occasions when I have ruled a question relating to the Opposition's policies out of order. We all know there are ways of asking a question and there are ways of not asking a question. I think Senator Button was relating his answer to the question and, therefore, the question is in order.

—I was just making the point that, in talking about these industry policy issues, decisions have to be made about them based on realistic and pragmatic circumstances relating to the condition of the Australian economy. The Liberal Party is now lumbering along behind as it has done in all these issues and as it did with the factor F scheme in pharmaceuticals. Last week Mr McLachlan said that it would now adopt the Government's pharmaceutical industry program. There is either a difference in Fightback or there is not.
—Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In light of the answer that Senator Button has given, is the Minister satisfied that the Government's R&D program has been both cost effective and well targeted?

—Of course, sometimes these things are costly. Sometimes they have to be done because of market failure. This is a classic example of a market failure which took place over eight or nine years of a coalition in government when private sector R&D in this country fell to the lowest proportion of any OECD country. This is the Opposition which puts itself up as an alternative government for business. When the world was changing, the Fraser Government allowed R&D in the private sector to drop to the lowest proportion of any country in the OECD. We have fixed that situation and it is important that it be done.

PARA.TAB: In terms of the program's targeting, it is a market related measure. People have to spend their money in the marketplace in order to attract this concession. That is what has happened. The results are seen in the huge increase in exports of elaborately transformed manufactures. The desperation of those opposite is shown in their consistent interjections about the unemployed, because that is all they have going for them now, nothing else, and they love it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade seen reports of comments made by the current Governor of East Timor that as far as he is concerned more people should have died in the Dili massacre and that the massacre was quite understandable? Has the Minister also seen recent reports of comments made by the current military commander of East Timor that the requested visit to Dili by Australian parliamentarians was probably deliberately chosen to cause trouble by `stirring up something', a comment which the Indonesian Government, and presumably the military commander, know to be patently untrue? Will the Minister yet again make strong representations to Indonesia about the internationally totally unacceptable attitudes of those in charge of this very troubled and extremely sensitive area?

—I have seen reports of comments made by Mr Abilio Soares which are part of an interview carried in an Indonesian language news magazine. Mr Soares's comments, if they were reported and translated accurately, are on any view extremely regrettable. They are inconsistent obviously with the position taken on the massacre by the Indonesian Government. They are particularly disappointing coming from someone who is himself a Timorese and obviously they will not help the cause of reconciliation in East Timor. It is to be hoped that the new Governor, as he becomes more familiar with his job and its responsibilities, will display rather more sensitivity to the human rights issues which trouble so many both in Indonesia and around the world.

PARA.TAB: We will certainly be taking the appropriate opportunity to make our concerns about Mr Soares's reported comments known to the Indonesians. I will in fact have an early opportunity to do so because I will be seeing the Indonesian Foreign Minister in Beijing on the weekend as part of the round of consultations on the Cambodia issue.

As to the second part of Senator Bourne's question, I have also seen the reports of the comments made by the Commander of the East Timor military command, Brigadier-General Theo Syafei, that the proposed visit to East Timor by the study tour of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade may have been deliberately timed to stir up trouble. Obviously, as Senator Bourne has acknowledged, there is no such intention on the part of the Committee. Brigadier-General Syafei's comments clearly represent, at the very least, a misunderstanding of the request to visit East Timor and the purpose of the visit as a whole.

The study tour, from the beginning, was seen as an opportunity—and I am sure this view was shared by the Indonesian Government generally—for the Committee inquiring into Australian-Indonesian relations to come to a better and more complete understanding of Indonesia. East Timor was to be just one part of the study tour which visited seven other provinces. It is regrettable—a matter for disappointment as I have also said—that, for a variety of reasons, the parliamentary committee was not able to get to East Timor on this occasion, but I do not think the reasons apparently advanced by Brigadier-General Syafei for that have any foundation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What is the Government's reaction to the massacre in Sri Lanka that reportedly occurred on 15 October and to the prospects for a peaceful settlement of the continuing ethnic conflict in that country?

—The massacres reported on 15 October are undoubtedly among the most horrifying single episodes of violence since the conflict in Sri Lanka began. According to official reports, 166 people, of whom 146 were civilians—many of them women and children—were killed by Tamil separatists, members of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, when they attacked four Muslim villages near Palea Gidela in north-east Sri Lanka.

PARA.TAB: The Sri Lankan Government has established a full-scale commission of inquiry to investigate the incident. We hope that report will be made public so that those directly responsible for this outrage can be clearly and unequivocally identified and condemned by the international community.

The Australian Government does deplore the continuing violence in Sri Lanka as manifested by this latest very tragic incident. We continue to urge both the Sri Lankan Government and the Tamil Tigers to continue to pursue avenues for a peaceful solution. Our High Commissioner in Colombo has expressed to the Sri Lankan Government at the highest levels our concern over renewed fighting which began in May this year. We continue to affirm Australia's preparedness to assist through our initiative involving a possible Commonwealth good offices role in the process of arriving at a peaceful solution. The Australian proposal, which I acknowledge is a bipartisan one, was first formally—

TALK.START.PARA: —Your initiative?

—Senator Hill should not be ungenerous; I am giving him a guernsey for once in his rotten little life. There is just no grace in this place, Mr President. The initiative was first formally put forward during my visit to Sri Lanka in August 1990, but it had been raised publicly, as I was about to say, by Senator Hill in his own conversations in Sri Lanka and with me. It was subsequently confirmed in a letter from Mr Hawke to President Premadasa on 11 September 1990. It remains on the table.

PARA.TAB: We are conscious that the Commonwealth's involvements in the internal affairs of Sri Lanka can only come about as a result of a direct request from the Sri Lankan Government and with the broad support of other Commonwealth members. A focus of moves is presently on a multi-party parliamentary select committee. We look forward to the report of that committee which is expected towards the end of the year. We hope it will come up with some worthwhile suggestions for a way out of the present agonising impasse in Sri Lanka.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. Is it a fact that a private borrower of funds has an obligation to disclose to the lender all material information which may affect the value or cost of borrowings immediately; and if a borrower knowingly fails to do so, could he or she be charged with an offence of fraud; and if anyone else conspired with the borrower to conceal the information from the lender, would they also be guilty of an offence?

—I would not have thought that that was a matter which fell under State criminal code provisions, in any case. Quite apart from that, it is requiring a legal opinion to be offered by me and I do not intend to give that.
—A fairly tortured way of raising the Victorian borrowings!

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister whether he draws any distinction between the public and private sectors, or is there a rule that says that some pigs are more equal than others?
—It is quite clear that the supplementary depended on an answer which I did not give. So there is no answer to the supplementary.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. What interactions with the Chinese Government have assured the Minister of the safety and safe treatment of unsuccessful applicants for asylum in Australia? How does the Minister intend to ensure the safety and safe treatment of those refugee applicants who were deported from Australia on Friday, 23 October? Finally, what actions will the Australian Government take to monitor the continued well-being of unsuccessful applicants and has the Government approached the International Committee of the Red Cross or the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees to assist in monitoring of the treatment of deportees?

—In answer to Senator Chamarette, I understand that the Australian Government has had discussions with the relevant authorities, the PRC authorities in Australia, about the return of PRC nationals who arrived in Australia by boat. The PRC authorities have provided assurances that failed asylum seekers who are returned to China will not be punished as a result of their illegal departure from China. I understand that these assurances were reiterated prior to the recent removal from Australia of seven persons whose applications for refugee status, as we know, have been rejected. The Australian Government will monitor the general situation of return to China and the subsequent treatment of failed asylum seekers.

PARA.TAB: In the case of the seven recently returned failed asylum seekers, discussions with PRC officials have occurred in both Canberra and Beijing following their return to China. In other words, the Chinese authorities have been asked about the situation, although I do not know that a full response has been received as yet. At this stage neither the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees nor the International Committee of the Red Cross have been requested to assist with the monitoring of the treatment of returnees.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer the Minister to his answer yesterday to a question of mine when he said that he became aware of the breach of Loan Council borrowings limits `probably some time in late July'. I ask the Minister: what action did he take on becoming aware of this breach?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I notice that the honourable senator's colleague Senator Short has put out a press release today which is naughty, if not reprehensible. It says:

ANSWER.PARA: Now it has also been revealed that the Government's senior Minister in the Senate, Senator Button, was also in on the cover-up.

That is fairly typical of Senator Short. I was asked yesterday by Senator Hill when I first became aware of this matter. I answered, `In late July'. I had better tell honourable senators opposite the circumstances so they can all rest easily. I was walking along the passage in the ministerial wing with Mr Dawkins and we had a bit of a chat about the forthcoming Victorian election, when it would be and so on. He asked me something about it as I am a Victorian senator and resident. I told him something about it and he said to me, `Look, I am having some difficulty with the Government down there, getting information out of them about their financial situation'. That is what Mr Dawkins said to me. I regard that as a statement by Mr Dawkins at the time that he was having concerns about this matter and was pursuing it. He said that.

PARA.TAB: In so far as the answer I gave yesterday is concerned, I should rectify one other thing in order to get it right. I said that I was not going to tell people what happened in Cabinet about any of these matters. It is not my habit to answer in relation to Cabinet discussions. I add to that today that Cabinet at no time considered this matter. I add that simply because of this sort of press release. Cabinet at no time considered this matter because it was a matter between the Treasurer and the Government of Victoria because the Treasurer—if honourable senators over there can finally get it into their heads—is Chairman of the Loan Council. That was what it was about.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't you say this yesterday?

—Probably because I was interrupted by Senator Macdonald. The Treasurer, as Chairman of the Loan Council, is responsible for these negotiations and it is not a matter appropriate for Cabinet. I would have thought an alternative government might have understood that—but as I go on listening to those opposite, I realise that they do not understand anything.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of that astonishing answer, I remind the Minister that yesterday I asked him the question: when did he become aware of Victorian Labor's massive breach of Loan Council borrowing. It was a simple question, and there was a simple answer: `Probably sometime in late July'. Is the Minister now saying that the answer he gave to the Senate yesterday was incorrect?

—What I am saying is simply this. In the course of my discussion with Mr Dawkins, he said to me that he was dissatisfied with answers he was getting from the Victorian Government about its financial matters and he was trying to get more information from it in his capacity, of course, as Chairman of the Loan Council—because he has no other way of doing it, he has no other capacity in which to do it. Again, this indicates Senator Hill's ignorance about these matters and it just makes the point I made in answer to the first question.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Is the Minister aware that the Government's tariff cutting program has produced a rising flood of imports with TCF products showing import penetration close to 50 per cent, heavy engineering 60 per cent, furniture 35 per cent, and cars with an increase of 40 per cent in one year alone; and that this rising tide of imports is a major factor in seasonally adjusted unemployment rising from 6.7 per cent only 2 1/4 years ago to 11.1 per cent in June this year? In view of these trends, is the Government prepared to consider a 12-month pause in tariff cuts now that a substantial number of the Minister's own parliamentary colleagues at last weekend's Canberra conference have joined the Democrats, the ACTU and major industry associations in calling for such a pause?

—The first part of the question makes some allegations about what purport to be matters of fact—and I do not know where Senator Spindler gets his facts or so-called facts from. For example, the position in relation to textile, clothing and footwear imports is simply this. Last year the import penetration in relation to textiles was 56 per cent, in 1985-86 it was 59 per cent, and it has been higher or as high in most years throughout the 1980s. There is nothing new about the import penetration in relation to textiles. If we take clothing and footwear, import penetration in 1991-92 was 27 per cent, which is one of the lowest figures for import penetration of a so-called sophisticated industrial economy anywhere in the world. It is, in fact, lower than the import penetration for manufacturing generally.

PARA.TAB: If I may take another example, the imports of motor vehicles, it is true, that went up to 40 per cent and it has since declined. It went up to 40 per cent for a variety of very good reasons, namely, that the market was seeking smaller cars here and we do not manufacture many small cars.

Senator Spindler went on to say that the rising tide of imports, as he called it, is a factor in high unemployment, rising from 6.7 per cent 2 1/4 years ago to 11.1 per cent in June this year. What does the honourable senator think was happening to tariffs 2 1/4 years ago or more than 2 1/4 years ago? They were going down and the Democrats were complaining about it. What has happened since? There has been a recession. If the Democrats do not understand that, they ought to have a discussion with coalition members because they do not understand anything else. Have a talk with Senator Panizza. He knows nothing else except that. Senator Spindler ought to have a bit of a chat about that.

To make the illogical leap from some rising import penetration in some industries and relating it to unemployment without also looking at the issue of export propensity, which has been huge across manufacturing, and to draw the wrong conclusions about that, renders the whole premise of the honourable senator's question silly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, Senator Kemp will give the Democrats some help if they want it afterwards. He approaches every problem with an open mouth. He can help the Democrats with this and they will be able to sort it out with him. They will get no help from us. The answer to the second part of the question is no.
—Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am afraid that I do not accept the Minister's answer in terms of the figures he has quoted. I would be happy to put on the public record the sources of the figures that I have quoted to him. I really do wonder how long the Government and the Minister are going to ignore the rising opinion which is now well and truly documented—
—Order! Please ask the supplementary, Senator Spindler.
—For how long is the Government prepared to continue to ignore the opinions that are being expressed by its own members?

—We do not ignore opinions which are expressed. They are important points of view, but we do not happen to share them. We have to make judgments about these things. We have made a number of judgments. We made a number of judgments about the way to make Australian industry more outward looking, more export oriented, more productive and so on.

PARA.TAB: I think Senator Spindler should try to focus on some of those issues rather than focus on the negative issues of the past which produced very inward looking industry sectors in this country. This country cannot be an island away from the rest of the world. It has to be participating in a global economy and the vast improvement in export figures of manufactures shows that we are now beginning to do that. I do not think Senator Spindler should discourage it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry asked the ILO to rule that the Government's 10,000 minimum membership requirement for trade unions is in breach of ILO conventions 87 and 98, which guarantee freedom of association? Has the ILO already upheld a similar complaint from New Zealand? Will the Government repeal the 10,000 minimum membership requirement if the ILO finds it has breached the conventions? Will the Government repeal section 118 of the Industrial Relations Act, which prevents trade union members from joining the union of their choice?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the first question, yes, the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry—or the Australian Confederation of Industry, as it was at the time—made an application under freedom of association conventions, which exist to protect the rights of unions to exist in a society, to strike down or find to be in contravention the 10,000 minimum rule. I have said—and I said it at the time the application was made—that if the ILO were to find that way, we would amend our Act accordingly because we regard the rule of international law in terms of the ILO as important. It is something that a country like Australia should always be concerned to observe.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, I might also say that I have before me another finding made by the ILO—a finding which the then Confederation of Australian Industry found uncomfortable. I have not moved on this finding. However, if I were to move on the minimum size of unions, I would have to look at it.

According to the ILO committee of experts, the finding is that Australian domestic law is in contravention of ILO conventions on the right to strike. There is no right to strike in Australia by reason of the existence of tort law and sections 45D and 45E. If the ILO—which currently has the question of minimum size before it and is expected this day Geneva time to make a decision about it—were to find that the minimum size rule should be brought into conformity, I would go straight to the National Labour Consultative Council and ask the employers of this country, since they have raised this matter, whether they now want me to bring all areas the ILO has raised with Australia into conformity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. We have had an answer to a question I did not ask and a non-answer to another question I asked—that is, will the Government repeal section 118 of the Industrial Relations Act, which prevents trade union members from joining the union of their choice?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have said that we will observe international labour conventions. If one wants to talk about international labour conventions, the other ILO finding is that the New South Wales Government is in contravention of the ILO convention dealing with the right to strike on the basis that it has defined essential services more broadly than the definition in the convention in order to bring other workers not in essential services into that definition and free from the right to strike. This is exactly what the Kennett Government is doing; it is exactly what the John Howard industrial relations policy would do.

PARA.TAB: Since Senator Durack has had the honesty to raise a question about the rule of ILO conventions, I hope he has the courage of his convictions to stand up in the party room, should there ever be an effort made by the coalition to implement law in Australia in contravention of international standards.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Industrial Relations whether he is aware of today's figures on industrial disputes published by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. Does the Minister agree that these figures show new record lows in industrial disputes? Do these figures show that the accord has produced a cooperative industrial relations climate in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia has a growing international reputation as a country where there is a low level of industrial disputation. We have an increasing reputation for being a reliable supplier and we have a record of attracting investment, particularly in manufacturing industry, which values and cherishes the industrial harmony this Government has been able to bring to the country.

PARA.TAB: One of the key factors in that is that through the period of our Government, under the accord, we have reduced the level of industrial disputation. Even in years of high economic growth and a good bargaining position for unions in the market, industrial disputes have decreased. We have shown that we are able to manage industrial relations far better than the coalition could ever hope to do.

It is not surprising, therefore, to find that, in the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures released today on industrial disputes for this country for the month of July, almost every record in the book is broken in terms of the low level of industrial disputes. The total number of working days lost in July 1992 was the lowest in this country since 1958, and the total number of working days lost per 1,000 employees was at a record low level. Last year the Greiner Government had industrial confrontation, which wrecked our record a little. The APPM dispute in Tasmania earlier this year—the closest personification of the Opposition's industrial relations policy—wrecked those figures again.

Let us turn now to Victoria and look at the current state of play. The figures for July on industrial disputes in Victoria were a mere 69 per cent below the national average. There were 69 per cent fewer industrial disputes in Victoria than the ruling national average. That is an example of a Labor Government working in consort with a Federal Labor Government, managing industrial relations very well and developing the ethic of cooperation in the workplace rather than confrontation and conflict.

Enter Jeff Kennett. I do not want to make any doomsday predictions, but any person, irrespective of his point of view in this debate, must now say that Australia's international reputation as a good industrial relations country is about to be wrecked. This will have a devastating impact on our standing for investment and our reputation overseas. I hope that Mr Kennett backs off and sees the error of his ways, but I do not expect that he will, being the bull-headed person that he is. Despite reports in today's newspapers that many in the Opposition asked Mr Howard and Mr Reith to stand shoulder to shoulder with him and support him, I do not expect that the Opposition will, either.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Industrial Relations noted the comment of the Chief Executive of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, Mr Ian Spicer, that most workplace agreements are not achieving substantial workplace reform or, to use his own words, were uninspiring and would do little to improve productivity? Is that not contrary to his own claims that workplace agreements are achieving substantial workplace reform? Are not Mr Spicer's comments substantiated by Australia's abysmal productivity performance and the decline in real income that has occurred during the past decade? How does the Minister explain the discrepancy between Mr Spicer's views and his own, which were expressed in response to Senator McKiernan's question, and that of his hired gun's report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Spicer is wrong. As the spokesperson for the employer organisation in Australia that at every national wage case in the history of this country has stood up and said that no worker in Australia should ever get a wage increase, the views being expressed by Mr Spicer are not surprising. But none of the companies that have struck these workplace agreements with unions and have had them registered in the Commission would agree with Mr Spicer.

PARA.TAB: Earlier today, in answering a question by Senator McKiernan, I gave case examples of high quality, productivity producing and cooperative ethic instilling industrial relations worked out between employers and employees with the aid of their unions and negotiators. I have absolutely no compunction in saying that Mr Spicer may well feel that the institutional role of an employers' body is undermined when employers deal directly with their own work force and negotiate industrial relations agreements with the work force unions.

Let me talk about the question of productivity and quote from the West Australian of last week. An employer, JLV, said that it had concluded a workplace agreement and got a productivity increase of 25 per cent. Turnover had risen from $6m to $14m. The article states—and I will quote these words and leave the debate at this point:
Company general manager Bill Johnson attacked the coalition's industrial relations policy, saying it was loaded in employers' favour and would not give workers a chance in the bargaining process.

ANSWER.PARA: `What's the use of having a disempowered workforce', Mr Johnson said. `You want your workforce to be vibrant, you want them to be skilled, you want them to feel good about themselves, you want to feel empowered, you want them to have respect for themselves and you want them to have respect for you'.
The next quote is as follows:
`You don't get that with pickaxe handle industrial negotiations and that's what the Liberals are trying to bring back'.
That is a comment from an employer who has successfully made the workplace bargaining options and the flexibility available under our system work effectively for him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister whether he noted the comment of Mr Palmer of Palmer Tube Mills, who recently returned to Australia, that one of the greatest disincentives to investment in the manufacturing industry was when visiting delegations from Australia made the remark that agreements on industrial relations here were made between governments and unions. This not only made him wince, but it was a disincentive to investment. So how does the Minister explain that in respect of the answer he gave?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a totally extraordinary allegation. The growth in manufacturing exports out of this country points to a very effective emergence of a new workplace culture, particularly in the Australian manufacturing industry. Senator Parer might be able to get one quisling to jump up and put a favourable complexion on the Opposition's policy, but I can tell him that the metal industry and, particularly, the manufacturing industry in Australia want to see us continuing with developing world best practice in Australian manufacture and an orderly framework of industrial relations.

PARA.TAB: Ask the Metal Trades Industry Association, the employer body in this case, whether it wants to go to the Howard model or to ours and that body will say unequivocally that it wants ours. It will say that for the very reason that the Opposition has proved beyond doubt that it does not understand ordinary Australian workers and how to manage a change in relationships and attitudes in the workplace. The Opposition wants more penalties and more expenses.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I preface my question by noting with approval the Minister's intention to take speedy parliamentary action to protect Victorian workers from the worst excesses of the draconian industrial relations policies of the Kennett Government in Victoria. Why then did the Minister, only three weeks ago, support the Democrats' committee reference on the question of sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act? Was this move intended to bury the issue until after the Federal election when, as Senator Bell has said, and I quote from the Melbourne Herald-Sun of 14 October, `the existing Government is not expected to be returned'? Will the Minister reconsider that committee reference and extend his empowerment to Victorian workers by implementing ALP and ACTU policy to repeal sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act before that election?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I fully expect that the Keating Government will be returned at the next election, and the opinion polls give me good reason for believing that. The performance of the Opposition's industrial relations policy is the second other good reason for believing that.

PARA.TAB: It is an established fact, confirmed this weekend by Mr Howard and Mr Reith out of their own mouths, that Jeff Kennett lied to the Victorian electors before the election when he promised that none of them would lose a cent due to industrial relations changes, and that after the election he took away the holiday annual leave loading. Both Mr Howard and Mr Reith have said that Mr Kennett in effect lied to the Victorian electorate.

Of course, the only difference between the Opposition's industrial relations policy and that of Mr Kennett is that Mr Kennett is a bit cruder and the Opposition is a bit more oily about how it presents the lack of protections under its policy. But it seems that in dealing with the problems in Victoria the most essential thing is to enable the Victorians to access the Federal jurisdiction of the Industrial Relations Commission, protect their awards, have real minimum protections and access to an arbitrator in the event of disputes that cannot be settled by negotiation, mediation or conciliation, so that they have somewhere to go and they have the basic safety net protections that our system offers.

So it is that I am currently examining the ways in which under the arbitration powers of the Constitution the Federal Industrial Relations Act can better accommodate or facilitate a transference of State awards, should the parties in Victoria wish that to be the case, from the State of Victoria to the Federal jurisdiction. This will protect and preserve the rights that Victorian workers and their employers currently enjoy, rather than to have that State beset by disputation and confrontation, the very nature of which Jeff Kennett is proposing to bring on. It seems that that is a most sensible and reasonable course for the Federal Government to take.

On the question of sections 45D and 45E, this Senate has decided to refer that to a committee of inquiry. I think that is an appropriate course of action to take. The events in Victoria will be an interesting counterpoint or backdrop to that inquiry as we see the events there unfold. I hope that inquiry will come to a speedy conclusion and offer intelligent advice to this Senate to remedy a problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. TALK.START.PARA: —I think it passing strange, with the greatest of respect, that when this Government brought forward legislation to repeal sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act it was defeated on a combined vote at the time by the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. There has been much debate in recent weeks on the Government's decision announced in the Budget to cut out the tax deductibility of non-compulsory corporate wardrobes. Can the Minister tell the Senate whether the Government has had discussions on this issue with the clothing industry? If so, can he outline the results of those discussions?

—That is a very useful question. Senator Sherry often asks pointed and useful questions. It has been a matter of some discussion on talkback programs and things of that kind. It is a difficult issue which the Government has managed to reach a satisfactory solution about after discussion and consultation with industry.

PARA.TAB: In putting together this year's Budget, the Government was concerned by evidence that the system of tax deductibility for non-compulsory corporate uniforms was being abused. The evidence suggested that in some cases some people were claiming a deduction on work clothing which was not essential for ordinary business wear. For example, I discovered one company recently which is providing tracksuits for its employees which they did not bring to work and claiming a deduction. There are other examples where non-compulsory wardrobes are provided for staff with the company logo behind the lapel with tax deductibility being claimed in respect of those.

That was a distortion which the Government set out to get rid of in relation to non-compulsory corporate wardrobes. Since then the Government has sat down with the industry to consider other ways of dealing with this matter and will now amend the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6), when it reaches the committee stage in the House of Representatives, to change the implementation of the Budget announcement on occupational clothing. The guidelines on eligibility of corporate wear for the concession will be tightened to prevent rorts of that kind to which I referred without undue adverse effects on legitimate businesses.

The Treasurer will set up strict guidelines in consultation with the industry on what uniforms or corporate wardrobes will qualify for the concession. The Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority will administer the guidelines. To allow the industry time to adjust, the implementation of this decision will be postponed by a further six months to July 1993. The Government has listened to industry and consulted with industry on this issue and has sat down with those affected in order to achieve a satisfactory resolution.

TALK.START.PARA: —What will this cost the Budget?

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Is it true that the head of the National Companies and Securities Commission, Mr Bosch, personally contacted the Reserve Bank in the seven days prior to the collapse of the Estate Mortgage unit trusts to express his concern about the fund and about the actions of the banks? —This question is probably technically out of order, but I still intend to answer it because it indicates the very real need for the radical reform in the companies and securities area that was undertaken by this Parliament and the Government. This is because, when the National Companies and Securities Commission existed, it was not answerable to the Federal Parliament through a responsible Minister. Responsibility was diffused through the Ministerial Council of Federal, State and Territory Ministers. That is why this Parliament had to take action to establish the Australian Securities Commission to make this regulatory regime answerable to this Parliament through a responsible Minister such as the Commonwealth Attorney-General.

PARA.TAB: So the short answer to Senator O'Chee's question is that the Federal Attorney-General of the time would not have had the sort of political responsibility to deal with Mr Bosch or to be aware of the activities of the NCSC in the answerable way which the honourable senator implied in his question. I will ask whether the successor organisation, the ASC, can find in its records any evidence of such a meeting that might be helpful to Senator O'Chee—and perhaps in departmental records. But the key point is that the Federal Attorney-General did not have responsibility for the operations and activities of the National Companies and Securities Commission, nor for its head, Mr Bosch. TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—In accordance with that resolution and order of the Senate relating to questions on notice, I ask the following Ministers for an explanation as to why the following questions I placed on notice on 20 August 1992 have still not been answered, more than 75 days later: to Senator Collins, question Nos 2170 and 2176; to Senator Cook, question No. 2165; and to Senator Tate, question No. 2159. TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) in response to a question without notice asked by me on 4 November 1992 relating to Estate Mortgage unit trusts.

SPEECH.PARA: Today I raised with Senator Tate a very important matter which related to the collapse of the Estate Mortgage unit trusts. At their peak, the Estate Mortgage unit trusts had something in the vicinity of $1.8 billion of assets under control, yet within the space of a very short period of time those assets were dissipated and many of the investors in Estate Mortgage unit trusts have lost nearly all of their life savings. A principal problem in this was the fact the National Companies and Securities Commission agreed to the amendment of the trust deeds of that trust at a time when it knew that the Estate Mortgage unit trusts had difficulty maintaining their solvency.

PARA.TAB: The consequence of that was that the assets of the trust were dissipated, ultimately to the loss of the investors but to the advantage of the banks. There has not been a clear explanation to this point in time as to what was the arrangement that was made, or what was the meeting, between the NCSC Chairman, Mr Henry Bosch, and the Reserve Bank of Australia. Nor has there been any explanation, despite my question to Senator Tate today, of what the Attorney-General knew at the time about what was going on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or the Treasurer.

—Or the Treasurer, as Senator Tambling quite rightly points out. Senator Tate tried to say that the NCSC was acting on its own, but there is very clear evidence that the Chairman of the National Companies and Securities Commission, Mr Henry Bosch, personally contacted the Reserve Bank. Whom did he speak to at the Reserve Bank? That is a question the answer to which we must know. What did he say to the Reserve Bank? We know that there were discussions over two days between the Reserve Bank of Australia and the National Companies and Securities Commission. If the Reserve Bank of Australia was fully cognisant of the problems faced by Estate Mortgage—and I understand that there are some 40 documents in the possession of the Reserve Bank that relate to this, only six of which I have received from them pursuant to my freedom of information request—we need to know what was done with the information.

PARA.TAB: It is totally unacceptable for Senator Tate merely to say to this chamber, `Look, the NCSC was acting on its own'. We all know that ultimately the NCSC froze the funds in Estate Mortgage. Arguably, it should have done it earlier; arguably, it should not have assisted with the dissipation of the assets. But what we also know is that some time after this the Federal Government took it upon itself to freeze redemptions in other property trusts in this nation.

It is not correct for Senator Tate to say that it was a matter solely up to the NCSC. He might be correct in saying that the NCSC may have been acting on its own. But this Government always had the power to step in and prevent the dissipation of the assets from those trusts. Both the then Treasurer, Mr Keating, and the Attorney-General, Mr Duffy, knew that these funds were insolvent or on the verge of insolvency. They knew that they could not meet redemptions. They knew that money was going through the funds in a sideways shuffle, which meant that the latest people to invest in the funds ended up losing out the most. Yet this Government, under the then Treasurer, Mr Keating, and under the current Attorney-General, sat there and dithered while the investors of Estate Mortgage burnt—and burnt to the tune of millions and millions of dollars.

The suffering that is faced in 52,000 households in this country as a result of the dithering of the Government that sits opposite is an appropriate subject for scrutiny and one which Senator Tate should come back and explain to this Senate tomorrow afternoon immediately after Question Time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Audit Report No. 3 1992-93 Efficiency Audit: Australian Customs Service—Management of the marine fleet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an extraordinary report from the Australian National Audit Office—extraordinary in its findings in that it is quite damning of massive incompetence in the Australian Customs Service. The report contains the findings and recommendations of an audit of the management of the Australian Customs Service marine fleet, which currently comprises 24 vessels and is an integral part of the control and enforcement activities of Customs. Briefly, the audit found that:

.the marine fleet was significantly underutilised in respect of the control, or secondary role of the fleet. This resulted in an overall reduction in the control and enforcement capability of the fleet

.due to the changing nature of the fleet and its underutilisation, the Collector Class fleet of 14 vessels should be rationalised or phased out completely; savings up to $0.9 million per annum could be achieved

.the management of the fleet required improvement. This could be achieved through the introduction of an enhanced management information system, better strategic and operational planning and improved monitoring of the operations of the fleet
.there were inconsistencies in the interpretation of Conditions of Service for the crew of the fleet and significant variations in the level of victualling allowances paid to marine crew
.existing conditions of service led to inefficient work practices. For example, rather than pay large overtime payments, crew were often stood-down or deemed to be on leave, and
.some marine officers had not received adequate Customs-specific training following the transfer of the training of marine officers from the Australian Marine College to TAFE Colleges.

Those concerns expressed about Customs are very serious. The details of the Auditor-General's report underline how absurd some of the practices have been and how ridiculous the management of this fleet of vessels is. This fleet currently consists of 24 vessels located in various ports around the Australian coastline. The estimated replacement cost of the fleet is about $12m.

PARA.TAB: The audit found that the level of usage of the fleet had decreased substantially over the five years from 1986-87 to 1990-91. This has meant that all classes of vessels were significantly under-utilised, resulting in a reduction in the control and enforcement capability of the fleet. The audit also cast doubt on whether expensive marine assets had been used in the most effective manner.

The Audit Office found no evidence to indicate that the fleet's primary role of responding to specific indicators of unlawful activity was not being performed, but no records are maintained which would confirm this. However, according to the Auditor-General, other secondary but nonetheless important roles, such as conducting routine patrols of designated risk areas, were not being performed fully.

One of the most extraordinary features of this under-utilisation of the fleet is that the 14 collector class vessels—that is, the majority of the vessels—were utilised for only 50 eight-hour shifts per year. Fifty eight-hour shifts, according to the Audit Office, translates into 50 days use in a calendar year. I have to correct the Audit Office; it does not mean that at all. It means that they were used on 50 days throughout the calendar year. It does not mean 50 days usage. In fact, the amount of usage is something like 400 hours out of the 8,760 hours in a year. In other words, these vessels were utilised for something like 5 per cent of the time. This is a classic waste of taxpayers' money.

The Auditor-General explains that the target rate for this class was originally set at 100 shifts a year, but that this target was reduced to 50 shifts at a regional managers meeting in April 1991. The Auditor-General says:

SPEECH.PARA: When compared with the total number of days crew are available and, in view of the capital and operating cost of these vessels, the ANAO considers this target to be too low.

Details of monthly usage are set out in this report. The Auditor-General points out that in one case, the Charles Kingston, a minister class vessel stationed in Geraldton, Western Australia, was utilised for only one shift of eight hours in the three months from 1 November to the end of January 1991. The replacement value of this vessel is currently $3m and its operating costs are approximately $400,000 per year, of which fixed costs including salaries, allowances, mooring and maintenance costs, represent a major proportion. So this major asset was used for one eight-hour shift in three months. During this period, the five marine officers allocated to the vessel were not deployed effectively in marine activities.

PARA.TAB: As I mentioned earlier, the audit indicated that that is not an isolated instance; that there has in fact been a significant decrease in fleet utilisation. The smaller collector class vessels have a replacement value of approximately $1.3m. As I indicated earlier, these vessels were significantly under-utilised. According to the report:

SPEECH.PARA: The vehicles required to tow these vessels are leased at a cost of approximately $16,000 each per year.
There are 14 vessels to be towed. What fascinates me is that the Audit Office revealed the following information about one of these vessels:

. . . the Neal located in Fremantle has not been deployed in the South West of Western Australia for some considerable time due to the absence of a vehicle which could legally tow the vessel. Consequently, it was being used for routine patrols along the Swan River and surrounds which are not regarded by Customs to be as vulnerable as the South West coast for the illegal importation of narcotics . . .
This might have given the Customs officers friendly tours of the Swan River but it was not doing much to block the illegal importation of narcotics. The report goes on:
. . . the Lockyer located in Newcastle was not utilised for many months because the trailer was not functioning. As a result, the vessel could not be moved.
This is plain, straightforward, uncomplicated incompetence.
An examination by the ANAO of the utilisation of these vessels since April 1991 found there had not been any marked increase in usage.

This is despite the fact that in April 1991, Customs decided to examine the need to rationalise the marine fleet and give the Collector class vessels in particular a 12-months trial. The Audit Office now says:

The overall utilisation of the Collector Class vessels is low and the vessel is not well suited to current Customs' requirements. From inquiries and observations made by the ANAO, it seems that the functions currently carried out by Collector Class vessels, such as yacht checks and river patrols, could be carried out effectively by small dinghies which are carried on Minister Class vessels, or by the ad hoc chartering of suitable vessels. The running costs of the Collector Class is in the vicinity of $900,000 per annum. The phasing out of this class could therefore yield substantial savings. Where smaller vessels are required such as in Sydney, the above savings would be at least partly offset by chartering or the retention of a smaller number of Collector Class vessels.

In brief, the Audit Office saw no evidence which supported the continued use of the existing fleet size of 14 vessels. Quite frankly, one wonders what is holding up Customs from implementing massive cost savings, rationalising this operation, and diverting the funds towards doing something that would effectively help the fight against the illegal importation of narcotics, which is what I understand it is supposed to be doing.

PARA.TAB: This kind of failure is inexcusable. It is extraordinary that it requires the Auditor-General to point out to the Customs Service what should be and is patently evident from simply taking a quick look at the utilisation rates and what is happening. This is one of those classic examples of inefficiency. I commend the Auditor-General for once again drawing to the attention of the Parliament the incompetence of a section of this Government.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: INCOME TAX (INTERNATIONAL AGREEMENTS) AMENDMENT BILL 1992
This Bill will provide legislative authority for the entry into force of comprehensive double taxation agreements between Australia and Indonesia, Australia and Vietnam and Australia and Spain.
The Bill will insert the texts of the agreements into the Income Tax (International Agreements) Act 1953 as schedules to that Act.

The agreement with Indonesia was signed on 22 April 1992; the agreement with Vietnam was signed on 13 April 1992 and that with Spain was signed on 24 March 1992. The agreements allocate taxing rights over all substantial forms of income flowing between Australia and those countries. Details of each agreement were announced and copies made publicly available at the time of signature.
The agreements generally accord with the other comprehensive taxation agreements concluded by Australia in recent years.

A feature of the agreement with Vietnam is that it provides for "tax sparing" credit relief to be extended by Australia for tax forgone by Vietnam under specified development incentives for the encouragement of foreign investment.

Where income derived by an Australian resident taxpayer has benefited from the development incentives to be nominated under the agreement, a tax credit will be allowed by Australia for the Vietnamese tax forgone under those incentive measures. By this means, the development incentives will retain their attractions for Australian firms and allow them to compete for business in Vietnam on favourable terms with investors from other countries.

Each of the respective agreements will enter into force when diplomatic notes are exchanged advising that the necessary constitutional processes to give the agreement the force of law in the respective countries have been completed. The enactment of this Bill will complete the processes required of Australia for those purposes.

The Government believes that the agreements will contribute positively to the strengthening of trade, investment, and wider relationships between Australia and the treaty partner countries. I am pleased to be able to say that Australia is the first country with which Vietnam has entered into a double taxation agreement.
It is not possible to accurately predict the eventual effect of the three agreements on the revenue, but it is not expected to be significant.
I present the explanatory memorandum and commend the Bill to the Senate.
OVERSEAS STUDENTS CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1992

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Overseas Students Charge Act 1979 to fix the amounts of the charges payable under the Act for the 1993 academic year. In accord with established practice, the Overseas Students Charge is adjusted annually in line with movements in the index of higher education charges. The amounts payable in 1993 are shown in the Bill. The charges are payable by overseas students enrolled in Australian education institutions under the subsidised program to which the Act relates.

PARA.TAB: I commend the Bill to the Senate.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: ABORIGINAL EDUCATION (SUPPLEMENTARY ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

The Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody found that the most significant factor contributing to the over-representation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in custody is their disadvantaged and unequal position in Australian society, socially, economically and culturally.

Running through many of the Royal Commission's recommendations is the proposition that eliminating these disadvantages requires an end to domination of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people by non-Aboriginals and the return to them of control over their own lives.

The social, economic and cultural factors which contribute to this situation lead to low self-esteem and reduced confidence. It is a national tragedy that Australia's indigenous people remain the country's most chronically disadvantaged group on every social indicator, including health, housing, education and employment.

The poor levels of educational achievement recorded in the cases examined by the Royal Commission is an apt reflection of the level of education participation by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people generally.
Of the 99 cases investigated by the Commission, 40 of those who died had not proceeded beyond primary school and only 2 had completed secondary schooling.

There is wide agreement in Australia, including across political parties and among church and community groups, that there is a need to raise the level of awareness of non-Aboriginal people about Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander history, cultures and contemporary issues.

For far too long the education system did not offer Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people "a place" and provided no recognition of the richness of Aboriginal culture and history, and the importance of contemporary issues as they affect Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

This blinkered approach must continue to change if Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are to find relevance within our education system and if we are to increase non-Aboriginal people's awareness of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander issues.

A number of recommendations made by the Royal Commission seek to achieve this balance. Specific recommendations proposed that the curricula of schools at all levels should reflect the fact that Australia has an Aboriginal history and Aboriginal viewpoints on social, cultural and historical matters, and that Aboriginal viewpoints, interests, perceptions and expectations are reflected in curricula, teaching and administration of schools.

The Royal Commission endorsed the joint Commonwealth/State agreement to the 21 goals of the national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Education Policy (AEP). These goals, developed by governments in consultation with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, aim to address the educational inequalities experienced by Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders. Strategies to achieve these goals are currently being implemented under the AEP.

In endorsing the AEP, the Royal Commission identified areas where more needed to be done, such as the provision of pre-school education, provision of education to prisoners, and importantly, expansion of Aboriginal studies and Aboriginal control of curriculum.

This Bill represents a continuation of the Commonwealth Government's commitment to addressing the inequality of education opportunities between Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and non-Aboriginal people. The Commonwealth remains committed to overcoming the educational disadvantages faced by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people which were highlighted by the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody.
In 1989 all State and Territory governments and the Commonwealth government agreed to a Joint Policy Statement underpinning the National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Education Policy (AEP).

The Policy Statement included a commitment by the Commonwealth to supplement its normal provisions of recurrent and capital funding for education in the States and Territories with a dedicated commitment of funds on a forward triennial basis for assisting the implementation of the National Policy through one consolidated Aboriginal Education Strategic Initiatives Program.

The Policy Statement also contains a commitment by State and Territory governments not to diminish funds allocated for Aboriginal education by them because of any additional funds provided by the Commonwealth.

Since the introduction of the AEP in 1990, the Commonwealth has provided $214m under the Aboriginal Education Strategic Initiatives Program (AESIP) for initiatives directed at improving educational outcomes for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people; in addition to other forms of direct assistance to individual and groups. I will table later this session a report on the implementation of the Policy in 1990 and 1991.
This Bill proposes a significant increase to $241m in funding; a 13 percent increase over the first AEP triennium.

The Minister has made it clear to education providers that the implementation of the Royal Commission's recommendations concerning education are the Commonwealth's first priority over the next triennium.

The second Commonwealth priority for the next triennium is the implementation of the national Aboriginal Languages and Literacy Strategy, the first component of which is the Aboriginal Language Education Strategy (ALES) which will commence in January 1993.
ALES will support strategies geared towards the teaching of Aboriginal languages in schools. These strategies include:
special "languages other than English programs" in Aboriginal languages for children attending Aboriginal schools;
bilingual and bi-cultural programs;
measures for Aboriginal languages curriculum development and materials production; and
the provision of Aboriginal bilingual language teaching and para-professional staffing resources.
Such activities will have a critical place in the maintenance of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cultures.

The second component is the Aboriginal Literacy Strategy, also to commence in January 1993. It will support special strategies to improve the English literacy of Aboriginal primary and secondary students, particularly students whose first language is not English. Here again the Minister sees an opportunity to break down barriers, reduce disadvantage, and create positive self-esteem.

Bilingual and bi-cultural education is essential if strong and weakening Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander languages are to be maintained. From an educational perspective it is vital that a balance be found between the maintenance of Aboriginal languages and the teaching of English literacy.

The acquisition of knowledge and skills to allow Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to live without disadvantage in the wider society on the one hand, and the retention of Aboriginal culture on the other will continue to be a challenging issue.
I want to turn now to the third priority of the Commonwealth for the next triennium, the National Reconciliation and Schooling Strategy.

The role of Aboriginal studies, both as a discrete area of study and as an integral part of all curriculum—from preschool education through formal schooling to post-schooling and higher education—is vital to provide a proper foundation for future relations between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians and in bridging the gap between home and school for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders.

Aboriginal studies will make a significant contribution towards the process of reconciliation. The negative attitudes towards Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people on a large range of issues need to change. These attitudes form the basis of negative myths, generally based on ignorance or misinformation which are the foundation of racism and prejudice. These myths are major obstacles in the development of harmonious cross-cultural relations and have had their foundation in the school age education received by most non-Aboriginal Australians. In a very real way, generations of non-Aboriginal Australians were educated to be prejudiced. Through the process of educational and societal change these issues can and will be addressed.

The process of including Aboriginal studies in the curriculum has created an opportunity for change. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander viewpoints on social, cultural and historical matters are providing much needed opportunities for non-Aboriginal people to redefine and increase the richness of their understanding of their society. It is also a strategy which will assist in maintaining the rich indigenous cultures of this nation and the identity of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.
The Minister believes Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander studies will lay one of the foundations for the development of Australian society in the 21st century.

It is encouraging to know that there has been some considerable advance made with the development and inclusion of Aboriginal studies in the curriculum of some tertiary institutions and education systems.

Last year the Minister announced elements of the Reconciliation and Schooling Strategy—a way of putting together some existing curriculum development work, and providing new elements and a new focus for this work. Work so far has included:
the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander studies curriculum project, contributing to the national collaborative curriculum exercise, and preparing a publication as a guide to Australian schools;
a review and survey of best practice in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander schooling, leading to a video and teaching notes;
the teacher inservice modular education system, designed to increase the quality of inservice training of teachers of Aboriginal studies and of Aboriginal students;
a comparable exercise for pre-service training of teachers;

the sister schools scheme, which I launched recently, to encourage contact between students of predominantly non-Aboriginal schools with students in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander schools. The reception to this scheme has been most encouraging, and I am confident that with further promotional activity at the beginning of the next school year, there will be a large number of schools participating in 1993;

the local history project, which involves a video and kit to encourage and help Aboriginal school communities to research and prepare local histories for use in the Aboriginal studies curriculum of their schools; and
initial steps to research and develop a strategy to improve education and training for Aboriginal prisoners and ex-offenders, amongst the most educationally disadvantaged in Australia.
As the third priority of the Commonwealth for the Second AEP triennium, the Minister is confident that this work will be advanced by education providers.

Definitely, much more needs to be done to ensure the continuation of efforts towards achieving our set goals. As the next AEP triennium approaches, the Minister is looking forward to hearing about different strategies to address the vital national issue of ensuring that Aboriginal students are just as well taught, well educated, highly motivated and successful as any other Australians.

The Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill 1992 provides for the continuation of Commonwealth funding of the Aboriginal Education Strategic Initiatives Program addressing the National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Education Policy for the years 1993-1995.

The purpose of the Bill is to appropriate funds to enable the Commonwealth to continue to enter into bilateral education agreements with State and Territory governments, non government school systems, Aboriginal education institutions and Aboriginal Education Consultative bodies for the provision of Aboriginal education initiatives consistent with the AEP.

The Government has allocated a total of $241 million as its commitment to the National Policy over the next 3 years 1993-1995. This amount includes $17.3 million in response to the recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody in relation to additional preschool places and additional Aboriginal education workers and an amount of $16.8 million has been included for Aboriginal Languages and literacy initiatives. The Bill provides for the appropriation of $76.9 million in 1993, $81.3 million in 1994 and $83.1 million in 1995.
This Bill underpins one of the continuing successful reforms of the Federal Labor Government. This Bill is about social justice and is about greater accountability in government expenditure.
It is a good news story for the Government and the nation, and warrants the backing of the whole Parliament.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator West, I present an addendum to the report from Estimates Committee E on proposed expenditure for the year ending 30 June 1993, which was tabled earlier today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for lunch at 12.45 p.m., we were considering the Appropriation Bills. I had made a number of points about this Government's Budget for 1992-93. In particular, I had commented that this was the fifth attempt in 18 months by this Government to try to fix the economic problems that it had created with the recession that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said we have to have. In the 1992-93 Budget the Government is yet again tinkering at the edges.

PARA.TAB: Before lunch I was focusing on a number of areas which I considered of importance in budgetary policy. I was comparing what a Liberal government would do under Fightback with what this Labor Government has done, particularly within the areas of employment and training. I was making the point that Donald Horne, one of the most respected commentators on Australian society, warned that this country would have to be prepared; that it could not depend on its luck; that in particular it could not depend on resources booms to come along and save it; that there would come a time when Australians would have to rely on their own merits; and that in particular we would have to get training and education programs under way.

Donald Horne warned that this would have to be done 10 years before the crunch point was reached. That crunch point has certainly been reached with the great recession that has been under way now for about 18 months. This Government has not done enough to help change the training systems that are needed to pull this country out of the mess that it is in. Horne warned about the day of reckoning. Over the last 10 years the Government has neglected the main area that he was warning us about—training, particularly technical training. It has neglected this area more than any other area in our whole education and training system.

In many ways, if it is not too late for us to be pulled out of this problem, it will be a very long time before that will happen. The Government has to make some very hard decisions in the area of vocational training. The Government has to set up training programs. But it has not created the circumstances under which people can find jobs when those training programs have finished. So we have two problems: not only do we have inadequate training programs but also we do not have jobs for young people when those training programs are finished.

Some months ago I had discussions with the migrant community in Wollongong, which is Australia's seventh largest city. They told me about the problems they were facing in the recession and of the help available to them. The only help the Government has provided is endless training programs that are not properly linked to jobs. They complete training, but the economy of Wollongong is in such a state of disaster that they are unable to find any work; they retrain, but still they are unable to find work; so they retrain again, and so it continues. The result is that Wollongong has the best educated dole queue in the world.

Putting people into innumerable training schemes does not solve the problem, it merely hides it, and it delays the inevitable. This Budget is not about job creation, it is about vote creation. Under Fightback, by contrast, the coalition will commit $945m over the next triennium to expand vocational education and training. The coalition will also encourage the commitment of additional private resources over and above those likely to be committed under the present Government's policies through substantial increases in the independence of schools, colleges of TAFE, private providers and universities to offer an expanded range of vocational education courses.

Levels of participation and attainment in training must, with these programs, be raised to best international standard. The Liberal and National parties will promote an open and flexible training market and facilitate better links between schools, training institutions and the workplace. In addition to the extra funding the coalition will provide, we are committed to establishing a framework for the assessment of key competencies for work force participation. We will support national competency-based training and a national system of training certification and we will support approved cross-accreditation between schooling, training and higher education. This vocational training initiative, in combination with the rest of the Fightback reform package, is the foundation for sustainable job growth within a dynamic and expanding economy. By contrast, the ALP Government's last Budget attempted to hide the unemployment problem and has not addressed the real issues.

Similarly, in other vital areas of economic reform the ALP Government has not had the guts to make the changes that are so desperately needed. For example, in the area of taxation reform, we recall that policy reforming joke known as the Tax Summit in 1985, where the Government wimped out yet again. The Prime Minister, then the Treasurer, a keen advocate of the GST, could not get his own way. On 13 June 1985, at a lunch in Adelaide, Mr Keating said:

SPEECH.PARA: Tax reform has been in the nation's too hard basket for many years.

Yet it is unquestionably the structure of the tax system, more than any other feature of public policy, which influences the efficiency of economic activity, and decisions to invest, to save and to work.

Only a week earlier, at the National Press Club, Mr Keating espoused the benefits of a broad based consumption tax, saying that it would allow a more rational indirect tax system to replace the anomaly ridden tax system. It is interesting to note that that is still in place, it is still pulling in $9 1/2 billion every year, and people do not even realise that the tax is there.

PARA.TAB: Back in 1985, Mr Keating said that his GST proposal would provide a major reduction in personal income tax, and he noted that it would generate tax from those who continued to evade or avoid income tax. In that same speech the current Prime Minister said in relation to a broad based consumption tax:

SPEECH.PARA: For too long the politically unpalatable decisions have been put off in this country because our politicians have not had the strength of purpose to tackle the hard issues.

This shows that not only did he not have the guts to follow through with taxation reform, but he is also now taking a very hypocritical position by opposing it. In addition, this ALP Government has not had the strength of character to introduce the labour market reforms that are obviously so necessary. Indeed, today we heard Senator Cook claim all the enterprise bargaining agreements that he had under his belt. He listed them one by one. I think Hansard will show that the enterprise bargaining agreements the Minister for Industrial Relations alluded to could be counted on the fingers of both hands.

PARA.TAB: The harsh reality is that the vast majority of workers in this country are still under a highly centralised and regulated system. Only a very small number of workers have got out from under the yoke of the IR club that runs industrial relations in this country. Senator Cook is starting to head in the right direction, but the progress is at a snail's pace. That pace has to accelerate very rapidly for this country to revive and to grow again.
