Union involvement in the agreements that have been made so far illustrates the problem. I refer in particular to the waterside workers agreements and the huge rip-off of taxpayers' money involved. I think it was Senator Cook again who claimed here how little trouble the Government had had with the waterfront reform program. He said that they had the agreements and that the manning levels had dropped. Why would the Government not get agreements, with the huge pay-offs being made to waterside workers? Why would the waterside workers complain? Why would they strike? The average redundancy payment is $100,000 per wharfie; I would not expect any strikes on that basis. That has actually cost the taxpayer $430m. These costs have been shared not only by the taxpayer but also by the shipping companies, and one of the effects of that is to stop the drop in the price of shipping in this country and in the shipping rates. Of course, the net effect is to keep shipping charges up and to keep Australia uncompetitive.

For 10 years in this country the ALP has had its hands on the levers of economic power to implement the necessary structural reforms, but it has run away from the tough decisions at every opportunity or been forced to back down by the trade union movement, which holds the whip hand over this Government, and this Budget is no exception.

What is the bottom line for all of this? What has this Labor Government and the policies of financial mismanagement it has pursued over the past 10 years created? It has created a situation where we are looking at leaving our children a lower standard of living than that which we have enjoyed, and that is a disgrace after 10 years of rule by any government. Labor policies have clearly failed, and a completely different approach to the key policy areas needs to be taken. This will start next year under Dr Hewson's visionary 20-point Fightback plan. The Fightback approach to this Budget will mean more jobs and fewer taxes. Under Fightback, the coalition will lift the burdens placed on individuals and businesses and it will get this country moving again.

We will reduce costs for business, we will create a more competitive environment, we will give back to individuals their freedom of choice, and we will give back to individuals the incentive to strive to achieve their potential. Fightback addresses those issues, and it is the coalition's Fightback budget that is really needed for the future of this country—not this Budget, which is the ALP Government's fifth pathetic attempt to get this country out of the great recession that our Prime Minister, Paul Keating, said we had to have.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1992-93 Budget, the first under the leadership of Paul Keating, is a Budget with an emphasis on jobs. Jobs provide the basis for security, quality of life and personal dignity. Jobs are not just about statistics. Employment figures do not simply show us how good or how poorly the economy is performing. Employment is about people—about men and women who want to provide a quality of life for their families, some of whom are unable to. This Government has a responsibility to provide for those without jobs, not just because increased employment is good for the economy and good for government revenue but because it creates the opportunity for a healthy and happy society.

PARA.TAB: One stark aspect of the recession is the increase in crimes of theft and domestic violence. People are hurting, but before any government can help its people, it has to care. This Government stands on its record—from Medicare to family assistance—as a government that sees the people of Australia as people and not as fodder for a discredited doctrinaire economic approach.

In line with this, the Government reaffirms its commitment to a goal of full employment. The coalition has already indicated that it wants to drop the Government's commitment to full employment by removing this objective from the charter of the Reserve Bank. Dr Hewson may bleat that he still believes in full employment, but one does not leave the barn door open and at the same time insist that one does not want the horse to bolt.

Without that commitment or objective, no government can expect people to believe it is serious about reducing the level of unemployment. It is effective work that creates wealth and value. Speculative frenzies such as the recent currency crisis in Europe, which saw billions of dollars disappear overnight, show how vulnerable we are all to economic terrorists who have no allegiance to any country or any government. This Government has put its faith in the constructive and effective labour of its people. We have not succeeded as well as we would like, but as the Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, said, `Regret, without action, has a hollow ring to it'. That is why this Government has a plan of action—a package aimed at providing a stimulus for job growth in this country.

This package involves a number of measures, including a new local capital works program covering regions hardest hit by unemployment. This will involve spending $345m in the next two years, of which Queensland will receive $48m. The package will also include more money for roads and schools; $188m for urban development and public housing; and big increases in the Jobstart and Jobskills programs. Of course, job growth cannot rely solely on a strong public works program; it also relies on a number of indirect measures which allow Australian industries to also grow and develop and in turn provide more job opportunities for Australians.

As Chairman of the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs, I have a strong commitment to rural industries and regional Australia. I am pleased, as will be my fellow members of the Rural and Regional Affairs Committee, to see a number of initiatives in this Budget which greatly assist farmers and others. The measures include an increase of $157m to $166m in Commonwealth funding for the rural adjustment scheme. This includes restructuring of the rural adjustment scheme with the cooperation of the State governments.

Other measures include the establishment of a national drought policy, which the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Simon Crean, announced shortly after the Budget details were released. They also provide for an additional $31m for the debt reconstruction with interest subsidy scheme; $6m for the continuation of the crop planting scheme, as announced in the One Nation package; an additional $3m for the primary industries and marketing skills program and for improved access to education, training and services in rural areas; an additional $1.4m for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities for the development of rural resources; $8m for a rural incentives program to encourage general practitioners to relocate to rural areas; and last, but by no means least, a 25 per cent increase in the base component of the income tax remote area zone rebate, effective from 1 January 1993, which will benefit some 44,000 people living in remote regions of Australia.

As Chairman of the Rural and Regional Affairs Standing Committee, I am especially pleased and proud to see the release of a national drought policy. People on both sides of politics have certainly looked for that for some time. People in the industry themselves, through the use of examination of the current position and recommendations of a drought policy review committee, have also suggested this.

The Rural and Regional Affairs Standing Committee released its final report on a national drought policy, appropriate government responses to the recommendations of the drought policy review task force were made in July this year, and a number of recommendations have been addressed in this Budget. The national drought policy is an agreement between the Commonwealth and the States. It is based on principles of sustainable development, risk management, productivity growth and structural adjustment in the farm sector.

Under this policy drought is no longer seen as a national disaster—something sudden, unexpected and out of the ordinary—but as one of the risks that farmers will normally contend with during their working lives. Drought will affect a farm's efficiency and profitability, as will man-made problems such as falling world commodity prices and general changes in consumer demand or consumer preferences.

However, this does not mean that there will not be droughts for which farmers cannot plan and prepare. I believe that any government should have a responsibility to assist in those circumstances beyond the current and continuing policy of the Government in relation to assisting the rural area. Also, the fact that it is no longer seen in the disaster area does not mean that it should not also attract assistance of a similar sort.

The role of a national drought policy is to reduce the effect of drought as one of the several sources of uncertainty affecting farm businesses in Australia. The specific objectives of the national drought policy are to encourage primary producers and other sections of rural Australia to adopt self-reliant approaches to managing for climatic variability; and to maintain and protect Australia's agricultural environmental resource base during periods of extreme climatic stress. I am pleased to have had this aspect brought to my notice. Many farmers are very enlightened in this regard and clearly see their land as something to be husbanded, something that they will be on for the rest of their lives and something to leave to their families and the nation. This is to be contrasted with the attitude of some people who in the past have been very short-sighted and who have abused the land rather than farmed it skilfully and thoughtfully.

Another objective of the national drought policy is to ensure early recovery of agricultural and rural industries consistent with long term sustainable levels. Under the national drought policy farmers will have to assume greater responsibility for managing the risks arising from drought conditions. This principle is an important one. Farmers are a fiercely independent group who, above all, want to maintain control of their own farms and businesses and not have to come to government for handouts and other financial assistance time and time again.

If we, as the Government, can provide a range of measures that allow the farmer maximum control of his or her farm, which often has been worked by the same family for many years, we will achieve something that no amount of money can buy. I refer to dignity and self-respect, a feeling of worth and accomplishment.

Recession and drought bring more than economic hardship to rural communities because farmers take so much pride and honour in their work and their contribution to the Australian economy and society. Their failure hurts them very deeply. We have seen many people forced off their farms who see themselves as failures. But drought is not their fault, recession is not their fault and world trade subsidies are not their fault either. The goal of the national drought policy is to show farmers and other primary producers how to beat the odds and make what is one of the world's most efficient and productive industries viable in the long term through any sort of adversity.

The national drought policy consists of a number of components which provide a full package of assistance to primary producers. They include a new rural adjustment scheme based on sustainable long term profitability and provide assistance in times of exceptional downturn, including not only drought but also falling commodity prices, disease outbreaks and other situations beyond the farmers' control. They also include an improved income equalisation deposits scheme, including a farm management bond. This scheme will assist farmers to build financial reserves which will be available to them during the period of drought or other downturn in income. It will provide $700,000 per year for three years for research and development into drought preparedness, including climate prediction and pest and weed control; $11.5m in the next four years for education and training to assist farmers in property management planning, risk assessment, drought management and for the implementation of associated land care measures. One and a half million dollars will be spent to ensure that farmers are aware of the national drought policy and its advantages, including how to prepare for and manage during drought.

Also under legislation to be administered by the Department of Social Security, the Commonwealth will provide farm household support for farmers who are in extreme financial hardship. Drought relief in the form of interest subsidies or farm household support meet the immediate needs of rural producers, but other measures—such as a renewed commitment to research and development on drought preparedness—should not be underestimated for the potential contribution they can make to improving the long term profitability of the farming sector.

The Commonwealth will develop an integrated national grant research and development program in collaboration with the States and rural research and development corporations. Over $2m will be contributed by the Commonwealth in the next three years with additional funding provided by private companies through collaborative research agreements. Coordinated drought research is essential, and it is hoped that this research will cover a wide range of issues including climate predictions; technical, biological and financial information; control strategies for weeds and pests; the needs of rural communities and farm families in times of stress; and on-farm and off-farm investment strategies for farmers.

The national drought policy will succeed with the understanding and cooperation of the rural community it is designed to help. To ensure the best results, the Government will complement its ongoing education and training programs with a new awareness campaign aimed at farmers, farm organisations, associated industry groups, accountants, advisers, bankers and other financial institutions, Landcare groups and others. This cooperative approach is capable of achieving the best results.
I now turn to industrial relations. In the program performance statements for the Industrial Relations portfolio the following comment is made in regard to subprogram 1.1:

SPEECH.PARA: The sub-program will present to the AIRC review of the operation of the October 1991 National Wage Case decision the Commonwealth's views on the implications of the legislative amendments for the AIRC's wage fixing principles. This will involve a shift from the approach of setting detailed and prescriptive central wage fixing principles to one of facilitating workplace negotiations within broad guidelines, while retaining an important role for the AIRC in the protection of minimum standards and the resolution of industrial disputes.
The sub-program will play an enhanced role in ensuring that social justice considerations are accepted as a key element in industrial relations.

We heard a lot from the Opposition about the idea of freeing up the labour market absolutely, deregulating it and allowing for and encouraging individual negotiations between employer and employee. This, of course, creates a totally uneven and unfair negotiating situation with the power lying totally with the employer because of his resources, experience and capacity to call on other people with skills in that area. We, as a government, suggest that we should continue to have strong trade unions which negotiate on behalf of workers.

PARA.TAB: As far as our progress in the area of negotiated enterprise agreements is concerned, it is true that we have not gone as quickly as we would have liked. There are not masses of such agreements. But there are now many, particularly in the metal industry award, and the number is growing quickly. As many people know, sometimes things begin slowly but pick up quickly with acceleration.

I would like to mention two particular situations which show successful achievement. We are normally told by people in the Opposition about all the failures. I have in front of me the Metal Worker of October 1992, which is the journal of the Metals and Engineering Workers Union. It states:
Ford Motor Company's Geelong casting plant has won an order to export $30 million worth of engine blocks to Mazda in Japan.
The job will mean an increase in the work force at the plant of about 50 in the short-term, with the potential for more orders and a significant increase in employment in recession-ravaged Geelong.

SPEECH.PARA: Showing that there is a clear understanding in the trade unions, the article went on to say:

PARA.TAB: MEWU convenor at the casting plant, Wayne Moore, said that the quality of the engine blocks shipped to Mazda would determine whether the contract was increased.

SPEECH.PARA: The union knows how important quality is. It is aware of it and it is playing a role. The article reported the comments of Wayne Moore in the following terms:

PARA.TAB: "The contract is for 72,000 engine blocks over four years, but the plant's capacity is for up to 120,000 blocks," Moore said. "We are aiming for Q1 quality rating which would rank us as a preferred supplier. . . Moore said the Geelong plant had already improved its quality in other areas, particularly the plastics section where wastage was now down to almost zero, but he said quality control was a constant process.

SPEECH.PARA: This shows a clear understanding that the workers on the job are aware of the importance of quality control as well as the matter of productivity levels.

PARA.TAB: Mr Kim Elliott, who is a Victorian organiser for the Metals and Engineering Workers Union, said that experience with the Japanese had shown that while ever they were getting the quality they required they would support Australian companies and continue to order. The article further states:

Wayne Moore, MEWU convenor and Tony Anderson, senior shop steward at the plant for the VBEF were on the steering committee that looked at the best ways of improving quality and productivity to enable the company to make a competitive bid.
Both played a big role in changing work organisation at the plant, including the formation of "natural work groups" to operate as teams.
"The way things are done at the plant is changing rapidly," Moore said. "People on the shop floor now have a much greater say in the way things are done.
"There is more input, after all no one knows better than the workers how the plant runs.
"We have had important input into the installation of the four-cylinder line and its layout.

SPEECH.PARA: One might say that that is the trade union people saying how well they are going and maybe telling a few fibs about the fact that they are conscious of quality and the level of productivity. But the article continues:

PARA.TAB: Ford President, Jac Nasser said the employees should be proud of the progress they were making in work place change which was making the company competitive in world markets.

"In the casting plant the employees, unions and management have worked together to reduce costs and improve quality over the past year, thus playing a key role in the success of the Mazda contract", he said.
"The commitment of our employees to continuous product improvement augurs well for the further expansion of Ford's export program.

SPEECH.PARA: Very clearly the position is that progress is being made, not by standing over people, not by legislating and saying that they have to do things, but by open discussion between management and labour indicating what needs to be done in the mutual interest.

PARA.TAB: Another article relates to a job which was carried out on the aluminium smelter in Tomago near Newcastle. A construction manager, Don Colman, made this comment:

"It was a fine job done by fine people—on time and on budget," Colman said after some of Transfield's employees from the Seven Hills plant in Sydney inspected the results of their work on the Tomago production line last month.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, this is the concept of saying to people, `Come back when it is working; see what you have contributed'. This gives them a realisation of their part of the process. The article further states:

PARA.TAB: Colman, originally from England, has overseen the installation of pots manufactured by Korean and Finnish companies at two smelters in Canada in recent years and said that Transfield Pots lost nothing by comparison.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, this refutes all the accusations by the Opposition that our people are inferior. It went on to say:

PARA.TAB: "They matched that quality in every way," Colman said.

In fact, Transfield had introduced an innovation which had improved on the construction pots. . . Colman said the pots had "arrived like clockwork, two a day, and they even exceeded that sometimes.". . . "We had a good site agreement here and a good safety agreement, both of which worked extremely well," Colman said.
"We have not had a dispute worth talking about—the unions kept the industrial relations away from the safety issues, and vice versa.
"You have good industrial relations here, it is a good place to build.

SPEECH.PARA: They are not airy-fairy ideas. That is a description of what actually happened in those particular areas of work. We have seen a lot of documentation put forward by the Opposition, particularly the Jobsback program, about the need to free up the right of individual workers to negotiate with employers. But the fact is that, no matter how well an employer and a labour union or employees in a workshop may get on, there is always a clear difference of interest between those two parties. If they both contribute and create wealth in their particular enterprise, each of them could well honestly believe that their share of the wealth should be larger. There is, therefore, a position of negotiation. It can be one where somebody wants a greater share of the same cake or it can be one where they cooperate and create a bigger cake with the share of each then in totality being greater; so there is a mutual benefit.

PARA.TAB: But no matter what happens there is that clear difference of interest between labour and capital. Anybody who suggests otherwise shows that he or she is ignorant, stupid or absolutely dishonest. So there will always be a need for trade unions that are run democratically—that operate from the bottom up, with the members indicating what they want to be done—and that have good leadership which thinks laterally and puts forward new ideas and makes suggestions as to the direction in which the organisation should go, and which has an appreciation of the interests of the nation, or society, while at the same time realising that its first commitment is to its members. That does not mean for one moment that the interests of the members of that organisation do not and cannot coincide with the public interest.

I believe the Budget is a good one. I realise that everyone will not be happy with the amount of expenditure in every area, but that is not possible if you have limited capacity. To those who suggest that the economy should grow at a particular rate, given that this Government, as suggested by the Opposition, is saying that we have to continue to seek quality, delivery, price and efficiency—jobs are being destroyed every day in their thousands in pursuit of that—although I do not suggest we move away from that, we need to have a government which cares about the people. That mass of wealth that we create must be evenly and fairly distributed throughout the community. I believe this Budget goes to that question and succeeds in that regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Appropriation Bills that we have before us this afternoon define the expenditure for the Federal Government for the next 12 months. In a sense, they are habitual Bills; they come up every year after the Federal Budget.

PARA.TAB: Unlike the previous speaker, I do not agree it is a good Budget. I am astonished that the Government can spend so much money it does not have, pat itself on the back and say it is a good Budget. These are really extraordinary times. The Australian economy is in terrible condition. We have low commodity prices for our exports in primary products; we have record bankruptcies; we have lack of profitability in industry; we have record crime and social instability within the country to a degree that none of us have ever seen before in our lifetimes; and on top of it all we have record unemployment figures. The Australian community, in my lifetime, has never been in a worse condition; yet we have this sort of Budget put before us to cope with what I believe are quite exceptional circumstances requiring urgent redress. As a nation, we have an acute balance of payments problem which has all the appearance of being accepted by the Government as something that is permanent and immutable.

We have record overseas debt. Within the 10 years of this Government, we have seen the debt position of Australia go from $30 billion to somewhere in excess of $150,000m. Added to that, we now have a collapsing economy where in the last few months the Australian dollar has decreased about 9.6 per cent against the US dollar, which of course has had a bad run itself. Every cent we take off the dollar makes that $150,000m we owe harder to pay because the currency is debased. We have to pay back that debt, and before we pay it back we have to pay interest on it. The sad thing is that nothing in the Bills that are before us this afternoon produces any circumstances that will change the affairs of the state of Australia at the present time. I think that is an enormous price for the Australian people to pay for this Government.

The Government has said, `We cannot fix it; we are just going to keep on doing the same thing as we have done for the last 10 years', completely oblivious of the fact that what the Government has done for the last 10 years has been the cause of the problem. We need to change the way we do things in this country and we need to change them quickly; but change is impossible to the monolithic Labor Government. What we need is a government that provides leadership for the nation and a leadership which unifies this country of Australia towards national goals, common goals, that all people can believe in and work for.

The leadership ought to inspire people to make sacrifices and work hard so that as a nation and as a community we derive the benefit from those sacrifices and the efforts we have now to make to an extraordinary degree to recover from the incompetence that has been foisted upon us. That requires the Government to develop different community attitudes; to develop a new vision in the community; to get some self-discipline, a willingness to work hard and to save; and to pursue quality in manufacturing the way the previous speaker was talking about so that Australian industry produces goods that the Australian community can support by buying them for their quality.

Let us get back to rising standards of living and get away from the dreadful poverty that now faces so many sections of the Australian community. What I am asking for really is a return to those values that made Australia great in previous times: the willingness to work hard; the ability to hold on to the rewards from that hard work; some incentive for effort; and the ability to save and look ahead, not live for the moment or live for the next Commonwealth cheque which has been the legacy of the Labor administration and the Labor philosophy. Sadly, nothing in the Bills that are before us this afternoon will change the circumstances of Australia one iota.

I do not wish to take very long this afternoon because it is the wish that we get through the second reading stage of the Appropriation Bills by 7.30 tonight. I just want to make a couple of points in the Appropriation Bills about the Defence Department. Before I do that, I would like to pay tribute to the retiring Chief of the Air Staff, Air Marshal Funnell, who is the latest of a line of quite outstanding officers who have been Chief of the Air Staff in my time in this Parliament—Air Marshal McNamara, Air Marshal David Evans and Air Marshal Jake Newham. I wish the retiring CAS, Air Marshal Funnell, well in his retirement. I am confident he will make a significant contribution to Australian public life in the many years he has left to him in his retirement. I do not wish to comment on his career and his achievements except to draw attention to what I regard as one of his best achievements, and that is the setting up of the Air Power Studies Centre in the RAAF.

A successful armed service requires many attributes, including a well-developed sense of discipline and the ability to cope with great adversity and danger so that overwhelming physical force can be applied to achieve victory. I have a great and unbounded admiration, as everyone in this chamber would know, for the three services that comprise the Australian Defence Force. I have also had a lifelong concern about the academic component of the Australian Defence Force which I do not think has been as strong as it could have been, and certainly it is not as strong as it needs to be for the years ahead.

What I am talking about here is a little difficult to define. I am certainly not saying that the educational qualifications of the Australian officer corps in all three services are not first class; they are first class, they are world class. The professional training we give our officers is excellent. I am certainly not saying that there are no intelligent people in the defence forces. There have been and are some very highly intelligent people. What I am trying to express is a need for more scholarship in military affairs. Australia, for example, has never produced a Captain Liddell Hart who had such a seminal influence on warfare not only for the British defence forces but also for armies around the world in the period between the First and Second World War; or a character such as Count von Clausewitz of the German forces in the last century.

It is essential that this academic component is developed within the Australian armed services. It is understandable, in a way, that all three services, which are concerned with fighting, do not think terribly much about what has to be done in an abstract or alternative way. The lessons that the defence forces apply in their training are lessons that have been bought at the ultimate price in the cost of human lives, and they are quite naturally very reluctant to accept deviation from that. But we are in very different circumstances to those in which we have been for the rest of this century.

We are all conditioned to think in terms of global war. We had World War I and we had World War II, and in both cases there tended to be a major polarisation of the world into two camps. After 1945, the end of the Second World War, up to about two years ago, we had the Cold War which again polarised the world into two camps—the Western liberal democracies and the Soviet Union.

I would argue that those days are gone—they are gone for the rest of our lives. Future military conflicts will not be on a global scale but on a regional scale. While it is important that Australia maintains its alliances—namely, ANZUS and the Five Power Defence Agreement, which is becoming increasingly important as the countries with which we are allied grow and develop in South East Asia—we do have to look to the situation where we will be involved, regrettably, in military operations on our own in a regional context. Despite our best diplomatic efforts, we know from history that this will happen. I hope sincerely that those incidents are few and far between and that we can avoid them, but our defence planning must be based on the proposition that, henceforth, we will really have to look after our own affairs. I would also argue that, unlike the First World War and the Second World War, there will not be a formal declaration of war; things will probably erupt with little or no warning. Unlike the Second World War, which was fought to a point of unconditional surrender by the Allies against the Axis powers, future conflicts will have quite limited objectives. They may be territorial, they might be trade, but they will be quite finite in their objectives.

Future military conflicts will be regional; they will be small; they will come with little warning; they will be intense, in time and possibly space; and they will be finite. That means that we have to have a higher degree of readiness, a higher sustainability and a high degree of professionalism in the defence forces. All of these factors have to be developed in an environment where there is no clear threat. Therefore, it is difficult to focus public attention and public resources into developing a suitable defence force. We need a balanced, flexible defence force equipped with contemporary military skills with a judicious blend of both high and low technologies. The government of the day needs to have a range of options to respond to any situation. Of course, we do not currently have any of these things in the Australian Defence Force. No-one in this Parliament is thinking or talking about the need to move in that direction.

In relation to the academic component of defence, I would argue that there is now a very real need to have people who are trained in the profession of arms thinking about the future directions that the defence forces of Australia should take. Certainly, I do not want to see the Australian Defence Force composed of or run by obscure academic thinkers. But in the future we are going to be critically dependent on the intellectual input that we put into our defence forces. They are going to be small and we are going to be dependent on them when the time comes.

Air Marshall Funnell has made an important contribution to Australia's defence by setting up the Air Power Studies Centre. Similar bodies have been set up subsequently in the Army and the Navy. The Air Force has been very careful in selecting the personnel to go into that body. It has some very able people; some very able thinkers. It may be argued that it is a little easier for this to be done in the Air Force than in the other two services because the Air Force, by its very nature, is a more highly developed service technically. There is probably more diversity of intellectual effort in the Air Force than in the other two services—I say that carefully and with the greatest respect to the other two services.

We ought to have these academic cells within all three services. As someone who has been involved in academia, I issue a caveat to that. Senior personnel in the Australian defence forces have to recognise that these bodies must have academic freedom; they cannot be controlled with respect to their output. The personnel who are selected to serve in these units should not only be officers of great professional experience and competence but also they should have first class intellectual capabilities and be capable of original intellectual thought.

When a body like this is set up, academic freedom has to be granted. One cannot guide or direct what the output of that thinking should be. One can certainly dictate the subject in which the thinking is done, but one cannot attempt to dictate the output. One just has to stand back and take what comes out. To me that has been the great legacy of Air Marshall Funnell. One point that I should have mentioned earlier is that the creation of these cells is not of benefit solely to the Air Force, the Army or the Navy on a single service basis. The creation of these cells within all three services does a great deal to develop a common bond. It helps form the three services into a composite Australian defence force for use by the nation.

I will briefly touch on the mine warfare element that appeared in the Defence estimates. The history of mine warfare in Australia in the last 20 years has not been one of achievement; it has not been a history in which we can take much pride. The Navy set out to address the shortages in mine warfare with the minehunter inshore program. Unlike most people, I give the Navy unbounded praise for what it did there. It set out to seek an innovative solution to what was potentially a very expensive problem. It embarked on the design of a new type of platform—a catamaran hull—for operations in the inshore areas of Australia and equipped it with a certain sonar.

Full marks to the Navy for having the originality and the courage to back its ideas. But it did the wrong thing when it found that this was not working. No-one had the courage to say out loud, `Hey, we have reached a dead end here; we need to go back and try something else'. The program dragged on and on for years and years. The true figure of expenditure for the minehunter inshore program probably will not ever be known, but it is well in excess of $120m. I think Navy or Defence admit to an expenditure of about $85m or $90m, and it is certainly a great deal more than that.

Nevertheless, we still have this requirement for minehunters. The program has now been renamed the minehunter coastal program and the Navy is going to go for a larger ship. In the last 12 months the Department of Defence sent a team around the world to look at a number of selected designs. My objection to that is that there is now a degree of inflexibility in Navy's thinking, in so far as the selection team will consider only ships that have been built for other navies around the world.

We need a minehunter that we can buy as cheaply as possible, provided it will do the job that we need it to do. Basically, we need a hull that is going to survive for 30 years with minimal maintenance, and we need a good sonar. We certainly need characteristics like the magnetic and acoustic signatures to be minimal so that mines are not detonated. We certainly need good shock resistance so that mines that are detonated accidentally do not kill the crew or destroy the hull. Those are the requirements. We certainly do not need a gold-plated design for a ship which cannot be used for any other purpose but hunting mines.

Most of the ships that the Navy has can be used for a number of functions. They have patrol functions and even logistic functions. They can carry people or freight in an emergency. A minehunter really cannot do anything else but hunt mines, so it is going to spend its 30 years tied up at the wharf when it is not on exercises. If we look at recent history around the world, we find that most of these minehunter programs have been extremely expensive. The USN embarked on a program which saw a proposed design move from about 450 tonnes up to 900 tonnes at huge cost. I think the program still has not been completed.

At the end of the day there is no difference whether the RAN buys a gold-plated minehunter of its own or whether it buys a gold-plated minehunter that was designed and built for some other navy. We do not want to be involved in excessive cost. The figures that are officially put forward for this program for six ships are around $600m to $800m. Unofficially in the defence community in the city of Canberra, the figure that is commonly cited is $1 billion for those six minehunters. I think the $600m figure is way out of line. I think we could be looking at a cost that is about half the projected figure of $600m for those six minehunters, provided Defence was prepared to use a bit of initiative and originality in the design.

I do not see why, for example, we could not use a wooden hull. There are many successful wooden hull designs around that are in that 350- to 400-tonne category. Wood does survive. It lasts very well. We would certainly have to design to provide a low magnetic and acoustic signature and shock resistance, but there is nothing difficult about that. Those technologies are known. I might comment on the Collins submarines. The original Swedish design that we accepted as the basis for building the Collins submarines which are at present under construction in South Australia was very deficient in some areas, particularly on the acoustic and magnetic signature and all those things that I am talking about. Yet the RAN was able to build that technology into the design. I am quite confident that when those submarines are built they will be world leaders with respect to those attributes.

All I am saying is that that technology can be applied and there is no big deal in it. I would like to see the inflexibility with respect to built designs waived and the possibility of some locally designed minehunter coastal developed. There is not only a market within Australia for this; there is also a big regional market if we can come up with something that would cost in the order of $60m to $70m a ship, which I think is quite an attainable figure.

The second thing I want to talk about is the recent announcement by the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) of the acquisition of some more F111s for the RAAF. I support the Government very much on this. I think it is one of the most enlightened moves it has made in its time in government in relation to defence. I have been quite surprised at the protest movement about it, both within Australia and outside Australia. The protest within Australia is basically from people who do not understand what they are saying, but to have protest from outside Australia is a different matter again. The defence of Australia and what we do is primarily a matter for the Australian Government and the Australian people. We do not have to ask approval from any other country before we develop any capabilities in the defence direction.

Of course, it is common sense that one does not upset one's neighbours by acquiring new capabilities and all the rest of it without telling them in advance. But the acquisition of a few more F111s in no way alters the basic capabilities of the Australian Defence Force. I find it surprising that there should be comment from overseas about the acquisition of these aircraft. After all, Australia never protested when the Indonesians announced a few months ago that they were going to buy 14 or 24 more war ships, including a number of amphibious ships, which, if Australia were hypersensitive, it could have objected to. But there was not a word about it here. It is recognised as a proper decision for the Indonesian Government to make. The same standards ought to be applied to the Australian purchase of the F111s.

The F111 is a very useful component of the Australian defence forces. It provides an enormous deterrent capability. Even though the design goes back to the early 1960s, it is still a high performance aircraft. It is probably the fastest aircraft at low level in existence today. It is very hard to stop. When it is equipped with precision target acquisition equipment such as PAVETACK it is capable of using the range of precision munitions that we saw used in the Gulf. There are a number of applications that come from that technology that are useable in a passive surveillance role which are of great importance to the Australian Defence Force.

The real reason why the F111s were bought was that they became available at a relatively low cost. I know that the ADF has been aware of this for a long while, for a matter of years. I know that the Air Force has been looking at this. I have known for a long while that these aircraft would become available as they became surplus to the United States Air Force requirements. Basically, we have bought them for spare parts. It could be true that they could be used straightaway, but they could only be used with iron bombs and they could only be used in a relatively benign environment.

What we have at present is a restricted number of aircraft. We only had two squadrons. We have lost a number of them through attrition on training accidents. We will reach a point, if nothing is done, within the next few years, even with the best and most careful handling, where we will lose one or two more. Once the fleet size gets down to about 16 or 17 aircraft, then they become not worth while maintaining, given the great maintenance support that is required for them. Then we lose them from their inventory. Since the aircraft are not being made any more, the opportunity to acquire them for spares has to be taken when the opportunity presents. The Government has to be congratulated for its wisdom and flexibility in the way it moved to acquire those aircraft when the opportunity arose.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating three financial Bills. Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and Appropriation Bill (No. 2) are the core of this year's Budget, the 1992 Commonwealth Budget. We are also debating the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill. The first Bill appropriates over $14,000m from the Consolidated Revenue Fund for the ordinary services of the Government, the recurrent services. Appropriation Bill (No. 2) provides funds basically for public works. The Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill appropriates some $62m for the running of Parliament. Together they constitute this year's Federal Budget.

PARA.TAB: In economic terms, the Budget sets out to boost economic activity in order to achieve significant reductions in unemployment. The Budget aims to get unemployment down to 10 per cent within a year and to create some 800,000 new jobs in Australia over the next four years. Labor is going to spend some $1.2 billion creating jobs and opportunities right now through local works projects. The program is designed to kick-start local economies, give Australians jobs and create facilities for local communities in areas hardest hit by unemployment.

The Budget provides more jobs in areas of high unemployment by allocating some $188m on housing and development projects, some $184m on building and upgrading schools, universities and science research facilities and $60m to fix dangerous black spots on local roads in order to cut road accidents. In addition, there is a very important allocation of $1.1 billion to create some 434,000 places in labour market programs, also to help unemployed Australians. Overall, these measures will help give an immediate boost to economic activity and help alleviate hardship in the community.

This afternoon, in speaking on the Budget, I want to talk particularly about the impact of alternative policies in Australia on the Australian tourism industry, a very important industry and one that is now contributing significantly and largely to Australia's balance of payments in a very positive way and creating many jobs in the Australian community. It is an industry with an enormous potential for growth and one that has grown significantly over the last decade.

I suspect that Liberal Party and National Party backbenchers opposite have been railroaded by the Liberal Party hierarchy over the impact of the goods and services tax on our vital tourism industry. I believe that must have happened, otherwise they would never have accepted a policy which would jeopardise an industry that is projected to create an additional 200,000 jobs over the rest of this decade. Those additional jobs in tourism are projected over the course of this decade with current policies in place and with no change in policy settings. But the Opposition is proposing a policy that would damage that industry enormously; it would hold back that industry's job growth and reduce its potential. Under the 15 per cent goods and services tax proposed by the Liberals, the employment prospects for tourism would be severely damaged. Tourism is one of Australia's fastest growing industries and now our single largest export earner. The Opposition continually preaches about the virtues of a goods and services tax and insists that it would not tax exports, but it would tax our No. 1 single export earner, tourism.

The Opposition's proposed 15 per cent GST is a direct threat to Australian export earnings because the reality is that under a Hewson government the price of Australian tour packages sold overseas would rise by between 10 and 12 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the 30 per cent tax cut?

—I was saying that it is a tax on a vital industry, and the Opposition comes in right on cue. Australia is a long haul destination; we are a long way from the source countries for Australian tourism. Tourism to Australia is very price sensitive.
—The air fares will be GST-free, you dope.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crowley)—Order! Let us have some civility, Senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —And here we have an Opposition proposing a 15 per cent goods and services tax on a very price sensitive industry. We know what representatives of the tourism industry have been saying about Dr Hewson and the Liberals; I know the words they have been using. Senator Short described me as a dope. I know what industry has been saying about the tourism policies of Dr Hewson, Senator Short and others.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crowley)—Order! I ask honourable senators to allow Senator Maguire to speak.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reality is that a goods and services tax must inevitably raise overseas the brochure prices for Australian holidays. A 15 per cent goods and services tax will lift the cost of the holidays in Australia compared with the cost of holidays in other countries; that is undeniable. Potential visitors to this country, with the advent of a GST, would choose to go elsewhere.

PARA.TAB: The Liberal Party believes in market forces. I have been here for nine years listening to those opposite talk about the virtues of market forces, which I understand to be that prices move in a certain direction and markets move as a result. Here is a clear case where, under a goods and services tax regime, the brochure prices overseas of Australian holidays would rise. Therefore, under a GST regime there will be a reduction in the number of overseas visitors coming to Australia, and they will go elsewhere.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is nonsense; look at the New Zealand experience.

—I would ask honourable senators to look at the Swedish experience. Despite the worldwide economic slowdown, a record 2.3 million tourists visited Australia last year. It is estimated that by the year 2,000, some 6.4 million people will visit this country from overseas. I might point out that when the Liberal Party was last in Government in 1982, we did not have 2.3 million visitors from overseas; we had about 400,000 to 500,000. So there has been an undeniable improvement under this Government with a rapid growth in international tourism. We do not want to see that put in jeopardy. By the turn of the century we want to see that projection of 6.4 million visitors to Australia become a reality. We want to see its contribution to our balance of payments. It is forecast that by the year 2000 the balance of payments receipts from tourism will be $18,000m—a very significant contribution to the balance of payments.

PARA.TAB: In these circumstances I think we are entitled to ask why tourism has been singled out by the Opposition as the only export to have a goods and services tax applied to its foreign sales. Why is this? Why has the Opposition such crazy policies? Do those opposite recognise the enormous damage that their policies would inflict on Australia's flourishing tourism industry? I see Senator Herron is in the chamber. He comes from Queensland, a State which has benefited enormously from the tourism policies of this Government. Do those opposite, including Senator Herron, recognise the enormous damage to tourism that would be brought about by their policies? Of course they do not.

The reason for this damage is Dr Hewson's fixation on neatness. He wants one rate of tax—the same rate—on everything almost without exception. He wants a 15 per cent goods and services tax on virtually everything sold or produced in the Australian economy. So he is being very tough-minded about the tourism industry, possibly he is being tough on the honourable senators from Queensland on the conservative side of parliament, by proposing to tax this industry just like any other industry—yet I emphasise that it is a vital export earner for Australia.

Last month an exemption from the goods and services tax was sought by the travel industry for tour packages bought overseas. But rather than concede the blatant anomaly in the Fightback package and act accordingly, Dr Hewson—that zealous, tidy-minded rationalist who wants one rate of tax on everything—chose instead to lecture the industry about vested interests.

The reality is that the Opposition has got it wrong on tourism. All the gains that tourism has achieved under a decade of Federal Labor Government would be lost if the Opposition ever won office. Through vigorous promotion of Australia as an international tourist destination and in consultation with the industry, Labor has changed the face of tourism in this country. The reality is that Australia attracted about half a million visitors in 1982 under the Liberals, and a figure of 2.3 million visitors now under Labor. That is the achievement.

In 1982 under the Liberals, the foreign exchange proceeds in current dollars from tourism were about $1.9 billion. In 1991 this figure increased to $7.3 billion. It is growing every year and is a major contribution. Tourism now accounts for about 10 per cent of Australia's total export earnings—more than the single earnings from wool, wheat, meat or iron ore. So tourism now is eclipsing those major commodities in its contribution to our balance of payments.

In the next eight years international tourism to Australia is forecast to more than double. But there is an important proviso there, and that is that tourism to Australia is forecast to double if current policies are kept in place—in other words, if it assumes the same policy settings. But if there is a goods and services tax, as I pointed out in my analysis, if the Opposition ever got into power and were able to levy such a tax on the tourism industry, that forecast growth in the industry would not occur.

In 1981-82 under the Liberals, the total number of jobs in the tourism industry nationally was 337,000; this has now grown to 450,000 jobs. So there has been a net job creation of over 110,000 jobs in tourism since the Liberals were in office. It is forecast that over the rest of this decade, the remainder of this century, one in six of all new jobs in Australia—in other words, 16 to 17 per cent—will be in the tourism industry. But again this is assuming that policies are unchanged. It assumes that the same policy settings are in place as now apply. That would not be the case if there were imposed a crazy goods and services tax that discriminates against the Australian tourism industry, an industry which creates many thousands of jobs in the Australian economy.

In this Budget, for the first time there is a separate appropriation for tourism. This reflects the creation in December last year of a separate ministry of tourism and a new Department of Tourism. The $76m for the Australian Tourist Commission represents an increase of 18 per cent on last year and an eight-fold increase in funding since 1983. There is a $19m allocation for the Department of Tourism. An amount of $12m is provided for the refurbishment of the Indian Pacific train, which is a major vehicle for tourism in Australia. Over $6m is provided for the construction of cultural centres at both Uluru and Kakadu national parks. So there is a range of new initiatives in this Budget to keep on with the good work, to keep underpinning growth in Australian tourism. In addition, the Australian tourism industry stands to be a major beneficiary of the Government's $350m local capital works program in this Budget.

Overall, having set out those constructive initiatives in this Budget, we can draw a very clear comparison with the absolute nightmare that is in prospect for tourism in this country if the Opposition ever gets into power. A 15 per cent goods and services tax would be a death sentence for many businesses in the tourism industry. That is undeniable. In fact, I have not heard the Liberal Party tourism spokesman for some time now. I wonder whether the person who is supposed to be looking after the tourism industry for the Opposition still exists. That person probably knows the enormous damage—he comes from Senator Herron's home State of Queensland—a 15 per cent goods and services tax would do to the tourism industry in Australia in general and in Queensland in particular.

The reality is that, under a goods and services tax, all travel products and services in Australia would carry a 15 per cent tax. That includes hotels, motels, domestic air fares, conference venues, restaurants, meals, takeaways, tourist attractions, souvenirs, et cetera. The list goes on and on.

Under the Liberal Party proposal, international air fares would be zero rated; that is, there would be no tax on the cost inputs into international air fares as well as the fares themselves, but domestic air fares would not be zero rated. Therefore, it would be relatively cheaper for Australians to holiday overseas; in other words, the price differential between domestic and international holidays would be shifted in favour of international holidays for Australians. So more Australians, under Liberal Party policies, with a GST, would be encouraged to holiday overseas than otherwise would be the case. More of them would have stayed at home in the absence of such a tax.

There is a double whammy in this proposal. It makes it more expensive for international visitors to come to Australia, but by the same token it makes it cheaper for Australians to holiday overseas. So there are two policy settings, if allowed to be put in place by the Liberals, which would act to worsen the situation for the Australian tourism industry and also act to harm the Australian balance of payments.

A goods and services tax on the tourism industry would have the impact of throwing away the relative price advantage that Australia has at the moment. We do not have a goods and services tax on this industry. We would be throwing away a relative price advantage by making the industry more expensive for international visitors to Australia and making it cheaper, by zero rating international air fares, for Australians to holiday abroad instead of holidaying in our country.

A closer look at the implications of a 15 per cent GST on tourism shows the nightmare Australia's alternative government has in store for this country. We would have zero rated international air fares, which I have just referred to, and an incentive to holiday overseas. Giving an incentive to holiday overseas is bizarre logic. People would have zero rated flights to Hawaii, yet children's clothes would bear a 15 per cent goods and services tax. This is the sort of policy to which Senator Knowles, Senator Short, Senator Herron and all the others, including Senator Macdonald from Queensland, subscribe. The unfairness and the inequity are shown by the fact that international air fares on holidays in Hawaii would be zero rated—there would be a subsidy through the GST package—but Australian children's shoes would bear a 15 per cent goods and services tax. That is the unfairness, that is the inequity, of the policies being proposed by those opposite. That is Dr Hewson's tax mess. That is his package for Australian families.

Fightback, Dr Hewson's package, would cost Australian domestic airlines more than $250m each year, even allowing for any tax offsets they might gain through the abolition of various taxes. That $250m would mean that domestic air fares would rise. My estimate is that domestic air fares might rise by about 10 per cent as a result of the impact of a goods and services tax on the domestic airlines.

The reality is that many small businesses in the tourism sector would be badly hurt by a goods and services tax. That is undeniable. I remember hearing a speech in this chamber recently by Senator Knowles—who, coincidentally, happens to be present now—in which she said that firms would not be hurt because under the package there would be the abolition of payroll tax and therefore they would be advantaged.

TALK.START.PARA: —Here is this old furphy again.

—The reality is that 85 per cent of firms in the tourism sector, and Senator Knowles knows it, do not pay payroll tax. So we see the sheer ignorance of Senator Knowles and all the others who come in here and say, `Oh well, we concede we are going to put a 15 per cent tax on, but, really, you are going to get exempted from payroll tax'. The reality is that only 15 per cent of the producers in the industry pay payroll tax now. How can 85 per cent of the sellers of services in the tourism sector be advantaged by the abolition of payroll tax? The State governments have thresholds for small businesses. They do not pay payroll tax. Senator Knowles should go back to the drawing board, as should the rest of those opposite who come in here and parrot that twaddle about the abolition of payroll tax advantaging sellers in the tourism industry.
—Don't demean yourself.

—Senator Macdonald is also from Queensland. He knows what the reality is. He has been caught out in Townsville saying things about tourism. The reality is that only 15 per cent of producers in the tourism sector pay payroll tax and therefore only 15 per cent of them, in theory, could be advantaged by the abolition of the payroll tax.

PARA.TAB: Then we have the double twaddle from Senator Knowles and all of the others opposite who say, `Of course, we're going to abolish wholesale sales tax, too'. That is the other claim they make. I might also point out that payroll tax is levied by State governments, so these people claim to be talking for the State governments, too. It will be interesting to see whether all of the State governments go along with plans to abolish payroll tax.

Let us turn to wholesale sales tax. Those opposite claim, `We're going to put on a 15 per cent goods and services tax, but really, everyone in the industry will be advantaged because we're going to take off sales tax'. After labour costs, the biggest single item purchased by the Australian tourism sector is food. It is a hospitality industry. What is the story on food with regard to sales tax? Ninety-nine per cent of food items do not require the paying of sales tax. Senator Herron knows it; Senator Knowles knows it, although she parrots this twaddle about the abolition of sales tax helping the tourism industry.

The reality is that 99 per cent of food items are now totally free from sales tax, so how is the abolition of sales tax going to give a kick-start or compensation to the tourism sector if and when a 15 per cent goods and services tax is levied on it? There is silence from the other side—deafening silence. There is no advantage, is there? There is no advantage in removing sales tax for members of the tourism industry. They are going to get hit in the neck by a 15 per cent goods and services tax; 85 per cent of them will not get any advantage from the abolition of payroll tax. As I have pointed out, after labour costs, food items are a major purchase cost for the tourism sector and a great majority of food items are not subject to sales tax.

It is an incredible situation. The Opposition comes in here and claims it will advantage the tourism industry by abolishing those two taxes. The Liberals are exposed yet again and they still go on with this absolute nonsense that price rises as a result of the GST would be kept to about 4 1/2 per cent on average throughout the Australian community. However, the two taxes that come into this calculation, sales tax and payroll tax, have only a minuscule effect on the Australian tourism sector at present. Clearly, the price rise for Australian tourism will not be 4 1/2 per cent, it will be significantly higher than that. The Liberals have been very misleading when talking about the cost impact on this very important industry—this large Australian earner of foreign exchange—as a result of a goods and services tax.

I have had the opportunity of reading the report by Ernst & Young, which is one of the big six accounting firms. I believe it provides consultants to the Liberal Party. These consultants actually looked into the impact of this goods and services tax on the hospitality industry and came up with some interesting price rises. I said that the Liberals are claiming that prices across the board will go up 4 1/2 per cent as a result of a goods and services tax, but the Ernst & Young report said that the cost of accommodation would rise by 10 to 13 per cent. This is a double digit increase. The report said the cost of meals would rise by 12 to 13 per cent in the hospitality sector as a result of a goods and services tax and the price of alcohol would go up by 4 to 8 per cent.

Those are some of the problems that will accompany a goods and services tax, if and when one is introduced in the Australian tourism industry. Opposition back benchers have been sold a pup on this matter, particularly those from Queensland which has had a very rapidly growing and large tourism sector. They do not seem to realise that a goods and services tax is a value added tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —You sit down and I will tell you all about it.

—I advise Senator Macdonald that the value added in the tourism industry is largely added by labour. That is substantially correct, because labour is the largest cost item in this very labour intensive tourism sector of the Australian economy. Therefore, if a goods and services tax is applied to a labour intensive industry, it is substantially a tax on labour. It is a labour value added tax. In other words, what the Liberals are proposing for labour intensive sectors of the Australian economy, including tourism, is a universal payroll tax. It is substantially a payroll tax on an industry with a high labour content. It is a very labour intensive industry. Basically, what the Opposition is talking about for the tourism sector, and all other labour intensive sectors of the Australian economy, is a universal payroll tax.

PARA.TAB: At the present time we do not have a universal payroll tax in this country. The Opposition talks about abolishing the payroll tax, but, as I pointed out earlier, the payroll tax in the Australian economy is subject to very large exemptions. Small businesses do not pay it. They have exemptions.

If and when the Liberals get into power—and it is becoming less and less likely—they are proposing to trade off a payroll tax, with thresholds and exemptions for small business, for a universal payroll tax for labour intensive industries. That analysis is correct. Basically, they are talking about getting rid of a partial, selective payroll tax which takes small business out of the net and bringing in a universal payroll tax. It is a labour intensive industry and labour is the major contributor to value added in that industry.

Not only would the Opposition put a tax slug on the tourism industry, but also I understand it wishes to abolish the Department of Tourism. If Senator Macdonald makes a contribution to this debate, maybe he will answer that point. He is from Queensland and he may be able to enlighten us on this proposal to abolish the Department of Tourism.

I understand from looking at Fightback that there is no emphasis on tourism promotion contained in it, there is no emphasis on boosting tourism infrastructure and there is no national tourism strategy that I could find. Maybe I did not read it from cover to cover, but there is no emphasis on the national tourism strategy in that document.

All there is is a dead weight of a 15 per cent goods and services tax which would raise prices in the tourism sector by as much as 13 per cent. It is a dead weight without compensation in the form of payroll or sales tax reductions for many producers in the industry. The 15 per cent GST would contribute up to a 13 per cent increase in prices in the tourism sector.

For States such as Queensland, the Liberals are offering a disastrous 15 per cent tax for Australia's fastest growing industry. Here we have a situation where the Opposition—if it were allowed to get into power—could wreck a major industry. It could end a success story which has been going on for a decade in Australia and it must not be given the chance to do that. We must reject the Fightback package.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was my intention to speak solely about health care, but I am delighted that I was present when Senator Maguire was speaking, because what I have to say about the Government's understanding of health care also parallels Senator Maguire's understanding of the Fightback package.

PARA.TAB: Recently I listened to a speech from the Government side about health care. It was prostate wrenching, uterus twisting, gut wrenching, babbling nonsense from the Government speakers on health care and that applies equally to Senator Maguire's diatribe and his knowledge of the Fightback package. I quote from a recent speech by a Government senator:

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition will increase individual costs of visits to the doctor, force private health insurance on to people, increase dramatically the cost of treatment in hospitals, increase inflation and blow out the GDP percentage of expenditure allocated to health.
The only thing that speaker did not say was that it would cause AIDS.

PARA.TAB: I will take that last point, the GDP percentage allocated to health. It is often claimed by the Government—and also by the bureaucrats—that the proportion of our gross domestic product spent on health care in the last 16 years has been static. They claim it is a great victory—the same percentage of GDP has been spent. The Government does not tell us that we are now spending $740 a head below the average of the nine OECD nations. We have dropped behind the rest of the world, because not only have we had the recession that we did not have to have, but also we have screwed down expenditure on health care and it is making it impossible for people to be able to afford the freedom of choice to which they are entitled.I have another quote from that same speech:

SPEECH.PARA: One does not go to a private hospital to receive acute care for cardiac problems.

I would like Government members to visit St Andrews Hospital in Brisbane which handles more cardiac problems—it is a private hospital—than the Prince Charles Hospital, which is the centre for cardiac surgery in Queensland. The speech continues:
We do not go to a private hospital for major brain surgery.
I would like them to visit the Mater Private Hospital in Brisbane where major brain surgery is performed. The speech continues:
We do not go to a private hospital for intensive care.

I would like them to visit the Wesley Hospital in Brisbane and the other private hospitals in Brisbane which have more than adequate intensive care departments and which would parallel anything in a public hospital.

PARA.TAB: What concerns me most is that there is no acknowledgment that one-third of hospital patients treated in Australia today are treated in private hospitals; there is no recognition of this whatsoever. Government policy has deliberately squeezed private patients out of these private hospitals. I draw the parallel that, if private hospitals closed tomorrow, it would be like closing private schools and putting all those school children into the public system.

But that is the direction in which the Government is going. Why? Because that is its philosophy. It is philosophically driven to try to break the private insurance system of Australia without recognising the consequences of doing so. It is an absurdity. I believe that it does not recognise the direction in which it is heading because it is driven by a socialist philosophy. That philosophy has not changed. It was introduced with Medicare and we are witnessing the end point now, where the queues are getting longer and the public hospitals are screaming about their difficulty in being able to treat the number of patients who are presenting to them. There will be no end in sight unless there is a change of government.

Only 41 per cent of Australians can now afford private health insurance care. In my own State of Queensland, it is down to 30 per cent. Another percentage of Australians are not prepared to take the risk of waiting in queues and are paying for their treatment out of their pockets. So a certain percentage cannot be demarcated.

The Government claims that its great Medicare system allows freedom of access. I would like it to tell that to the widow of a patient in Western Australia who was waiting for coronary bypass surgery. This man received publicity in Western Australia last week because he died while on the waiting list to have coronary bypass surgery.

An extrapolation of that is the Canadian system, which this Government has so obviously followed. The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) acknowledged that this is occurring in Australia and that rationing is the only answer under Medicare. If we follow that system, as we are, we will reach the stage which has been reached in Canada, where the bureaucrats direct the cardiac surgeons as to which patients they should operate on. They have now reached the stage in Canada—and there was an article in the journal of the American Medical Association recently pointing this out—where rationing is starting to be applied to age groups and the clinical requirements of people. God help us if we ever get to that point in Australia. But if this present Government continues in power, that is the inevitable consequence of the policies that it is following.

Senator Maguire mentioned the GST effect on shoes. I would like him to know that, for the last nine years, the Spina Bifida Association of Queensland has been approaching the Government to reduce the tariffs on baby marche shoes, which can only be prescribed for spina bifida patients. They are used on babies from about the age of six months to children up to six years of age. There is a 41 per cent tariff on those shoes, and they are not produced in Australia. Despite approaches from the Spina Bifida Association, which, as I say, have gone on for nine years, and the fact that these shoes are sold only through the Spina Bifida Association to children with spina bifida—they have no other purpose—this current Government imposes a 41 per cent tariff on those shoes, which are not produced in Australia.

There are other examples. On 15 October, I asked Senator Tate, the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, about a missionary couple who are expecting a baby in January. They are recognised by the Australian Tax Office and the Department of Social Security as being Australian citizens, but because they have been out of Australia for three years in Papua New Guinea, they are not recognised by the Health Insurance Commission as being eligible for Medicare payments.

Senator Tate told me that within hours he would take it up with the Health Insurance Commission. I checked this morning. Those people have not been contacted by any government department. That was on 15 October. That is an example of the caring concern that people get. We get the words and the feeling that this is all encompassing, but the way in which the Government administers its policies proves that there is no caring concern and no freedom of choice. We are heading down the path of further rationing and a lack of freedom.

There is only one solution in relation to health, and that is the Fightback package. We are advocating freedom of choice for people. We are differentially assisting people on low incomes to obtain private insurance. This is recognised by the Australian Hospitals Association, which is the body representing public hospitals, not private hospitals. The Australian Hospitals Association represents over 600 public hospitals in Australia. It has put out a document together with the Private Hospitals Association called Operation Hospital Survival.

There is an abysmal and unbelievable ignorance on the part of the Government in terms of facing reality because of its philosophically driven commitment. That should be abandoned because it means the destruction of the public hospital system. Only 3 per cent of recurrent spending goes towards capital expenditure on public hospitals in Australia. They are deteriorating rapidly.

The health Ministers of Victoria and New South Wales are quite rightly holding out on the Medicare agreement at the moment because they want recognition of this factor and it is not being given to them. The Government knows that not only is the country broke, but also that the hospital system is broke. It is not prepared to address that. It has set up various inquiries and committees, such as the Macklin committee which has been going on for nearly two years, and issuing papers because it knows that it does not have a solution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this debate on the Appropriation Bills 1992-93 to address the issue of industry development or, perhaps more correctly, what needs to be done to ensure that our industries do not go down the drain totally and that they can be developed and made more competitive in international markets.

PARA.TAB: On 17 June 1992, I moved to establish a Senate inquiry into tariffs and industry development. That move was prompted by increasingly desperate appeals from Australia's manufacturing industries that Australia's industrial capacity and Australian jobs were being destroyed by cheap imports encouraged by the Government's tariff cutting regime. The Government's program called for inexorable step by step reductions until the year 2000, when the tariffs on cars would be down to 15 per cent; on TCF products to 25 per cent or lower; and on all other manufactured goods no higher than 5 per cent.

Dr Hewson went one better. He proposed a scorched earth policy with zero tariffs by the year 2000. The consequences of this policy are now on the public record for all who are prepared to look at the evidence. In June 1990, unemployment was 6.7 per cent; in June last year, it was 9.4 per cent; and at the beginning of this year, it was 10.4 per cent. When I moved to establish the inquiry, it was 11.1 per cent and destined to remain at approximately that level to this day.

The terms of reference of the inquiry were designed to probe the connection between tariff cuts and the continuing loss of jobs and the wider social consequences of unemployment by establishing—and I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the effect of varying levels of protection on employment, public revenue, social security expenditure and regional communities dependent on particular industries.

The inquiry would seek to obtain relevant evidence through public hearings and written submissions from employers, unions, industry associations, consumers, workers, local government and community groups generally.

PARA.TAB: Somewhat predictably, neither the Government nor the Opposition wanted to hear first-hand evidence from the victims of their policies. They preferred to stay in their Canberra cloisters and pursue their free market ideologies.
