To their shame, Government and coalition senators combined to vote against the inquiry, hoping to keep the evidence of the damage their failed economic theories were causing from the communities which they purport to represent.

This may have been the end of it, but on this occasion our democratic system proved that it could survive attempts to subvert it. The Clerk of the Senate confirmed that there was no prohibition on an individual parliamentarian establishing his or her own independent parliamentary inquiry and to use normal parliamentary entitlements and resources to do so. However, this did not cover inquiry staff, travel or advertising costs which, for a three-month bare bones budget, were in the end covered by contributions from a range of individual enterprises, industry associations, including the Chamber of Manufactures, and the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Union.

Former parliamentary adviser and lawyer, Ms Lesley Vick, was appointed inquiry secretary. Mr Ernest Rodeck, National President of the Institute of Management, agreed to act as executive secretary of the inquiry. Inquiry funds are administered by public accountant Brian Harrisson and are subject to audit by KPMG Peat Marwick. My colleague Senator Sowada contributes valuable expertise in her capacity as industry development spokesperson for the Australian Democrats.

The title, `Inquiry into Tariffs and Industry Development', indicates that the ambit of the inquiry is wider than protection devices such as tariffs or quotas. Indeed, the inclusion of that term should not be taken to indicate that the inquiry was initiated out of a desire to return to the uniformly high protection of the 1950s or 1960s. That way leads to featherbedding, lazy management and high costs for industry and consumers.However, the inclusion of industry development does indicate determination to ditch the utterly irresponsible reliance on so-called free markets to determine the extent to which the social, economic and environmental aspirations of Australians can be realised.

It is time to discard the failed concept of economic rationalism. It is time to adopt a deliberate strategic approach to each industry on a sector by sector basis and to determine whether the industry should be maintained, phased out or boosted. This assessment must be made not only on the basis of short-term economic considerations but also must take into account social and environmental consequences, alternative employment prospects, long-term implications for Australia's economic and strategic independence, social cohesion and cultural sovereignty.

It is little wonder that neither the Government nor Dr Hewson wanted this deliberate strategic approach. It would have meant loosening their desperate grip on economic rationalism and their reliance on free markets for all decisions. It is a stance which appears to absolve them from their responsibility to govern for the benefit of the people who have elected them. In fact they are, of course, guilty of dereliction of duty for abdicating just these responsibilities.

The evidence collected by the inquiry will force them to confront the fact that they are culpable and will lead, hopefully, to a change of attitude and a change of direction before it is too late for Australia's manufacturing industries and primary producers. The inquiry has received over 50 submissions, has collected a large body of research material and has held two days of public hearings in Melbourne, one each in Canberra and Adelaide, as well as shorter, less formal meetings in Warrnambool, Ararat, Mildura, Shepparton, Wangaratta and Albury-Wodonga. Further public hearings are scheduled for Geelong, Ballarat, Bendigo, Sale and Bairnsdale, as well as Launceston, Sydney and Brisbane.

The focus today is on the evidence received during the first three public hearings in Melbourne and Canberra. Madam Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to table the interim reports of those three hearings.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Four major themes emerged from these reports: firstly, there is a significant correlation between tariff cuts and the increased levels of unemployment; secondly, there is significant intervention by other governments to develop and protect their industries and to erect barriers against imports from Australia and other countries; thirdly, the promised cost reductions due to micro-economic reforms have not eventuated; and, fourthly, low wage levels, unacceptable working conditions, lack of health and safety standards and the almost total absence of environmental safeguards in some competitor countries, raise the question of how Australia can best maintain hard won living standards and avoid being dragged down to the world's lowest levels in these areas.

PARA.TAB: Statistics provided by Ms Anna Booth, National Secretary of the TCF Union, indicate that the import share of textile and shoe products has risen to almost 50 per cent from 26 per cent in 1985-86. Today, in answer to a question asked by me, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) provided different figures. I know which figures I would like to choose. I will provide the Minister and the Senate with the figures which substantiate this claim made by the TCF Union based on information provided by the Bureau of Statistics.

Clearly, the recession can be blamed for a drop in total demand. However, it is less plausible—in fact it is wrong—to blame the recession for a change in the composition of sales in a given industry. Job losses as a result of that influx of imports in the TCF industries are at this very moment continuing at the rate of 200 per week on a national basis. A recent survey of 203 TCF companies by Arthur Andersen indicates that employment is likely to continue to fall at least by another 5 per cent in total during 1992 and 1993 unless there is an immediate turnaround in Government policy towards import protection.

Mr Richard Dowe, Executive Director of the Heavy Engineering Manufacturers Association, reported a 60 per cent loss to imports in heavy engineering since 1985. He referred to a Queensland University study showing that each $1m of manufacturing activity retained in Australia generated 29.5 person years of employment, $280,000 government revenue, $231,000 social security savings and $255,000 increased disposable income. It behoves us as a nation to look at both sides of the ledger. We should not simply chase down the road of economic rationalism, saying that sometime in the future we will receive some benefits.

In the furniture manufacturing industry, which is employing directly 50,000 workers, imports have reached a record 35 per cent. And in the sugar industry export earnings had dropped in 1991-92 by approximately 25 per cent as a result of a significantly lower tariff as well as adverse weather and lower world prices.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is absolute rubbish. The tariff has absolutely nothing to do with it.

—Senator Macdonald should have a look at the Queensland sugar industry; he should look at what the Government is doing, with his support, to the sugar industry. In July imports of cars and trucks recorded a 40 per cent increase in just one year.

PARA.TAB: Let me turn to what other countries are doing to protect their industries. An example of the readiness of other countries to protect their own is provided by the United States Industries Mobilisation Act which was used just three years ago to prohibit the importation of propeller shafts, even though substantial orders had already been placed with an Australian manufacturer.

The Thai Government ensures that Thai producers of sugar can recoup all their fixed costs from domestic sales, enabling them to savagely cut their prices on international markets, very effectively keeping out Australian sugar. Tariff and quota protection used by other car producing countries is substantial, starting with 10 per cent in the European Community, even though it has easy access to the world's largest market and long production runs.

Korea has in place tariffs of 15 per cent and a total ban on the import of Japanese vehicles. Other countries provide incentives for the birth of new car industries by imposing prohibitive tariffs: Taiwan 42.5 per cent, the Philippines 50 per cent, Indonesia 100 per cent, and Thailand 200 per cent.Australia is now one of very few significant car manufacturing countries without quantitative restraints of some sort. The agricultural subsidies used by the United States and by the Europeans, notably France and Germany, are legendary at an average 40 per cent, with some States in the United States providing subsidies of up to 90 per cent.

The emerging data from the inquiry points to the rest of the world protecting their industries and their jobs while our Government, aided and abetted by Dr Hewson, is prepared to sacrifice our industries on the altar of discredited theories which are not of this world.

The suggestion that we are prevented by GATT from taking action is simply not true. It is a furphy. Article 12 of GATT provides a specific exemption for countries with balance of payments difficulties and allows them to use protection measures to address their difficulties. Heaven knows, Australia has balance of payments difficulties. All it takes is some political will.

Costs rise as tariffs fall. That is another finding which is very clearly emerging from the inquiry. When the Government embarked on its tariff cutting program Australian manufacturers were led to expect that micro-economic reform would reduce their costs. However, these cost reductions have simply not been delivered.

The failure to pass on stevedoring cost savings to shippers is on the public record. However, it goes beyond the failure to deliver cost reductions. Industries are facing rising costs even as protection levels are reduced. The Chemical Industries Council testified at the inquiry that last year alone government charges had risen by 9.5 per cent. The two-way squeeze industries are facing is one more factor supporting a 12-month pause in tariff cuts.

But there is another side to this situation. The most telling example of the pressure faced by Australian industries was the evidence about wage levels in China, which in 1991 provided 69 per cent of clothing and 55 per cent of footwear imports. This had risen from 53 per cent and 27 per cent respectively in 1988. The evidence was that the wage for a six-day week in a Chinese textile factory is the equivalent of $20. There was little evidence of work safety provisions which we take for granted, or the anti-pollution safeguards our manufacturers are correctly obliged to use and which they have to cover in their cost structure.

We have a choice as a community. We can try to compete with these exploitative practices and in the process negate the industrial, social and environmental standards we have. We would depress our standards in trying to compete. Very clearly, we cannot compete successfully. So we have a choice. Do we buy cheap products, do we allow imports to come in and do we throw our workers on the scrap heap and pay higher taxes to pay them unemployment benefits for doing nothing? Or do we continue to pay current prices for consumer goods, do we forgo cheaper prices for the goods we use and continue to have people in productive work?

However, it is not a black and white choice. The evidence in this inquiry is not pointing to high protection as the saviour and the be-all and end-all of what needs to be done. What is being requested is a pause so that we stop destroying our industries, stand back, look at each industry sector and develop the measures that need to be taken not only to save industries and to continue putting people in jobs but also over time to increase the competitiveness which ultimately will lead to greater prosperity for all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is no wonder so few people these days take any notice of the Australian Democrats and it is no wonder that their vote has fallen to less than 3 per cent when we have the sort of speech that Senator Spindler just made. In all sincerity, it was full of unfactual rubbish. Senator Spindler somehow tried to say that because we remove a tariff from sugar—a tariff is to stop sugar coming into the country—it suddenly cuts our export values of sugar. Senator Spindler will have to tell me how that actually happens, bearing in mind that the tariff is to stop sugar coming into the country. He is telling me that that in some way affects the amount of money we get for sugar we sell overseas. It is absolutely incredible, particularly when 80 per cent of our sugar—Senator Spindler would not realise this—most of Queensland's sugar, is exported and is not therefore affected by a tariff on sugar coming into the country. Senator Spindler must understand why people are leaving his Party in droves.

PARA.TAB: I thought I might start my contribution to the debate on the Appropriation Bills by quoting some comments by a prominent Australian politician. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: There are three main advantages of (consumption) tax:
First, it will allow a more rational tax system than the current anomaly-ridden wholesale tax, which has multiple rates, numerous exemptions, and fails to tax the services sector.
Second, it will enable us to generate tax revenues to provide for a major reduction in the marginal rates of income tax. No other tax has the same potential for this purpose.
Third, it generates tax from those who will continue to evade or avoid income tax. That provides a useful `net dividend' for distribution to the rest of the community.
He went on to say:
I'll be barracking for a broad based consumption tax.

I ask Senator Bolkus, who is in the chamber: who would he think that was? Would he think that was John Hewson, or perhaps Peter Reith? Those words were not theirs; they were the words of his leader—no-one else but Mr Paul Keating, the man who wanted the broad-based consumption tax. Senator Bolkus would have got that wrong, but those were the words of Mr Keating advocating a consumption tax, a GST.

PARA.TAB: I usually have a high regard for Senator Maguire. He usually talks a lot of sense, as is shown in the committees on which I have been involved with him. The absolute rubbish that he spoke in his contribution, particularly as it relates to the tourism industry, encouraged me to respond to him, even though I was not originally listed to speak in this debate. I point out for the benefit of Senator Maguire and for the benefit of those people who might be listening the enormous advantages that the Fightback package will bring to tourism. As a Queenslander, one who lives in the premier tourism area of Australia in the north of Queensland, I am very pleased that the Fightback package has given these sorts of benefits to the tourism industry. Time will prevent me from doing other than merely mentioning them very quickly.

The tourism industry will benefit from the abolition of seven existing taxes. The Federal Treasury—this is the Labor Government's Treasury—has estimated that over $1 billion of savings will be available for key sectors of the tourism industry through the abolition of indirect taxes. These savings include: $376m in air transport; $361m in entertainment; and $318m in restaurants, hotels and clubs. The abolition of the petrol tax for private users, totalling 19c a litre, a saving of $11 each time the average car is filled, will bring domestic travel back within the reach of ordinary Australians. Business users will save 26c a litre. In the tourism industry a major Queensland coach company would save almost $2m in fuel tax, $100,000 in sales tax on tyres and $125,000 for parts and maintenance. A Whitsunday air charter company near where I live would save $67,500 from its Avgas bill of $217,500. People will be able to afford to travel to tourism destinations in my area.

The abolition of sales tax will see the hotel and motel industry free from the 20 per cent tax it currently pays on items ranging from soap and toilet paper to bar equipment, laundering equipment, glasses, crockery and bed linen. Personal income tax cuts in the range of $13 billion will put more money in the pockets of average Australians to spend on domestic travel, and they will do it.

There are changes in the capital gains tax which will benefit tourism operators. The Jobsback package will be particularly beneficial to tourism. All GST on any business inputs into the tourism industry will be rebated in full, so tourist operators will not in any way be burdened by the GST but they will make enormous savings from the abolition of seven existing taxes. There are another two pages of benefits I could mention but time does not permit me to do that.

In the last five minutes of my speech I want to respond to some equally silly comments made by one of the Labor Party senators, Senator West, earlier on in relation to local authorities. I do not know what Senator West's expertise is but it is quite obvious that she has no idea of how local authorities operate and how the Fightback package will impact upon them. She probably should have investigated just what taxes this current Government imposes upon local authorities. They pay enormous payroll tax in my State and in several other States of the nation. The petrol tax that all councils pay is an enormous impost on their operations, one which they pay purely in tax revenue to this Federal Government.

Of course, the sales tax legislation is somewhere around the Parliament at the moment. In that legislation, this Government attempted for the first time to impose a sales tax on local authorities through the incidence of hiring. I might also say that, through this Government's recently announced initiatives, local authorities are going to benefit by having the fringe benefits taxes that they currently pay doubled. So that is what this Government thinks of local authorities.

By contrast, our proposal to remove petrol tax, payroll tax and the training guarantee levy will have significantly beneficial impacts on local authorities. For example, the Labor controlled Townsville City Council will save some $307,580 from the abolition of fuel tax alone. It will also save $210,000 from the abolition of payroll tax.

Our package is a very honest one. We acknowledge up front that our grants to State and Federal governments will be cut by 5 per cent. If that were done across the board for every council there would be a 5 per cent cut in their financial assistance grants. But, in the Townsville example that I am citing, while the reduction of 5 per cent in FAGs would be $160,000, the savings from fuel tax would be $307,000—almost double that—and the savings from payroll tax another would be another $210,000 on top. So the Townsville City Council, even allowing for a 5 per cent reduction in FAGs, would still be $357,000 better off under the Fightback package.

That does not take into account the particular savings that councils will make from the reduction in prices that their contractors will tender to them because of the abolition for contractors of wholesales sales tax, petrol tax, payroll tax, the training guarantee levy and the other taxes we propose removing, and the pegging of the superannuation guarantee levy. So there are enormous savings to every local authority around Australia, and Senator West obviously does not understand that. I pity her. She has to fight an election shortly. She simply does not understand that any GST that a local authority might pay on its business inputs will be refunded fully and immediately. I repeat that: fully and immediately refunded. So there will be no negative burden on local authorities from the GST. But local authorities will have enormous savings from the abolition of those taxes. I have given honourable senators the example of the Townsville City Council, but I could give the examples of the Burdekin shire, Pioneer shire, Flinders shire, Ballina City—any council the Government cares to name. I have figures from many councils. All of them will be better off in their operations as a result of the Fightback package, even allowing for the reduction in FAGs.

There is a lot of scuttlebutt going around from some councils or local authorities that are controlled by the Labor Party. But one would expect that. It is the same thing Senator Maguire and Senator West did. People who know better simply and deliberately misinterpret and say things about our policies which are untrue and which they know to be untrue. The regret is—and it is a shame that the Labor Party descends to this type of activity—that the Labor members know them to be untrue but still go around saying them.

In that line, it is a real circus to read what the Brisbane City Council, controlled by the Labor Party, has said about the Fightback package. First of all, the Mayor, Alderman Soorley, decided that it was going to increase the costs of every Brisbane ratepayer by $211. He later changed that to $226; then he went up to $320. He then said that the cost of administration would be $700,000. Then he changed it back to $200,000. He has absolutely no idea. He simply puts forward what his Labor mates down here suggest to him might be a good selling point to try to scare people. But it will not work. He was forced to concede that the Brisbane City Council will save, from the abolition of the petrol tax and the payroll taxes, some $11.4m. He was forced to concede that, and that is fairly typical.

Our program acknowledges across the board that costs will increase by about 4.4 per cent. Obviously, Senator McMullan's lot did not believe that. He went out and got Treasury with all of its resources to check our figures. It came back and said, `Yes, the Liberals are wrong. It is not 4.4 per cent; it is only 3.6 per cent'—less than our calculations. So we acknowledge that the amount people spend per year will increase by about 4 per cent. But, to ensure that no Australian is in any way disadvantaged by the Fightback package, we will increase their take-home pay—put

SPEECH.PARA: money in their pockets from a number of very well thought out, well costed proposals.

PARA.TAB: I am not going to mention all of them—just a couple. Firstly, the tax take for most working Australians will fall by 30 per cent. So a person on $20,000 a year will get $15.60 more in his or her pocket every week, and that is to cover for a 4 per cent, or a $13, $14 or $15, increase in the cost of living. In addition to that, someone with three kids will get an extra $30 a week from the family allowance, and every time they go to fill the family Holden with fuel they will save $10, $11 or $12 as well. So just in those three measures alone a family on $20,000 will be far better off under Fightback, even paying any additional costs that there might be from the introduction of the GST. So they will be better off by something in the range of $30 to $40 more in their pockets every week.

To compensate pensioners for the 4 per cent increase in the cost of living, we will give them an 8 per cent increase. That is not bad deal for pensioners. Their costs increase by 4 per cent; they get 8 per cent more. So they are doing very well. If one goes through the whole range, one finds that all Australians are compensated under the Fightback package and, as a result of that package, they are far better off.

Rather than a high taxing, high spending government that has created the recession we had to have and made almost two million—not one million—of our fellow Australians unable to find full time work, we have a vision, a plan, from the Liberal Party and National Party, and from John Hewson, to send Australia in the direction it has to go in this next decade. It is a plan to turn Australia around and to get it to the great heights that we know our country can reach.

TALK.START.PARA: —In summing up the second reading debate on the Appropriation Bills, I thank the Opposition and its members and other parties for their cooperation in expediting this debate—particularly Senator Reid and Senator Hill. If we were going to expedite it on any day so that everybody got a chance to speak, many senators would have enjoyed today, being broadcast day. Nevertheless, I appreciate greatly the fact that a number of people foreshortened their speeches to enable the debate to be concluded within the timetable and that will enable us to get on with the legislative program.

PARA.TAB: The second reading speeches on the Appropriation Bills are always an opportunity for an important debate. Not every contribution made in the course of it is necessarily important, but it is an opportunity for people to speak about important issues and to range widely across matters of concern, because the Appropriations cover every area of government. A number of people have made substantial contributions. It is entirely inappropriate for me to pick out any of them. I might succumb to the temptation to respond slightly to Senator Macdonald, but it is not my intention to do that simply on the basis that he was coincidentally the person speaking when I came in and sat down. I thank honourable senators for their contributions.

We have in Australia today a very important debate about the nature of economic policy. Of course, there is a very dramatic contrast. The only point Senator Macdonald and I might agree on is that the contrast between the two propositions is very dramatic. We would probably agree upon a second point, and that is that six months before an election it is very welcome that both parties have their programs out before the people so that there can be an informed choice. It is the nature of democracy that informed choice enhances the democratic process and it is welcome that we have these comprehensive packages put forward so early. However strongly I might disagree with Fightback and its industrial relations counterpart, I welcome the fact that they are before the people.

I do not want to speak for long because others have expedited proceedings and foreshortened their contributions. I will not take up the time which they have been prepared to forgo. However, I think it is necessary to put on the record that these Appropriation Bills do in some way symbolise one part of the stark contrast between the Government and the Opposition because they set out a policy designed to give stimulus to the economy. One part of the contrast between Government and Opposition going into the next election is that we believe it is appropriate, at a time of concern that recovery from the recession is all too slow, for the Federal Government to be giving stimulus to the economy.

That is the prevailing view now in almost every Western economy, given the election of Bill Clinton today as President-elect with a similar policy. Almost every Western economy—Japan, Germany, Australia and now the United States—has governments, or government elect in the case of the United States, committed to a policy of stimulus to assist in an all too slow recovery from the recession in our case and the lingering recession in other cases.

We have from the Opposition a proposal to slash public spending in a way that would reduce economic growth and enhance inequity. I highlight the contrast in only one other way. I cannot resist elucidating something which Senator Macdonald said. He was very keen to quote the Treasury report which said that prices under Fightback would increase only by 3.9 per cent. But I did not hear him go on to refer to those other parts of that same document which said that, although it is true that on average prices will go up only that much because the prices of some luxuries will fall dramatically, the price of food will go up by 8.8 per cent, the price of clothing by more than 10 per cent and the price of electricity by approximately 10 per cent. The three basic necessities that every family has to buy will go up by more than twice the average. That is an example of how the inequity is generated.

It is also exacerbated by the nature of the income tax cuts where the biggest increases in after tax earnings go to those on $75,000 a year, which seems to me not to be a definition of those in greatest need in our society. It may be a definition of the salary most commonly found in the Opposition party room, but it does not reflect where I think the burden of need most importantly lies. It is in some way a magic pudding approach. I am sure Senator Macdonald believes what he said, but to pretend we can make massive increases in the welfare of the already well off and that somehow everybody is going to be better off—that there is a magic pudding where you can give everybody a bit extra and nobody loses—is in fact a dangerous illusion, although I accept that the people saying it in the main probably believe it.

However strongly I may disagree with the views that some people have expressed, I welcome the fact that we have had a comprehensive and wide ranging debate on these Bills. It is the standard way these Bills are dealt with but, nevertheless, it is appropriate we should deal with them this way again today. I thank honourable senators for their support of the legislation. I commend it to the Parliament.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.
Motion (by Senator McMullan) agreed to:
That consideration of the Bills in the Committee of the whole be made an order of the day for the next day of sitting.

DEBATE.TITLE: HEALTH AND COMMUNITY SERVICES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 16 September, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —With the concurrence of the Senate I suggest that Government Business order of the day No. 3 be debated cognately with Government Business order of the day No. 4.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's organisation of business has been absolutely appalling. I sat in the chamber earlier in the session waiting to debate the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill for two half days and it did not come on. It was not on the Notice Paper for today; it has now been brought on. The Government seems to be in utter chaos. If it runs the country as it runs this chamber—we know how it runs the country—it is no wonder that we now have $150 billion of debt. We had a significantly lower figure in 1984. I think it was $23 billion; now it is $150 billion. That just shows the chaos that the Government has brought upon this country and upon this chamber. We are now debating cognately these Bills when the first Bill should have been debated last sitting fortnight.

PARA.TAB: The Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill is an omnibus Bill. It involves a number of minor amendments to various pieces of health legislation: for example, substituting the term `patient' for `in-patient' in the Health Insurance Act. In 1989, changes were made to allow for payments for day surgery procedures and patients no longer had to be admitted to hospital overnight to qualify for benefits. At the time, changes which were necessary in the Health Insurance Act to address this change were overlooked. The Bills we are going through today include a number of issues that have been overlooked. We spend enormous amounts of time in this chamber fixing up things that have been overlooked when Bills are brought through.

Another change grants the Minister the power to determine that a medical practitioner is a specialist in cases where the practitioner has omitted to seek recognition in the speciality. This is designed to ensure patients are not restricted to the lower Medicare rebate payable to general medical practitioners rather than the higher rebates payable to specialist practitioners.

Another removes the anomaly which precludes the payment of Medicare benefits for a pathology test if a blood or urine specimen is collected at one laboratory collection centre but is tested at another laboratory. I will not tabulate all the amendments. In relation to the majority covered in this omnibus Bill, the coalition recognises the need for them and has no concerns about them.

One amendment which should not go without comment is the one which provides for removal of what became known as the black box. This was a system that was to be put in place in pharmacies where we would all have an upgraded Medicare card and each pharmacist would have a box in the pharmacy which would be hooked up to the Health Insurance Commission. When anybody went in to get a prescription dispensed, the card would be zapped through the black box and the information would go down to the Health Insurance Commission. Information would come back telling the pharmacist whether the person concerned was eligible for a benefit; that is, whether that person was a resident of Australia and was eligible for the $15.70 benefit, as I think it then was, or the $15.90 benefit as it is now, or whether it involved a pensioner or health care card holder.

We were concerned about the privacy issues and as to whether the saving which the Government said it was to achieve would not be found in this measure. We were told that the savings would be approximately—and I stand to be corrected—$126m. The coalition and the Democrats were told that if this measure did not come into place, we would be contributing to yet another hole in the Budget and we would not be contributing to Government savings and all these terrible things. When Mr Johns bought forward the amendment to take away the clauses which would enable the setting up of this black box, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill also contains provisions which will repeal those sections of the Health Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Act 1991 which related to the introduction of the interactive eligibility checking system and restricted the availability of pharmaceutical benefits to Australian residents and other eligible persons as defined in the Health Insurance Act 1973.
Here is the classic sentence:
These provisions will not now come into effect because the conditions which had been inserted in the commencement provisions could not be met.
A nice little soft soap line here, and it is true. But what were the conditions?

PARA.TAB: The conditions were put in place by the Opposition at the end of the legislation, saying that this could not come into place until the day after a joint inquiry of the Department of Finance and the Auditor-General had reported to both Houses of Parliament that the estimated savings contained in the financial impact statement in the explanatory memorandum to the Health Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill 1991 were realistic estimates and that equivalent savings could not be obtained through the use of alternative eligibility checking systems which are no more intrusive than the eligibility checking proposals contained in the Health Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Act 1991.

What did the Auditor-General find? He found two things. The first was that the Department had used an incorrect figure for estimating the number of claims that were made or prescriptions that were dispensed when the person was not entitled to a benefit. That involved a person who got the lower benefit who was not entitled to it and who was not on unemployment benefits, but still had a current card. The Department was wrong in that respect.

An even greater mistake was that the Department estimated that the average savings for a basic claim would be $12.50 for each person who was receiving a benefit to which he or she was not entitled. Again, the Department got it totally wrong. It forgot that all of us get a benefit at that stage if the drug costs more than $15. The Department was adding up the average cost and including drugs that were worth $45 and $75, and in that way arrived at its average cost. But even if one was not entitled to the lower benefit as a health care card holder, one still was entitled to the other benefit—a benefit to which we are all entitled. So when the Department corrected that, it was found that the average cost was $7.93. That was a very basic error.

Somebody said to me—and I will not say who said it because it was in the confidentiality of the corridors—`I wonder how many other estimates on which we base budget decisions are wrong?' We found a number of them and this was just one. The situation was just appalling. Instead of achieving a figure of $126m, the Department's net savings would be a maximum loss of $13.9m and the maximum gain $6.8m. That was worked out on a range of the number of fraudulent claims. The Department was going to make a loss. So this huge amount of saving we were going to have suddenly dissipated because of two basic errors made by the Department.
What happened then? Mr Johns came into the chamber and very quietly said:

SPEECH.PARA: These provisions—
He was referring to provisions to institute the black box—
will not now come into effect because the conditions which had been inserted in the commencement provisions could not be met.
They could not be met because they got it totally wrong. The Department was shown up for not doing the calculations correctly, and the Government was shown up for not following that through.

PARA.TAB: The Minister should have been asking those questions. Without the benefit of all the resources, we on this side were saying, `These figures look shonky; we don't reckon you can get that sort of saving'. From the very beginning, we questioned the savings that would be made by the black box and our concerns have been vindicated. This legislation is an embarrassing back down by the Government of an admission that it was wrong.

A new patient eligibility checking agreement has been negotiated—`negotiated' may be too kind a word—between the Pharmacy Guild and the Government. It provides that, unless patients can prove their entitlement to pharmaceuticals at the cheaper concession rate, the pharmacist will have to charge the higher general patient rate of $15.90. Accordingly, this Bill now provides the Health Insurance Commission with the power to provide a refund to concessional beneficiaries who subsequently prove their entitlement to the concession rate. It is understandable that the pharmacists object to playing the policemen for the Government. The pharmacists should not be held responsible or suffer financial loss for mistakes made by the Government—for instance, where entitlement numbers are incorrect.

Obviously the navigation of the agreement waters has seen the Minister's good ship `Eligibility Checking' founder yet again. The Pharmacy Guild issued a press release a couple of weeks ago announcing that it was instituting proceedings in the Federal Court against the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) and the Commonwealth. The Guild action was asking the court to declare unlawful the system introduced on 1 October by the Health Insurance Commission to check on social security and war service pensioners.

Another area which concerns the coalition is the provision which abolishes the six-month period before approval to dispense pharmaceuticals is removed. Currently there is a six-month waiting period before either the Secretary of the Department of Health or the Minister can remove either a pharmacist's, a doctor's or a hospital's approval to dispense pharmaceuticals. This Bill removes this waiting period. Neither the Pharmacy Guild nor the National Association of Nursing Homes and Private Hospitals can see any positive rationale for this change, while the latter perceives this to be a further impediment to the private sector and raises the concern that it would allow the Minister to shut down the pharmaceutical operations of a private hospital as soon as it becomes insolvent. The Department of Health has defended the change on the grounds that the power to retract the approval is needed because some approvals are not returned after the close of business. This prevents the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority from issuing approvals to other pharmacists to start business.

However, the coalition is not entirely convinced by this argument and Dr Woods has stated in the House of Representatives that he will be monitoring the situation to make sure that this particular provision is not being abused. The coalition signalled its intention in the House of Representatives that we would be supporting the Bill. However, I wish to move an amendment regarding eligibility checking. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ", but the Senate calls on the Government to make every possible effort to ensure that entitlement numbers on benefit cards are correct, in particular on interim cards issued by the Department of Social Security, and the pharmacists are not penalised financially as a result of mistakes made by Departments".

PARA.TAB: The second Bill that we are debating tonight, the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill (No.2) 1992, also makes a number of minor changes to legislation relating to the health portfolio. The most important is the extension of the sunset clause for R-type diagnostic imaging services to 1 January 1995. Amendments to the Health Insurance Act in 1991 meant that from January 1993 Medicare benefits would not be payable to medical practitioners who rendered diagnostic imaging services. This latest amendment extends the sunset clause to 1995 to allow the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners time to develop accreditation guidelines for GPs who provide radiology services.

The Bill also introduces a new section 20BA in the Health Insurance Act requiring written referrals by GPs to specialists where a special service is carried out to be retained for 18 months. Such referrals must be provided upon request to the Health Insurance Commission. Both the AMA and the Australian Association of Surgeons support the retention of referrals. However, they are concerned that the Bill provides for the imposition of a $500 penalty for failure to provide patient referrals within seven days. The coalition believes that it is important that referrals be produced upon request and will support the $500 penalty. However, we believe that the seven-day requirement is overly harsh and will move in the committee stage of the Bill—I think the amendments have been circulated—to extend the time requirement to 30 days.

As is so often the case with this Government's legislation, this Bill also contains a significant number of amendments which are designed to overcome previous sloppy drafting and legislative oversights. I give some examples. A loophole which allowed pathology practitioners to provide nursing staff at the premises of the doctor or elsewhere has been closed off. Previous sloppy drafting which prevented the cancellation of organisations when the business of all health benefit funds conducted by them had been transferred to another organisation has been rectified.

A drafting oversight back in 1987 which had the unintentional consequence of reducing the Medicare benefits schedule fee rebate for optometrical services for private hospital patients from 85 to 75 per cent has also been rectified. A loophole which allows a child to be considered disadvantaged and hence eligible for a health care card has been closed. Finally, this Bill corrects drafting errors in previous legislation pertaining to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme.

These straightforward provisions are supported by the coalition. However, we are concerned that we are constantly required to spend valuable time in this place amending and correcting loopholes and errors in the drafting of Government Bills.

Secondly, I wish to discuss the parts of the Bill which affect age care and residential age care services—measures which were announced by the Government in the Budget. While there is a pressing need to provide additional funds for the elderly and their carers, the Government's measures fall far short of what is required to ensure a fair and responsible age care system.

The Bill provides for the increase of the domiciliary nursing care benefit. In addition to being tax free and not subject to a means test, the benefit will now be indexed annually on the basis of the CPI. The amendments will also mean that the benefit will be payable to carers for a maximum of 42 days a year while the person is being cared for in respite care. The coalition welcomes the $5 a week increase. It is still woefully inadequate in an era where there is a marked government and community preference for older people to live independently in the community with assistance. It is even more inadequate when it is realised that since its inception the DNCB has not been indexed with inflation.

There was also a Budget decision to provide additional funding for new and rebuilt private nursing homes and former participating religious and charitable homes. In last year's Budget additional recurrent funding was provided to proprietors over a 10-year period for building new nursing homes or completely rebuilding existing ones. However, difficulties arose because the grants were available only after the nursing home was constructed, requiring operators to have raised the capital for the home before they could apply for additional funding.

In response to this criticism, this Budget has sought to address the problem by extending funding available under the system. The Bill introduces an approval in principle system which will allow proprietors to borrow against increased recurrent funding prior to a home being built or rebuilt. However, if no progress is made towards rebuilding, the Bill allows the approval in principle to be revoked and then reallocated. While the coalition does not oppose the introduction of the approval in principle system, it is concerned that the voluntary sector has been virtually excluded from this additional funding without any real valid reason.

The third aspect of the Bill relates to amendments to subsidies currently paid to hostels for personal care and hostel care. The former is paid according to the level of care required by the resident—high, intermediate or low—and the latter is available to residents who do not require personal care and who are financially disadvantaged. The amendments in this Bill will provide for an increase in funding in all subsidies for financially disadvantaged persons by 55c a day. To offset this increase, the personal care subsidy for non-financially disadvantaged persons will be reduced by $2.65 per resident per day. In effect, this will mean that there are seven rates of subsidy. The Government intends that at all these levels of care within hostels there will be a $3.20 subsidy difference between financially disadvantaged and non-financially disadvantaged residents.

The Government has claimed that the amendments are designed to increase equity in the provision of hostel subsidies. It has been reasoned that, as hostels have a greater capacity to raise income from their non-financially disadvantaged residents through entry contributions and variable fees, these amendments will result in government subsidies better targeting support to those in need. However, with the alterations to hostel subsidies, the Government expects savings in expenditure in the vicinity of $34m over the 1992-96 period. The amendments would appear to be more in the nature of a cost cutting exercise than a genuine attempt to implement a more equitable distribution of hostel subsidies. This is also borne out by the fact that the 1992-93 Budget Papers have stated that only 25 per cent of hostels will benefit from the changes, leaving the remaining 75 per cent not being advantaged.

While the coalition supports the increase in subsidy for FDPs, it decries the cut in personal care subsidies for those who are non-financially disadvantaged which will have a detrimental economic effect not only on the substantial number of hostel residents but also on the viability of many hostels. We spoke this morning to a person who has been supervising a very large community program which offers a range of services from child-care, family care and family counselling to home and community care programs in the community and hostels and nursing homes. This person has been running these places since the early 1970s, one of the jewels in the crown in the area of providing an all-round service to families and relatives who are coping with maybe a child who has a problem or family problems and who are also simultaneously caring for an older relative who needs home and community care or residential care.

This person said to me, `Our hostel will go bankrupt. That is what will happen as a result of this. The other thing we may have to do is to look towards having people who can make an ingoing, because we are going to have to balance people who can make an ingoing against those who are financially disadvantaged'. I hope that my colleagues around this chamber will never see that day—the day when decisions are based not on need but on whether a person can pay. That is not the aim of any of us, I presume, in this chamber, but that is what people are saying will happen as a result of this legislation.

Under many existing contracts between residents and proprietors, entry contributions or monthly fees may not be altered until an annual review, a CPI adjustment or with the agreement of the residents. Therefore, the reduction in subsidies for non-FDPs will have a severe effect on many homes' financial viability. As I said, we were told this morning by people who came to see us, who have a record of surviving, that their hostel is in doubt. This includes small or remote hostels that rely heavily on their local community for capital fund raising.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who came to see you?

—If Senator Bolkus wants to know who came, I will ring them and ask them whether they mind. They came here to speak to us confidentially. I will ring the persons involved and ask them whether they want me to name them in the chamber. I am sure that they will be only too happy for me to do so. They are desperate because they feel their hostel will close down. I will do so, as long as Senator Bolkus gives me leave to tell the chamber who they are.

PARA.TAB: Difficulties also arise in the current definition of FDP for the purpose of recurrent funding in hostels. The current definition does not reflect the capacity of hostel residents to pay increased fees. As Aged Care Australia has noted, many elderly hostel residents have the full age pension as their sole source of income, but they are still classed as non-FDPs. Under the Government's proposed amendments, their hostel subsidy will be cut by $2.65 per day which, on the face of it, clearly seems unfair.

Aged Care Australia has recommended that the definition of FDP be changed to include any resident in receipt of the full single age pension who does not own a home. This definition would have significant financial implications. I believe that that or some alternative should be considered by the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs in light of the harshness of the changes included in this Bill. One of the reasons we are referring the legislation to that Committee is so that it can examine the submissions that have been put forward to us and, in particular, that suggestion from Aged Care Australia and any possible alternatives.

It is also likely that the creation of additional levels of subsidy will increase the already onerous administrative burden borne by all hostels. Let me tell Senator Bolkus that, if he cares to visit nursing homes and hostels and ask them what they spend most of their time doing, he would be told that it is not on caring for and comforting the aged; it is on filling out forms for departmental officers and various people who request information.

The fourth aspect of the Bill relates to changes in the date of effect of reviews of classifications for nursing home residents. At present, nursing home residents are classified on the basis of the resident classification instrument, the RCI, which measures their need for care. In classifying a resident, regional assessors are guided by the nursing home classification principle formulated by the Minister. The Secretary of the Department then has the power to review the classification at any time and may revoke it and substitute a higher or lower classification. However, there is presently no requirement for the Secretary to be guided by the principles when reviewing classification.

The amendments in this Bill will make it mandatory for the Secretary to observe the nursing home classification principles when reviewing a resident's classification. Further, the Bill provides that, where a resident classification is reviewed and altered, the subsequent classification will take effect from the date of the original classification and not from the date of the validation as is currently the norm. That is absolutely appalling. In this way, where the Secretary revokes the classification, which requires a lower funding level, the nursing home proprietor will be required to repay the Commonwealth the difference in funding between the reclassified level and the level of original subsidy.

This refund will be required even though the nursing home proprietor has already spent the money on personal care for the resident. In effect, this amendment will impose a system of retrospective reclassification which is inherently unfair. It will have an adverse financial impact on many nursing homes and is strenuously opposed by the coalition.

Concerns have also been raised by the aged care industry about the impact of the classification amendments. Aged Care Australia has again been critical of the Government's failure to consult with those most affected by the changes. Both the National Association of Nursing Homes and Private Hospitals and the Australian Nursing Homes and Extended Care Association have been particularly condemnatory of the way the amendments will allow the RCI auditors, acting on behalf of the Secretary, to have the power to override the initial assessment and make retrospective judgments about the nursing requirements of residents. Moreover, with the majority of reviews in the past 12 months having resulted in residents' classifications being upgraded, concerns have been raised that a massive upgrade of residents could send a home into bankruptcy or, at the very least, result in a genuine reduction in the standard of care received by elderly residents.
The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills has today reported on this aspect of the Bill and has expressed concern about its retrospectivity. The Committee report states:

SPEECH.PARA: However the Committee is concerned by what may be possible in relation to reviews which are determined after the commencement of the proposed new subsections. It would appear that, under the proposed new subsections, a reclassification which is determined after the commencement of those new subsections could be expressed to operate retrospectively, whether the reclassification is beneficial to the patient or not. If this is the case, it is a matter of great concern to the Committee. The Committee would therefore appreciate the Minister's advice as to whether or not this is the case.

Obviously this matter is also of grave concern to the Opposition, and we call on the Minister to take heed of the Committee's remarks and respond to them. The effect of the amendments in this Bill on the viability of the aged care sector and the maintenance of existing services for residents is significant. These matters clearly require further scrutiny by the Senate Committee before implementation.

PARA.TAB: The aged care industry has been subjected to significant change over the past five years, and it is currently being swamped by paperwork and departmental requirements. The concerns that the industry is raising in this Bill deserve the attention of the Senate, and the Committee when it meets. I hope that some of the industry's concerns, if not all, will be able to be addressed.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to look at the two omnibus Bills being debated cognately—the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 and the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992. Generally, the first Bill covers a large number of mainly technical amendments which relate largely to health and community services legislation. The Australian Democrats support the Bill and will not be moving any amendments to it.

PARA.TAB: I do not intend to make many comments on this Bill. However, there is one area of considerable concern, that is, the fact that this Bill brings to an end what we can term `the black box shambles'. This interactive eligibility checking system or, as it became known, the black box, was a particularly ill-conceived idea from the Government which, as it has turned out, was based largely on conjecture and anecdotal material; it certainly was not based on solid evidence. The black box is yet another instance in the health area where the Government has gone full steam ahead with a proposal without consultation and without looking for hard evidence.

The other instance which springs to mind is the changes to radiology services. In that case the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs looked in detail at the implications of those changes. The eventual decision was a unanimous one—to repeal the regulations and to suggest that a further detailed review of radiology be undertaken before any further suggestions of changes be made. It was a similar story with the black box. The Government's figures on just about every aspect of the proposal turned out to be little more than guesswork. It took the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration finally to get to the bottom of the story and get the figures right.

I do have a lot of sympathy for the Government trying to make reform in some health areas. There are obviously very entrenched vested interests involved who take a great deal of overriding interest—or perhaps we can best say that they protect their particular territory very well; they do not even like to see the edges of their territory in any way eroded. So it is obviously very difficult in some cases to make changes. However, it is in nobody's interests to proceed with what really are half-baked ideas and to get them to the stage of legislation and regulation without all the available evidence, without consultation and certainly without any very reliable data.

When we look at both of these hearings—into pharmacy and radiology—we see that neither the Health Insurance Commission nor the Department were able to supply the Government with reliable data. What we saw were a lot of guesstimates, hunches and anecdotal evidence with very few facts on which to base what were really quite major changes. Obviously, as I said, the Senate Committees recognised that that was not good enough. The withdrawal of the radiology regulations and the black box provisions surely must be a signal to the Government that in future it really does need to get the facts straight and the evidence right before it proceeds and continues with action like this. I hope that both these instances demonstrate to the Government the wisdom of undertaking wide consultation when proposing such changes. I am not saying here that the Government has to take on board everything that it is told, but at least there should be consultation, the weighing up of all the evidence and full investigations made.

Turning to the second Bill, imaginatively entitled Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill No. 2, this contains several provisions relating to the aged and some of these are of great concern to the Democrats. In fact, we have combined with the Opposition to send parts 2 and 5 of this Bill to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs for further examination.

Before I go to these specific matters, I want briefly to discuss the general amendments relating to health in this Bill. Many of these amendments correct errors in previous legislation and are not controversial. However, I must make the point here that there really does need to be a general smartening up as far as drafting of legislation in the health area is concerned. I do understand that some problems can arise because it is a very complex area of legislation; however, it is simply not good enough to keep passing legislation and then having to undo it and redo it again and again. We seem to devote an enormous amount of time in this chamber actually to fixing up errors that have gone through in previous pieces of legislation.

The Opposition has indicated its intention to move an amendment, which I will deal with now. The Bill requires consultant physicians or specialists to retain any referral for a period of 18 months. The referral will then have to be produced on request to an officer of the Health Insurance Commission within seven days of the request being made.

I note that Dr Woods in the House of Representatives and now Senator Patterson in this chamber failed to mention when presenting and discussing these amendments that there is a clause relating to this seven-day limit that actually gives an exemption; that is, where the consultant physician or specialist has a reasonable excuse. So, if there is a problem—for example, the specialist may be overseas, there may be a change of address, there simply may be some lost mail—there is an avenue of appeal. Really, I am at a loss to understand why the Opposition is now going to proceed with this amendment.

When we are talking about taxpayers' money, it seems perfectly reasonable to require professionals to have a standard of administration in their office that is sufficiently efficient that they can put their hands on documents, that documents can be filed away, that they can know the actual place that those documents can be found and then be able to submit them within seven days if they are requested. If circumstances out of the ordinary apply, then they can appeal.

I remind the Opposition that there has to be some reason for such a request to be made. People are not being asked to supply such information because somebody thought it might be a good idea. There is an investigation under way and that is material that is required. It may be to the specialist's advantage to prove that there is no improper conduct and that there is absolutely no shred of evidence of any fraud. So surely it would be in the doctor's best interest to make sure he or she could always put his or her hand very quickly on such information. I have to wonder, if we were talking about social security recipients having to produce evidence, whether some people would be quite so keen to give them all those extra weeks in which to do it. Unfortunately, I doubt it.

I want to turn now to the provisions in the Bill relating to aged care. Firstly, I want to make a very brief comment on the domiciliary nursing care benefit. This Bill provides for an increase of $5 a week. It also provides for indexation of the benefit and makes it payable during respite periods of up to 42 days in any one year. These measures are certainly overdue; they are welcomed by the Democrats as a recognition of the role and needs of carers of both aged people and people with disabilities.

In relation to parts 2 and 5 of the Bill, as I said earlier, the Senate Committee will be looking at these in detail. The Democrats will be moving amendments in committee after we have considered all of the evidence. However, I do feel that I have to make it very clear at this stage that measures being proposed by the Government in these two parts are not acceptable to us.

The Democrats believe that these measures as proposed at the moment are not adequate and will cause considerable problems. Part 2 relates to hostel subsidies. This Bill gives effect to the Government's decision to increase the hostel and personal care subsidy for financially disadvantaged people by 55c a day and decrease the personal care subsidy for non-financially disadvantaged persons by $2.65. This represents a significant change in the Government's subsidy policy and it certainly appears from correspondence I have had to my office that it is yet another move the Government has taken without consultation.

I consider this to be extremely ill-conceived. It is a move that I believe the nursing home and hostel industry has every right to be up in arms about. The industry is quite rightly arguing that the cut in personal care subsidies for non-financially disadvantaged persons will have a detrimental effect on a number of hostel residents and indeed on the viability of many hostels.

The rationale behind this move seems to be that hostels have a greater capacity to generate income from their non-financially disadvantaged residents and that any subsidies coming from the Government should be targeted at those with the greatest need. That sounds quite fair on the surface, but as Aged Care Australia has identified in material it has supplied to my office, there are quite a number of flaws in this approach. Firstly, for many hostels, existing contracts will preclude adjustments to residents' fees until either the annual review, automatic adjustment or with the resident's permission. This is likely to leave hostels with an operating shortfall. I note that the Australian Nursing Homes and Extended Care Association has argued that this problem could be alleviated by having the changes apply only to residents who move into a hostel, after this legislation is proclaimed.

Secondly, the Government itself concedes that 80 to 90 per cent of residents are in receipt of a full pension. Yet when we look at how many are actually officially classified as financially disadvantaged, we see that the ratio is 54.5 : 45.5. Obviously, there is a big gap between those on a full pension and the number actually classified as being financially disadvantaged.

Thirdly, interest income for that non-financially disadvantaged section has recently fallen dramatically. Many of those persons simply do not have the capacity to pay increased fees. Fourthly, hostels have limited capital resources and cannot be expected to rely on interest income to fund any shortfall. Aged Care Australia says that 60 per cent of residents entering hostel accommodation are financially disadvantaged, yet the Commonwealth building subsidy is generally pitched at 15 to 40 per cent financially disadvantaged persons, something the industry described as a `major mismatch' between departmental theory and reality.

Clearly, the Government needs to address these problems and I believe the industry has put a good case for a reduction in the cut to the personal care subsidy for non-financially disadvantaged persons. That reduction, from $2.65 to $1.45, will give them some respite and relieve some of the problems they believe will occur.

However, aside from the actual size of the cut, I suggest a very positive move would be to change the definition of a financially disadvantaged person. As the industry has pointed out, many so-called non-financially disadvantaged persons are now on the full age pension. The definition clearly needs to be changed and hopefully this is one area we will be looking at in committee and will receive support from the Opposition to amend when this Bill comes back before the Senate next week.

To look now at part 5, the Bill also makes several changes to the resident classification process. The main area of concern is the proposal to allow for retrospective classification of nursing home residents. At present, the residents are classified according to the resident classification instrument. This classification is done by the nursing homes according to these very strict guidelines and then at a later date, unfortunately in many cases at a much later date, it is validated. If there is a change in the classification, that change takes effect from the date of the validation or thereabouts.

The proposal in this Bill means that where a classification is subsequently changed, the change has effect from either the date of the resident's admission or the date of his or her last assessment, whichever is the later. The practical down side of this will be that, where a lower classification is substituted, the nursing home proprietor will be required to repay to the Commonwealth the difference between the first classification and the latter level.

There are a number of obvious problems with this. Firstly, these classifications are being done in accordance with the departmental guidelines, as I have said. I have heard no comment from the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) as to whether there is any deliberate misclassification going on out there, whether there is any deliberate, fraudulent behaviour whereby somehow people are being classified as needing a higher degree of care than they really do.

If indeed there is a problem, I ask the Minister to put that on the table. Without that evidence it seems unfair and not very sensible to let experienced staff assess and classify residents when they come in, and then to say at a later date that the classification is retrospectively altered.

Secondly, it is not as if proprietors are salting away the additional money. They are classifying persons in need of a specific level of care and that money is being spent on providing that care. There are no funds salted away in a bank account that can simply be produced and forwarded to the Commonwealth.

Thirdly, I wonder whether there is not some danger in this arrangement of encouraging nursing homes of always erring on the side on caution when classifying. Perhaps residents will not get the standard of care they require until that validation occurs, just in case a mistake is made. In other words, they err on the side of saying, `Maybe they do not require that level of care. We will put them up a classification so that we are not running the risk of spending money that later on we will have to return'.

Lastly, I simply do not see how proprietors will be able to plan their budgets with any confidence whatsoever if these retrospective elements are allowed to pass through this place. I accept that the RCI reviews show that in the majority of instances there is actually an upgrading. While that is fine, it does not address the concerns raised by the industry in relation to residents whose classifications are downgraded.

I would have thought that a more appropriate response from the Government would be to get its act together and ensure that validations are carried out very quickly. I note with interest Senator Patterson's comments. I hope we can join together to make sure that this Bill is not passed with any retrospective element in it. This is something we will need to look at closely during the committee stage.

Finally, I make the general observation that I think the Government has done a reasonable job in relation to improving conditions for residents in nursing homes and hostels. The Democrats have always been of the view that, if we are going to have a for-profit service looking after frail, elderly or disabled people, we must have in place a good level of government scrutiny and regulation. In this regard many positive measures have been introduced by Minister Staples. I believe that he can take credit for some of the changes that have gone on in the industry in recent years.

However, I have to say that the funding arrangements and constraints being imposed on the industry are getting tighter and tighter, to the point where they are becoming more and more complicated and more and more of a burden on the industry. More and more nursing homes and hostels are finding themselves squeezed to the very limits of their ability to offer good quality, high standard care. Staffing levels are being squeezed to the point where only essential nursing services can be offered and a lot of the highly necessary and certainly desirable services have had to go.

The industry is also complaining of lack of advance notice of changes in financial measures. I believe that this complaint certainly has a great deal of validity. The industry sees itself as being asked to cope simultaneously with tougher and tougher financial constraints, while being asked—and quite rightly—to smarten up its act in relation to standards for both personal care and physical surroundings.

This is certainly fair enough. The Government has to get value for its money. But the problems which are arising from the continuing tightening and rapid change undermine the relationship between the Government and the industry at a time when some degree of cooperation and mutual confidence is crucial—indeed, essential.

Some of these decisions appear to be driven solely by the requirement to save money in the short term, without any real look at all at the long term. This is not a satisfactory approach to take, especially where such a vulnerable and disadvantaged group of Australians is concerned.

The two Budget measures contained in this Bill seem to me to be underpinned by precisely that motivation. The fact that they were brought in with virtually no consultation with the industry whatsoever gives us all the evidence we need to see that this is the case. It certainly does not inspire any confidence within the industry.

I would hate to see the Minister's good work in this area go down the drain as a consequence of ill-considered financial decisions such as these, and I urge him to try to ensure that these sorts of short-term, financially expedient decisions do not continue. I am aware of the current review of the structure of nursing home funding. I trust that this really does represent a genuine attempt on the part of the Government to sit down with industry and community organisations working in the field and explore seriously ways of getting long-term value for the taxpayers' dollars, without undermining the standards of care being provided to residents. Perhaps the Minister could look at a similar process for hostels.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill. This is another piece of legislation which this Labor Government is using in an attempt to make some ongoing minor repairs to a fundamentally ailing health system. Therefore, this Bill provides us with an opportunity to take an overview of where Australia is heading in regard to health care.

PARA.TAB: Quite clearly, many people throughout Australia are very concerned about health care in Australia today. They can see that they are not getting anywhere and that their access to hospitals is being reduced. People are simply dying at the end of waiting lists. As the saying goes, if one asks a silly question, one gets a silly answer. That is what we are getting with a lot of this legislation which is before us today.

The evidence continues to mount that Labor's blind, ideological obsession to try to shore up Medicare while ignoring the private sector is giving more and more Australians a worse deal for their health. The latest report from the Western Australia Health Department in August shows that 10,814 people were on the waiting lists of our public hospitals for elective surgery at the end of March. This represented an increase from the figure of 10,676 in the previous quarter. The largest category was 2,656 people waiting for orthopaedic surgery.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, let's have more orthopods.

—Oh, what an intelligent interjection we have just had from Senator West! She said that there are no orthopods who could actually do the orthopaedic surgery. That is just the most absurd statement; that is the type of statement that really concerns the Liberal and National parties about this Government. To think that a senator who is on the Standing Committee on Community Affairs could actually make such an idiotic statement that there are no doctors to actually do the operations! Well, I'll be blowed!

PARA.TAB: The fact of the matter is that there are people with these problems who cannot get into hospitals. They can see the doctor, the doctor can do the surgery, but when they tap on the front door of the hospital they are told, `Sorry, no beds'. That is the point I am making. That is the point that Senator West's State colleague in Western Australia, Mr Wilson, also agrees with. Either Senator West is wrong or Mr Wilson is wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would claim Mr Wilson is wrong.

—I am glad Senator West says that Mr Wilson is wrong. He will be delighted to hear that a mere, meagre little backbencher in the Federal Parliament has said that he is wrong, when he clearly says that he can see the effects of the waiting lists in Western Australia. Those are the problems that are being experienced in Western Australia and right throughout Australia. The answer that Senator West just gave is the sort of stupid, silly answer that we get from the Government.

PARA.TAB: I suppose before I make my next comment, I should pre-empt Senator West's next interjection that there are no surgeons to carry out eye surgery either. Some 1,531 people are awaiting general eye surgery and 1,208 need surgery for ophthalmology. I suppose Senator West will say, `That is not because they cannot get into hospital. That is because there are no ophthalmologists'. These are hardly conditions that I would say are elective, in the sense that there is no hardship in having to wait a while. The bald statistics mean that a lot of individual pain is being suffered.

Those bald statistics also mean a lot to the bills that this country can run up. We have people who are waiting for surgery for things like hip replacements, knee replacements, intra-ocular lenses and so forth who are going lame or blind, who are not able to work and who then have to go on to sickness benefits. So those individuals cease being part of the work force, cease paying tax and go on to benefits that the reducing number of taxpayers has to fund. The likes of Senator West could not give a continental about that imbalance and the way in which that impacts on the fewer and fewer people who are paying tax today.

We need only look at some of the examples that are so often reported in the press. Take an incident in Kalgoorlie last June. There was a report of a 67-year-old lady who had to wait three months for heart surgery at the Royal Perth Hospital. There is no need to say that that dear old lady had been diagnosed in November and died on 13 February, just before the operation was due. That is what I mean when I talk about people dying at the end of the queue.

Senator West is now trying to justify that position as well. The great tragedy of it is that this Government will continue to try to justify people dying on the queue instead of solving the problem and allowing people to gain access to either public or private hospitals. Sadly, that is how some Australians, such as the 67-year-old lady, move from waiting lists. It is not the fault of the hospitals; it comes squarely back to the health system.
