Unfortunately, until this Government realises that there is such a problem, it will not do something about it.

A 68-year-old war service pensioner was told in February 1991 that he would have to wait a couple of months for a hernia operation. Late in June 1992 he was still waiting, having had a booking cancelled in May. Again, it is not the hospital that is to blame for having to give priority to more urgent cases. The examples continue.

In February, a woman was put on a waiting list for sinus surgery and told it would take two and a half years unless she paid $1,400 for private treatment. This is the choice that people are being confronted with. An 84-year-old public patient, who had a cataract removed in 1989, needed further treatment. He was told that he must wait 12 months. His family was then told by the specialist that, at his age, it was not worth it. I might add that he found the money for private treatment. But he was told that it was not worth it; that he may as well just go blind and let his quality of life deteriorate. It is a pretty sad reflection on our health system that we are prepared to allow people, because of their age, to go blind. That should not be permitted.

A woman was forced to wait six months for surgery on her achilles tendon. She was then told that she would have to wait a further six months but got treatment a month after this when her right tendon ruptured. She had to wait for emergency treatment. She could not get the treatment there and then on the spot. Only as an emergency patient was she eventually admitted.

A pensioner couple are trying to pay $10,000 in instalments for emergency hip surgery in a private hospital after failing to meet the membership criteria of Medibank Private. Where does this end? I can go on with story after story of all these people that this Labor Government is consistently locking out from access to public hospitals. Because of its ideological bent that it will not encourage private health insurance, the problem will not be resolved.

Other Australians such as those whom I have mentioned will be faced with similar pain because this Labor Government simply refuses to face the facts and encourage private insurance. The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) did not heed the plea from the Hospitals Benefits Fund managing director, Ray Walker, that privately insured Australians, such as the 560,000 covered by HBF, be exempted from the Medicare levy increase. He would not even consider any change. The Minister could not care less that, of the 826,000 Australians over 65, 42 per cent of that age bracket are still finding the money for private insurance.

If private health insurance is that crook, why do so many people want it? Why do so many aged people want private insurance? The Minister has also not taken any notice of the plea made on 28 May by the health Minister of the Western Australian Government, Mr Wilson, to whom I referred earlier, that more affluent Australians be penalised if they do not take private insurance and that a tax concession be given for self-provision. The Minister would not listen to Mr Wilson. Mr Wilson knows too much about the story; he is seeing it at the coalface. But somehow or other the key decision makers in this Labor Government do not wish to see it at the coalface or accept the realities.

Mr Wilson, in saying what he is, is arguing for the main principles of what we are suggesting in Fightback, with the support of the health professionals. But he commits the heresy of supporting the private sector, so he will be ignored and, no doubt, quietly removed from the health portfolio if the opportunity ever arises. I do not expect that Labor will get re-elected in Western Australia, but if there were a way of shifting Mr Wilson out of the portfolio today, it would certainly do it.

How serious about health care is this Labor Government when in June it could find $150,000 for the Osborne Park hospital in Perth for a new birthing unit while depriving the same hospital $80,000 for its family medicine program, which trains doctors who care for 40 women and babies each week? It may be because the Osborne Park hospital just happens to be in the most marginal Labor seat that the Labor Party currently holds—the seat of Stirling.

Yet again, a little funding fiasco is going on with the Osborne Park hospital in the same way that funding went to the Stirling City Council through the Budget. Is it not interesting that all these little funding deals come about in such a way? Of course, Mr Edwards will not need to worry about his seat of Stirling, because the endorsed Liberal candidate, Mr Eoin Cameron, will absolutely romp it in at the next election. He understands the problems of Stirling. He understands that there are people who need hospital treatment and that just switching dollars for dollars does not make any sense. Therefore, the current situation will all come to a halt.

We get bandaids on buckets all the time. Royal Perth Hospital, probably the major hospital in Perth, like all WA public hospitals is faced with a 20 per cent fall in Federal funding since Medicare and must institute low activity days every fourth Friday when the theatres are shut down and more people are denied the treatment they need. Low activity days in a public hospital!

I read last week where another public hospital is looking at cutting out the low activity days because it is putting extra pressure on its other services on other days. But this Government is prepared to stand by and let these low activity days continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, we are not, no way.

—Isn't that interesting. The Minister at the table, the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, is saying, `No, we are not'. But these low activity days have been going on ad infinitum. He knows what sort of an impact they have been having on the waiting lists. He knows how many people knock on the front door of a public hospital only to have someone from inside say to them, `Sorry, pal, no bed. Go home'. We still have hospitals in Australia with low activity days, and that is just extraordinary.

PARA.TAB: Nothing will stop these appalling pressures on public hospitals when, during the last year, private cover declined from 44.4 per cent to 41.9 per cent, thus adding $128m to State hospital costs. There is a further decline year after year. More and more people are pulling out of private health insurance and this Government does not care. It provides no incentive for people to privately insure. It ensures that people keep on queuing at the public hospitals.

Earlier in the life of Medicare, declining membership came mainly from those in the lowest table who lacked private hospital cover. Since December 1990, however, private hospital cover has fallen from 39.3 per cent to 37.5 per cent. Some 530,000 more Australians came to rely on Medicare, two-thirds of them as a result of the decline in private cover. Does the Minister care that public hospitals had to pay an extra $233m? It appears not, because nothing has been done to reverse the trends. These trends have not just been here since the depression that we are now in—not a recession, but a depression—and they have been consistently going down and down through the life of Medicare.

Premiums for private cover rose by 14.5 per cent on average between 1985 and 1991 and subsequently are now up 20 per cent. This can only mean that more Australians are adding to the Medicare queues. If we get more people back into the private hospital system and the private health insurance system, the overall cost will be spread across more people. But does the Government want to do that? No way. It still wants people to be reliant on Medicare. Private funds will be faced with more losses, leading to higher premiums, unless the situation is reversed. Yet this Government still refuses to reverse the situation.

In 1991 theatre benefit costs for over 65s rose 40 per cent and benefits payments for prostheses rose by 34 per cent. This Labor Government does not appear to care and will do nothing for these Australians earning less than $31,000 who comprise 40 per cent of those privately insured. Yet this is the Government that says it cares about the sick and those who need help.

In Fightback! the Liberal and National parties are talking about a dramatic contrast to what this Government has been doing. Fightback! gives rebates for private insurance to all Australian families with incomes below $30,000. That contrast could not be more obvious than when measured against what this Government is doing. The Government is squeezing out low income people because they cannot take out private health insurance without extreme hardship. Once again, Labor gives us its unique version of social justice by encouraging 30 per cent of Australians earning more than $41,600 and 20 per cent of those earning over $52,000 to remain uninsured.

This Labor Government continues in its contemptuous treatment of health professionals by its impositions on pharmacists, forcing them to police the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, so that after one warning regarding incorrect numbers the liability falls on the pharmacists. I cannot understand this Government. I have been here for a number of years and I have watched all this legislation go through. If the Government is not trying to pick off the specialists, it is trying to pick off the GPs. If it is not trying to pick off the GPs, it is trying to pick off the pharmacists. If it is not trying to pick off the pharmacists, it is trying to pick off the pathologists. Where does it end? Now the responsibility for government is going back on to those who deliver the services.

Pharmacists have pointed out to this Government that they have no defence against faulty counter cards used by the Department of Social Security, and that check digit routines in the software are simply not infallible, flagging correct numbers as wrong and unable to check DSS counter cards. The pharmacists have raised those issues with the Government and they are particularly concerned about them because the buck stops with them. As our amendment states, the Government is passing the buck to pharmacists for fraud by individuals under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. I wish the pharmacists well in their Federal Court hearing on 6 November.

Given the past performance of this Government, we can doubt whether the new system will save the projected $8.5m in a full year. This Labor Government has failed to prevent non-Australians from obtaining pharmaceuticals under the PBS. Labor has failed the people of my State of Western Australia miserably. I have been talking about this for years and years and still nothing has changed. Even their own Labor State Minister has been talking for a considerable length of time about how this Labor Federal Government continues to fail Western Australia, yet nothing has changed. Of course, it is not just peculiar to Western Australia; it is a problem that is Australia-wide. The only reason that one can give is this Government's blind maladministration of health care. Ultimately it will continue to defend the system at the cost and at the pain and hardship of ordinary Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to support the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill and the cognate measure that are before the Senate this evening because they deal with some important matters.

PARA.TAB: Before I go into the detail of that particular legislative package which the Senate is considering, I thought it might be useful to agree with Senator Knowles. I agree that there is a vast difference between the Opposition and the Labor Party in respect of the way in which medical and hospital care is to be provided for Australians into the next decade and the next century. That is basically because the Opposition is obsessed with the idea of Medicare as part of its original impetus as a way in which to finance the health system, rather than the more expansive orientation which is part of the approach under the new Medicare agreement being sponsored by the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, Mr Brian Howe. What we are concerned with in Medicare, revamped, is a comprehensive health care approach which will enable Australians to have access to affordable health care.

In so far as Senator Knowles in her emphasis on the financing aspects referred to private health insurance as the way in which dollars ought to be taken from individuals and householders in Australia to upgrade the health system, as she would put it, she castigated the Minister for rejecting a proposal from the private health insurance industry that those who pay private health insurance premiums should be exempted from the Medicare levy.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I did not.
—I thought Senator Knowles castigated the Minister. She said that he ignored and rejected that particular proposal.
—He won't look at any proposal to try to help people, including that one.

—Senator Knowles mentioned that proposal specifically. As far as the Opposition is concerned, am I not correct in saying that not only will it not exempt a person who pays private health insurance from the Medicare levy, but that it will require people to pay both? Under Opposition policy a person will finance the health system both by general taxation plus the Medicare levy, plus private insurance premiums. Senator Knowles would have rejected that particular proposal herself, but I am sure her Opposition spokesman on health has already indicated that there will be no diminution from or alleviation of the Medicare levy by those who take out a private health insurance premium.
—Under our policy they get assistance; under yours they get nothing.

—As to Senator Knowles's new point that she is making now—that the Opposition will subsidise the private health insurance premiums for certain categories of income earners—where is the subsidy to come from? Obviously the hundreds of millions of dollars that will be required will be found by the Opposition not funding the public hospital system. For example, it is cutting grants to the States by 5 per cent. That must have an impact on the ability of the States to fund the public hospital system in their various jurisdictions. That is very obvious.

PARA.TAB: Of course, the Opposition can in no way match the Federal Government's proposition that $1.6 billion be made available to the public hospital system over the next six years for those States which enter into the new Medicare agreement. I was going to say it was generous, but it is simply just and proper that that sort of expenditure be undertaken by the Federal Labor Government in support of the public hospital system which is properly lauded by all Australians. I was at the Royal Hobart Hospital only last week opening the hyperbaric chamber, which deals with treatment of the bends and, more recently with innovations in medical knowledge, with the better healing of wounds such as burns and so on. It is a very big project at our leading public and teaching hospital in Hobart. I am quite sure that that hospital will benefit greatly from the increased expenditure under the proposed Medicare agreement that will go into the support of those public hospitals. Not only will that expenditure go into the public hospitals generally, but it will go into a special program of moneys—I think it is $71m over the next two years—that will be devoted to a reduction in waiting lists.

I very much hope that the Western Australian Government has been able to agree—as I understand from talking to the Minister for Health, Mr Howe—to an assent to the Medicare agreement, perhaps modified a little to deal with the particular requirements of Western Australia, but in a way which will now allow that money to flow to reduce waiting lists in Western Australia. That must be extremely gratifying. I certainly hope it reduces the suffering of those who have a clinical need for treatment and who have found themselves not able to get the prompt and ready access to public hospitals which they would wish and which their medical advisers would wish for them.

They are just general remarks in support of the proposition put so well by Senator Knowles that there is a vast gulf between the approach of the Federal Government and the Federal Opposition to these matters. We are certainly not in favour of the private health insurance approach which is that it will be compulsory for every Australian to take out private health insurance. We know that the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, has gone to an AMA meeting and spoken in terms of the AMA being able to set the fees for treatment, for example, by a GP. We know that what the Opposition has in mind is that market forces should operate and the insurance system should match up to whatever the market happens to be charging, even though the Opposition leaves some sort of gap, as I recall. But I think this idea that the private health insurance premium should be compulsorily required of every Australian, in addition to their taxation contribution and their Medicare levy contribution, is something which I am sure will be rejected by the Australian people.

Honourable senators will be aware that we are discussing two Bills. The first is simply called the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill 1992. It covers matters which appear to be minor and procedural, but I am sure it will have a profound impact on the better provision of hospital treatment, for example, for Australians.

Honourable senators will know that it has certainly been an aim of the medical profession, and even private health insurance funds and governments, to encourage a move towards day surgery and day-only procedures which are consistent with modern medical practice and which allow the patient to return home on the same day as treatment. Terms have been used and definitions employed in various statutes which have provided something of an incentive for hospitals and so on to think about the need to occupy a bed for private health insurance benefit purposes. We want to reduce the financial incentive for patients to be admitted overnight and to try to encourage the move towards day surgery and day-only procedures—as I say, where they are consistent with best medical practice and the clinical needs of the person concerned. That is achieved by various changes in definition, nomenclature, in this Bill.

There will also be matters to do with tightening up of those procedures where persons who are entitled to concessional benefits attend a pharmacy and the local pharmacist has to be satisfied as to the identity of the person concerned in order to ensure that the person is truly entitled to concessional treatment. For example, as we all know, the difference can be many dollars for the person concerned—perhaps $2.60 versus up to $15.70, which can apply to those who pay the ordinary rate at the time of dispensing. That has to be better regulated and is provided for in this Bill.

The other important Bill is the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). Even in that slight distinction—(No. 2)—one can tell that it deals with an entirely different subject matter. Principally, it is to do with the way in which the Government relates to the carers, particularly of frail, older people in our community. These people are remarkable. I had the great privilege of meeting with the home and community care networks in the midlands of Tasmania both at Campbelltown and at Oatlands in recent weeks where I had some insight into the way in which care is organised through the various mobile teams and those very compassionate, but practical, people in the community—generally women, I have to say, Madam Acting Deputy President—who provide tremendous service for those who are frail, elderly, housebound or maybe disabled in one way or another and who would otherwise be required to take up residence in a nursing home or some other institution.

It has been very gratifying to meet such big hearted Australians as those whom I met at that time, and, again, in Hobart at a meeting of carers, in the sense of those who are perhaps spouses, children or parents of those who have suffered some traumatic accident or some chronic illness and who need treatment. Of course, once again, compassion and the loving instincts of the carers concerned mean that they take on the burden of care of those family members usually within their own household, at tremendous cost to their own health, to their social activity and so on.

So not only does this Bill recognise the tremendous role that such carers play by increasing, in a minor way, the sort of financial support that they are entitled to, but there is the recognition that they should continue to receive the benefit during respite care of up to 42 days a year. The recognition of the need for such respite periods, if they are able to take them, is an important part of this Bill. Once again, I think that the matter of respite care available to carers, as much as to those for whom they care, is very major and is one that this community does have to address.

I could take the Senate through a further review of nursing home and hostel matters, but I think that that would possibly be repeating matters which are well known to honourable senators, and, therefore, perhaps would not add to the sum of knowledge which has been fully committed to the Hansard by contributions from such people as Senator Patterson, Senator Lees and Senator West already during the course of this debate. In regard to Senator Patterson's amendment, I move:
That, on the second line of the motion that has been moved by Senator Patterson, the word `both' be inserted between `ensure' and `that'.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the changes in the Bill removes the need to occupy a bed for private health insurance benefits purposes. In other words, it deals with day visits to clinics, hospitals and so on. What is the clinical procedure for surgery that is most likely to be affected by this particular measure? In other words, what is the procedure that would currently require a patient to occupy a bed which, under this provision, would no longer require that patient to so occupy a bed? What types of surgery are we talking about?

—I think I mentioned in my response to the second reading debate that this measure is not concerned with dealing with matters which in the opinion of the medical advisers to a patient properly require an overnight stay. That is the point. At the moment there are definitions which could provide an incentive to encourage a person to stay overnight in a hospital in order for the hospital to get the full benefit of the private health insurance payments. The definitions are being altered to make sure that there is no artificial incentive of that kind and that if, in the clinical judgment of the medical practitioners or advisers to the person, a procedure could be carried out quite adequately within the course of a three-, four- or five-hour visit to the hospital, that ought to be undertaken.

PARA.TAB: As I say, the measure is simply intended to remove the definitional matter which has proved to be an incentive, or a temptation perhaps, for an overnight stay where it is not required.

TALK.START.PARA: —So this does not relate to the amount that a patient can obtain from private health insurance but to an amount which the hospital or clinic would be paid by the private health insurance fund?

—I think we have to be a little careful. What normally happens is that the patient assigns the payment of the benefit to the hospital, so in either case, I suppose, the hospital is the end beneficiary of the payment. Of course, a lower payment will be made to the hospital or clinic concerned for a confined three- or four-hour visit and procedure undertaken in a hospital than would be the case if there was an overnight stay. This is simply to remove that temptation to encourage the patient to stay overnight, which might be an artificial and unneeded stay in the hospital, which could, of course, earn more money for the hospital. We do not want to put that temptation in the way of the hospital concerned.
—What effect will this measure have on the provisions and payments that currently apply in respect of private abortion clinics?

—I am advised that they are treated as day surgeries rather than specifically as abortion clinics and, in so far as they are day surgeries, the lower benefit is payable for what I am advised is the usual situation where the woman concerned is not in there for a prolonged period requiring an overnight stay. So this particular provision, in so far as it is designed to remove that temptation for a clinic or hospital to encourage a patient to stay overnight, will not have much impact on that sort of day surgery, matter of course procedure.

—Does the effect of this particular measure require private health insurance funds to pay moneys in respect of the actual stay of the individual in the particular abortion clinic—or does it not have any effect at all?

—I am not too au fait with this matter, but I understand that a facility benefit is paid in addition to or after the payment of the Medicare schedule benefit for the actual medical procedure. So to that extent there is a payment made to the clinic or day surgery facility.

—I would like to get clarification of the Minister's answer. He mentioned that `facility'. Does that facility now exist? In other words, is it the case that this Bill is not altering one way or the other the situation that now exists?
—I am advised that it does not alter the situation; it just removes that temptation of an overnight stay which attracts a higher benefit.

DEBATE.TITLE: BROADCASTING SERVICES (SUBSCRIPTION TELEVISION BROADCASTING) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Collins) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to amend the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 to include provisions relating to subscription television broadcasting services.
Motion (by Senator Collins) agreed to:
That the following Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill reintroduces Part 7 of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992—the provisions to licence Subscription Television Broadcasting Services, or Pay TV.
As we are all aware this section was removed from the original Bill by the Opposition parties in this chamber four months ago.
I expressed dismay at the time that Pay TV may never again emerge from the "black hole" of the Senate Committee system to which it was referred.
However, the Committee acted expeditiously to complete its hearings and bring down its Report which was tabled in this Chamber on September 16.
I thank Senator Chris Schacht for his efforts as Chair of the Committee.
The Committee sought to resolve two major issues: how and when Pay TV service licences would be issued; and how best the ABC could participate in the industry.
Despite its best endeavours the Committee did not provide the Government with a ready solution to the impasse on Pay TV. I did not expect it would.
The debate has moved on even since the Committee tabled its report.
Optus recently advised the Government it now intends to move to digital transmission as soon as the technology is available. It proposes to sell channels not transponders.
Most potential bidders for a licence have also informed the Government they will wait for digital technology on satellites before starting services.
The Government therefore proposes to mandate the use of digital technology for Pay TV using Optus satellites.
Opting for digital satellite systems will place Australia at the forefront of world developments in direct-to-home satellite broadcasting technology.
Current licence conditions on Optus only require it to make available 6 channels for Pay TV until mid-1994.
Optus has agreed to provide satellite capacity for up to 10 Pay TV program services until 1 July 1997.

To allocate this capacity equitably, and recognising the commercial requirements of this new industry, the Government intends to issue two commercial licences A and B to provide up to four Pay TV program channels on the Optus satellite.
These will be issued simultaneously using a price-based allocation system under the provisions at section 93.
The choice of the digital system will be a joint decision by licensees A and B in consultation with Optus.

It is important that this decision is left to the commercial judgement of the operators because of the significant cost involved in the reception technology and the extent to which it can be adapted to meet licensee needs (eg pay-per-view, interactivity).
The system chosen will be used by, and accessible to, all satellite Pay TV service providers.
The chosen system will then be set as a standard by the Minister for Transport and Communications under section 94(1).
Any disagreement will be arbitrated by the Minister.
No further satellite Pay TV licences, other than that for the ABC which I will outline in a moment, will be sold before July 1 1997.
Hence section 96(3) states that the Australian Broadcasting Authority must not, before that date, allocate a satellite licence.
Satellite Pay TV licences issued after that date will be allocated under the provisions of section 96 for single program services, with the Trade Practices Act operating to govern ownership limits.
It is important to note there will be no restriction on the use of other technologies to deliver Pay TV such as cable or microwave (MDS).
They will be licensed under section 96.
These will be vetted by the Trade Practices Commission under section 97 before licences are issued to ensure competition policy objectives are met.
I now wish to turn to the role of the ABC in the proposed Pay TV industry.
The Government has always sought to have the ABC participate in a sensible, commercial manner with three vitally important caveats.
.the ABC's core free to air TV services suffer no detriment.
.the tax payer not be exposed to any financial risk from ABC involvement.
.the ABC board accept responsibility for the extent of the national broadcaster's involvement, given their fiduciary duties.
This Bill provides at section 93(2) that a third licence—licence C—to provide up to 2 Pay TV services be allocated to a subsidiary of the ABC.
The Government will maintain its earlier commitment to give the ABC $12.5m in seed finance.

The extent to which the ABC participates in Pay TV, forms commercial relationships with licensee A and/or B and other subscription service providers, and the nature and extent of programming will be left to the discretion of the ABC Board.
To minimise the risk to the Commonwealth from the ABC's involvement the Government will use ministerial powers to set licence conditions under section 93(3) to require it:
.to operate its Pay TV services through a subsidiary company with a separate board;
.to require that borrowings of its subsidiary over $2m are guaranteed only with ministerial approval;
.to require that an approved charging regime be developed for use of ABC assets and for goods and services provided to its subsidiary; and
.to require that an accounting regime on a fully attributed cost basis be developed that fully brings to account profits and losses.
Cross-media ownership limits will apply to licence A at sections 106 to 108 of the Bill.
These will prevent control and allow a maximum of 2% equity for commercial television broadcasters, large circulation newspapers and the telecommunications carriers.
These provisions facilitate diversity in media ownership by allowing at least one new player in Australia's media.
The Government is confident there will be a number of bidders for this licence.
No ownership and control restrictions will be applied to newspapers, incumbent commercial television licensees and telecommunications carriers participating in licence B.
This is to offset the special treatment given to the ABC and to allow the structural adjustment of the incumbent commercial television licensees to the new medium.
The Government does not intend to place a legislative straitjacket on the ABC.

Either or both licensee A and B can participate with the ABC in licence C subject to any conditions specified by the Minister for Transport and Communications and the provisions of the Trade Practices Act.
However, I do intend to set a condition under my powers at section 93(3) that the ABC must retain a majority equity holding in its licence at all times.
Section 110 provides that neither licensee A nor licensee B can control or hold more than 2% equity in each other.
The 2% limit minimises the opportunity to manipulate the ownership limits as a defence against hostile takeovers.
It does not penalise business where a small parcel of shares is acquired inadvertently.

Foreign ownership limits at section 109 are to be the same as those proposed earlier—that is, no more than 20% individual and 35% aggregate foreign holdings in any subscription television broadcasting licence, not just the satellite licences.
The Government considers that the Senate Committee's recommendation to increase program expenditure on Australian drama content on all predominantly drama channels to 15% is unrealistic.
Section 102 confirms our earlier decision by placing a 10% program expenditure requirement on satellite drama services.
This Bill places several imposts on the new industry that will add to the cost of Pay TV.
It will take some years before Pay TV services reach break-even.
To impose further expenditure requirements on them could threaten their commercial viability.
Opportunities for Australian production are enhanced under this model.
There are more channels available and 3 licences in the market from day one.
Australian content requirements will also be reviewed in line with provisions at section 215(b) of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992.
The special broadcasting service can choose to participate in Pay TV.
It could do this by being a provider of programs to Pay TV operators or by participating in commercial arrangements for the provision of satellite and other subscription services.
As with the ABC, any participation by the SBS in commercial Pay TV will be subject to conditions to protect SBS' free to air services.
The introduction of Pay TV and the mandating of digital technology presents exciting opportunities for Australian industry.
This legislation allows licence conditions to be imposed to ensure that licensees A and B put in place adequate Australian industry development arrangements.
The details are to be worked out by myself and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce.
As we settle these details an important focus will be on the employment opportunities provided by this new industry.
We recognise that industry development requirements should not be imposed in a heavy handed way.
However, minimum requirements will be that licensees A and B will need to select consumer reception equipment that is available for manufacture under licence in Australia.
A specific licence condition banning advertisements until 1997 is at section 101 of the Bill.

The ban on `X' rated programs and restrictions on `R' material already incorporated in Schedule 2 of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 have been retained for all subscription television broadcasting services.
Pay TV needs costly and sophisticated central subscriber data bases, control systems and technology to turn subscribers "on" and "off" and to bill them.

All licensees are free to operate their own subscriber management systems but will be required by a licence condition set under the powers at section 100(3)(b) to provide access for other operators to their systems at a fair price.

Section 116A allows use of additional satellite capacity so that Pay TV coverage can reach areas where direct reception of the Optus high performance beams is impractical. This provision will allow satellite Pay TV licensees to make use of other beams or technologies without requiring separate licences.
The Bill recognises that satellite is the only technology that is readily accessible now to most Australians to receive Pay TV services.

As set out in s.132 of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992, the sole means of delivering Pay TV by satellite is through use of Optus' satellites until 1 July 1997. After that date, other suitable satellite capacity could be used by Pay TV operators.

Providing this degree of protection during a time when further satellite capacity is likely to become available in our region and mandating the use of digital compression technology for the delivery of satellite Pay TV offers significant commercial advantages to Optus.

The Optus "monopoly" extends only to the provision of its satellite based facility. The Government requires assurance from Optus that the use of compressed digital technology for Pay TV will not require that the remote services using Optus satellites be converted to digital transmission, nor that there will be flow-on pricing increases for those remote service providers' use of satellites.
Section 115 and a licence condition at Part 6 of Schedule 2 of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 prevent the siphoning from free-to-air television of events listed by the Minister.
Mr President, I would like to make a few points in conclusion.
A regulatory regime for Pay TV in Australia has been 15 years in the making.
The Government has responded in a responsible way to what the Senate has asked for in its Committee report.
The government was asked to mandate one channel for the ABC—this legislation gives them two.
We have given them funding and allowed them maximum flexibility within the system.

I would remind senators that the original ABC galaxy model involved the national broadcaster entering a consortium as a minority partner with no money, trading their programming for equity, and competing for a licence in the price-based allocation process.
They now have their programming, $12.5 million of public money, and two assured channels on the satellite.
This is a rational and responsible proposal for the introduction of Pay Television into Australia and I commend this Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum to the Bill

SPEECH.PARA: The Banking Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 amends the Banking Act 1959, the Commonwealth Banks Act 1959 and the Reserve Bank Act 1959 for several purposes, mainly to give effect to policy measures previously announced by the Government.

First, the Bill amends the Banking Act 1959 to put into effect the Government's policy to liberalise foreign bank entry, which was announced in the One Nation Statement on 26 February 1992. The amendments enable foreign banks, whether they have been operating in Australia or not, to apply for a banking authority under section 9 of the Banking Act 1959.

The Government has decided to permit the issue of banking authorities to foreign-owned banks, where the Reserve Bank is satisfied that the bank and its home supervisor are of sufficient standing, and where the bank agrees to comply with Reserve Bank prudential supervision arrangements. This measure is in line with the Government's commitment to opening up the economy. It will bring benefits of competition in the domestic banking system and improve its international competitiveness.

Second, the Bill amends the Banking Act 1959 to permit foreign banks, which are authorised under the Banking Act, to operate as wholesale banks in the form of a branch. Under the current supervisory arrangements, foreign banks are required to be incorporated locally as subsidiaries of the parent bank.

A branch of a foreign bank cannot be subject to the same degree of prudential supervision and depositor protection as can be applied to a subsidiary. The Government places great importance on protecting the interests of depositors via the prudential supervision of the Reserve Bank. For this reason, the Government has decided to confine foreign bank branches to wholesale banking. If a foreign bank wishes to conduct retail banking in Australia, it must continue to be incorporated locally as a subsidiary.

The Government believes that this amendment should bring competitive gains and efficiencies, greater flexibility in the provision of finance, and cost advantages to Australian clients. It should also bring advantages to banks and improve the international competitiveness of the Australian financial system.

Third, the Bill amends the Banking Act 1959 to make it clear that depositors with foreign bank branches are not subject to the depositor protection provisions of the Banking Act. The Bill also provides that foreign bank branches will be required to disclose that they are not subject to the depositor protection provisions of the Banking Act. In addition, if foreign banks do not comply with conditions of their banking authorities, or requirements of the legislation, their banking authorities may be revoked.

Fourth, the Bill amends the Banking Act 1959 to complement New South Wales legislation which will enable the State Bank of New South Wales to apply for a banking authority under the Banking Act. The Government has agreed to a request from the New South Wales Government that the State refer its banking powers in this regard to the Commonwealth. The State Bank of New South Wales has indicated that it intends to apply for an authority as soon as the New South Wales legislation is enacted. As an authorised bank under the Banking Act, it will be on the same footing as other authorised banks and subject to the supervisory requirements of the Reserve Bank.

Fifth, the Bill amends the Banking Act 1959 to make several minor amendments with respect to unclaimed moneys in bank accounts, and to revoke the banking authority of the Australian Resources Development Bank (ARDB). The few remaining deposit liabilities of ARDB will be transferred to the National Australia Bank Limited, which currently owns all the shares in ARDB.

Sixth, Part 3 of the Bill provides for the amendment of section 32 of the Commonwealth Banks Act 1959 to streamline the process of declaring dividends, by enabling the Board of the Commonwealth Bank to declare dividends without seeking shareholder approval at a general meeting. This is consistent with the practice of other major banks. The Treasurer will continue to approve the amount of the Commonwealth Bank's dividend payments.

Finally, Part 4 of the Bill amends the Reserve Bank Act 1959 to provide for the creation of a second Deputy Governor position in the Reserve Bank. This will assist the Reserve Bank's prudential supervision of the banking system and is consistent with a recommendation of the Parliamentary Inquiry into Banking. The second Deputy Governor will also participate in the management of the Reserve Bank and will be a member of the Reserve Bank Board.
Mr President, I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.
