TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the adjournment debate to express some concern about a matter which came before the chamber today. I understand that Senator Spindler tabled reports of the inquiry entitled `Parliamentary Inquiry into Tariffs and Industry Development'. This matter and the activities of Senator Spindler in relation to this inquiry had been brought to my attention and a constituent sent me a copy of the Warrnambool Standard which some weeks earlier had headlined a story, `Parliament's tariff probe starts in Warrnambool'.

PARA.TAB: Being a member of the Senate and a member of the Parliament, I was intrigued that there was apparently a parliamentary inquiry looking into tariffs. My memory was there was no such parliamentary inquiry into tariffs at all. On further inquiry, the information I received confirmed my original view and the view expressed by a constituent that there was no such parliamentary inquiry.

When Senator Spindler tabled these reports today on this so-called parliamentary inquiry, I thought it was worthy of a closer look to see what issue and matters were raised by them. This is not a parliamentary inquiry. This is not an inquiry launched by this Parliament, voted on and agreed to by this Parliament. This is a private inquiry that Senator Spindler has launched. Senator Spindler is no doubt perfectly entitled to launch any private inquiry he wants. He is perfectly entitled to go around the country seeking the views of people about issues and he is perfectly entitled to seek the views of industry and union groups.

No-one has any argument on that, but it is not a parliamentary inquiry. As I said, Senator Spindler is free to call it what he likes, but to call it a parliamentary inquiry is to give his particular political activities a status that they do not legally have and that they should not have. For Senator Spindler to try to clothe his political activities in the garments and the prestige of this Parliament is quite wrong, in my view, and it is important that this be brought to the attention of this Parliament. Many people undoubtedly came before this so-called inquiry and, judging from this report that Senator Spindler has tabled, a number of industry groups came before it. I would hate to think that they felt this was a parliamentary inquiry. I understand the inquiry has two members: Senator Spindler and Mr Phil Cleary, MP, the honourable member for Wills. The secretary of the inquiry is Ms Lesley Vick. I happen to know Ms Vick.

TALK.START.PARA: —A former staffer.

—She is a former staffer of the Democrats, as Senator Knowles points out. I am sure she is a most worthy person, but she is not a person employed or paid for by the Parliament. Senator Spindler belongs to a party that used to have the slogan `Keeping the bastards honest'. I would have thought that a man who runs on that sort of slogan would have been far more cautious about trying to fool people on the nature and status of this inquiry. I regard this as quite a serious matter.

PARA.TAB: My understanding is that Senator Spindler is perfectly entitled to call his inquiries what he likes. But, in my view, we have here an attempt to fool people, an attempt to clothe his inquiries with the prestige and standing of this Parliament. I believe that what Senator Spindler has done is quite wrong. He has done a disservice to this Parliament and to his own party by pretending to give this inquiry a status which it did not have. Worst of all, he has done a great disservice to the people who came before this inquiry who may well have felt that the submissions that they made had some particular standing because they went before this inquiry but, as I have pointed out, it does not have that standing.

Senator Spindler's behaviour in this matter is quite serious. It is important that I bring this to the attention of this chamber. Whereas Senator Spindler will undoubtedly argue that he was free to call this inquiry what he wanted to, I believe that people who are concerned with giving a correct impression to others, people who are concerned about doing the right thing, not only by this Parliament, but also by the people who appear before the inquiry, would not have acted in the manner that Senator Spindler has acted.

I do not wish, at this stage, in view of the late hour, to comment on the substance of this report, although there are certainly a number of matters which I wish to raise. I say to Senator Spindler that if he is concerned about the status of industry in this country; if he is concerned in particular about the status of manufacturing industry, why would he adopt policies—which he has long advocated—of higher taxation on industry and the superannuation levy which adds to business costs? Also, he has voted consistently in this chamber for things such as the training guarantee levy which adds to business costs; he has supported the amalgamation of trade unions, which has been greatly opposed by all sections of industry in this country; he has proposed in his alternative budget—which he described as the alternative vision for Australia—a raft of taxes which totalled some $6.4 billion more than the taxpayer was currently paying. They included higher fuel taxes, transport taxes and energy taxes. All of these things have a direct impact on business costs. Let us face it: it is a stunt for Senator Spindler to go around pretending that he is concerned about business, about the capacity of business to compete, when he supports such policies.

I put it to you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that what we saw was a stunt. It was an inquiry, in my view, improperly named. Senator Spindler has for so long advocated higher taxes in this country and has opposed most of the major micro reforms in this country. I instance the need—to which even the Labor Party has woken up, albeit belatedly and altogether too slowly—for privatisation of government business activities. Senator Spindler has relentlessly opposed all of those micro reforms. It is absurd for Senator Spindler to have presented such a report to this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to address the issues of tariffs as they apply to the vehicle industry and add my direct call for the maintenance of a 15 per cent tariff rate until the year 2000. As a former secretary of the South Australian branch of the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation, I understand the importance of providing a good economic environment for manufacturing to exist in. It has been a long held view in South Australia, from all sides of politics, that government must provide tariff protection for vital industries.

PARA.TAB: In South Australia, the vehicle industry is vital. The major vehicle production plants make up only part of South Australia's reliance upon the overall industry. Vehicle component manufacturing industries are also significant to the growth of our economy. The policies of this Government are supportive of the restructuring of industry and increased productivity and flexibility in the workplace. Rather than being doctrinaire like the Opposition, the Government has endorsed the notion of a free market as important but not necessarily paramount.

The Australian alternative to conservative economic rationalism, experienced around the world in the 1980s, has been obvious through the maintenance of some key areas of protection. We recognise the need for an internationally competitive economy but we are not willing to compromise our basic belief in human dignity and social support.

Mr McLachlan, the Opposition industry spokesperson, brings with him many ideas which have already been tried in other economies and have failed. He also brings with him a number of other ideas that have not been tried because they would clearly be economically destructive. Zero tariffs in the vehicle industry is such a suicidal measure.

No-one can say that Labor has taken the easy decisions; we have reduced tariffs in the interests of greater competitiveness, but we will not destroy vital manufacturing and primary industries by cutting all protection out. The tariff debate has highlighted the great distinction between the Labor and non-Labor Parties today. As the Liberals and Nationals try to keep the dissension within their own ranks to a minimum, the conservative leadership is being shown for what it really is—out of touch with the Australian people and their needs.

As a senator representing the people of South Australia, it is my duty to stand up for the economic interests of my State. Not only will zero tariffs hurt South Australia, but the entire nation will lose out. Along with Victoria, we may rely on actual vehicle production, but there are many other workers and businesses that rely on the success of vehicle manufacturing and domestic car sales.

Tariffs are very important to the continued economic growth of South Australia. The problems that our State may have can only be exacerbated by the proposed reduction of tariffs to zero. I urge all other South Australian senators and members in another place to stand up for our manufacturing base and support the Government's position. Any South Australian who will not support the interests of fellow South Australians does not deserve to serve in this place. I would say that this goes for Victorians as well.

The Keating Government is totally committed to ensuring the viability of the Australian vehicle industry. By improving and enhancing the Button car plan, which directed vehicle industry policy in the 1980s, I know that we can see our vision become a reality. By the year 2000, we must have in place reasonable protection for the vehicle industry. The Labor Party is committed to a tariff level of 15 per cent, which is acceptable to the manufacturers and to workers.

The motor vehicle industry employs one-fifth of all the industrial workers in South Australia and around 15 per cent of the metropolitan work force. It is therefore imperative that this industry is given the opportunity to survive the latest round of conservative attacks. I have no problem with making industry more efficient. Indeed, I have been 100 per cent behind my Party's aims to do that over the past 10 years. What I cannot stomach is the assertion that by cutting protection to zero levels we will make the vehicle industry more efficient. There is a lot of difference between zero and 15 and I believe that it is the difference between having a car industry and losing it. Not only do I think this, but so do General Motors, Mitsubishi, Ford and Toyota; so do component manufacturers, car workers, their unions and business leaders; and, judging by the polls, so do the Australian people.

As a community, we must face a number of facts about the continued existence of a car industry. It is pretty obvious that there will never be an international free market as long as other countries continue to maintain protection for their industries. The Button car plan has been in existence since 1985. It has aimed to ensure that a strong local industry exists in the face of overseas opposition. It has been continually monitored and adjusted to meet the changes that have occurred in the economy and the industry itself.

Apart from the plan itself, there have been other complementary policies. For example, the recent decision to impose a $12,000 tariff upon second-hand imported vehicles was aimed at protecting the Australian market from dumping. The Industry Commission report of 1990-91 and the subsequent March 1991 economic statement pointed out the perceived need to reduce vehicle tariffs from 35 per cent to 15 per cent by the year 2000. Therefore, while this sector is the recipient of tariff protection, it will have to undergo major changes to maintain its current position. Already Nissan has decided to leave and there could be other casualties within the industry. However, the fact is that all remaining manufacturers are keen to make a go of it under the present arrangements. We just cannot change the rules and expect people still to invest.

The Button car plan is an indicator of the high motives of this Labor Government. It recognises the special needs of the vehicle sector and the role that it can and will play in the creation of the clever country. Its basic concept revolves around the fact that, if we want a vehicle industry, we have to ensure its survival. It accepts that we can produce a quality product; that we can benefit from the investment in technology and infrastructure; and that we can forge an export market for ourselves, as we are doing. As a major employer and trainer of Australian workers, the vehicle industry is a national treasure that must be preserved in the interests of Australian manufacturing and technology. The jobs in this sector require skills and commitment that can only benefit our economy. The national interest is best served as far as the car industry is concerned by the continuing involvement of government in the process of development and control of this sector.

I wish to be associated with my Caucus colleagues who several weeks ago in another place spoke in support of the South Australian vehicle industry. As well, I wish to convey my thanks and support to the vehicle industry unions who have also been the key to ensuring a viable and successful vehicle industry for Australia. I ask all Australians to examine carefully the proposals put forward by the Opposition. I know that if people recognise that the vehicle industry could disappear under the Liberals, they will not vote for them. This industry is very important to a great many Australians. I also know that, when examined, the GST and the Victorian model industrial relations policy supported by Dr Hewson will also be rejected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight on the adjournment, I rise to speak on Jobsback and to spell out a few things quite clearly to the people on the other side of this chamber, who have an enormous capacity to misrepresent the position of Jobsback and to then misinform the Australian public. Also, when commenting on that, one must take into account what Senator Foreman has just said, once again totally misleading this chamber and, of course, the Australian people with regard to the Opposition's position as far as the car industry is concerned. I throw this challenge down to Senator Foreman: if he is really serious about what he has just said, he will move immediately to convince his colleagues that the removal of payroll tax, wholesale sales tax and fuel excise and other initiatives in the Fightback package would not only keep the car industry in Australia but also enable it to grow and be far more healthy. However, that is not what I came in here to talk about.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday in the House of Representatives both Mr Keating, the Prime Minister, and Mr Willis, the Minister for Finance, in answering questions misrepresented the position which exists in Jobsback as far as minimum employment conditions are concerned. In a moment or two I will come to the detail of what they said yesterday. Also, in the debate on the urgency motion yesterday, Senator Childs misrepresented the position—and I did inform him I would be speaking on this matter tonight. Senator Childs said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the difference between their classification rate and the lowest base rate in the award is significant. It would be financially devastating for them. This is not worker friendly; there is no way it can be. For example, the minimum award rate for a metal industry trades person would fall from $417.20 per week, including supplementary payments, to $284.80 per week with no supplementary payments.

I want to make it quite clear that the minima, in fact, will be the classification rates. That is the position we had at the last election with our industrial relations policy. While there have been some changes in that policy, in this particular area there has been no change.

PARA.TAB: I would certainly give Senator Childs the benefit of the doubt and say that he genuinely misunderstood the position which existed. I certainly cannot give the same benefit of the doubt to either Mr Keating or Mr Willis as they consistently misrepresent policy positions of the coalition; they have become artists at doing so. I think it is quite tragic when they misrepresent the position, trying to shoot down what is a very good policy—one which will lead to productivity increases from which in turn will flow increases in real wages. As I said, I will give Senator Childs the benefit of the doubt. Nonetheless, he is totally wrong in what he said yesterday.

Just to put the record absolutely straight and to clear up a few points on this so that there is no more misrepresentation and misinterpretation, I want to go through a number of aspects of Jobsback. First, as to the transition process, there will be three groups of employees: those who along with their employers choose to remain within the award system—that is absolutely clear; those who agree with their employers to enter workplace agreements; and those whose award employment entitlements are converted to a workplace agreement. In each of these situations, the employees' legal entitlements are protected. Those remaining in the award system will retain their status quo; nothing will change. Workplace agreements by consent—that is, employees voluntarily entering into workplace agreements—are protected by the statutory minima. These are the minimum wage, annual leave, sick leave and maternity leave. In addition, they are guaranteed public holidays. Once again, this position was misrepresented in the other place yesterday. In most cases the minima will be irrelevant since employees would not consent to enter into a workplace agreement which did not improve their existing wages and conditions.

The minimum wage is the minimum hourly rate applicable to an employee according to the relevant award classification. As I have already said, that does not change the position that existed at the time of the last election. There was no intention to change it. Neither Dr Hewson nor Mr Howard—nor, for that matter, anybody else in the coalition—has said anything else. They have not indicated that it would change.

The minimum includes, as I have already said, any supplementary payments, but it excludes penalties, allowances and loadings. Those things will be negotiated between the parties—that is, the employer and the employees—either directly between themselves or with the respective representatives they wish to have. If the employer wishes to use its industrial or representative organisation, it may. Likewise, if employees wish to use a union, they may; or, alternatively, they can use anybody of their choosing to be the negotiator or negotiate themselves. I want to make these points absolutely crystal clear to those people on the other side of the chamber so that the nonsense that has been going on in this place over the last couple of days is corrected.

I now want to put on the public record exactly what the proposal is in terms of the national youth wage and to put to bed the lie that is being perpetuated by people on the other side of the chamber. Under the coalition's minimum youth wage, 15- to 17-year-olds can earn $120 a week; that is, $120 a week after tax because of the reform we are making to the taxation system. Senator Foreman could well have taken that into account in his comments when he spoke about the future of the car industry. The Government's minimum youth wage is $125 a week gross, and $120.77 after tax. So there is that huge difference of 77c in the net pay of people who fall into that 15- to 17-year-old group. Once again, that is the minimum. The coalition policy provides in addition a non-taxable training voucher worth $2,000 over two years, the equivalent of $19 a week. Recipients of this voucher can choose the type of training they take.

People on the other side of the chamber—it happened here again today at Question Time—say that we are not taking training into consideration and have made no provision for it. That is totally and utterly false.

For 18- to 20-year-olds, the coalition's minimum wage is $140 a week or $139.13 after tax. The Government's minimum is $150 a week or $140.77 after tax—almost the same. But once again, in addition to that, under the coalition's policy there is the $2,000 non-taxable training voucher over two years or the equivalent of $19 a week.

The claim made in the other place yesterday by Mr Willis that the coalition's youth wage represents an extraordinary loss of protection for adolescent employees is total nonsense. It is just false; it is not true and it should be corrected. Also, as I have already mentioned, there is a safety net with regard to public holidays.

I will now deal with the issue of casuals. Once again, it was Mr Willis who claimed yesterday that the average loading for casuals is 20 per cent. I must make the point here that we put in a minimum of 15 per cent for casuals. I must stress that that is a minimum, not an average. It is worth noting that, at this point in time, quite a number of awards do not have that 15 per cent loading over the minimum. That means that, in fact, under many awards casuals will be better off in terms of their minimum provisions.

The minimum applying to employees coming off the back of a certified agreement into a workplace agreement will be the minimum in the relevant award. Once again, that corrects the misrepresentation that has been echoed in this place and the other place. What has been said about the various minima is a total misrepresentation of the situation. It absolutely amazes me that people on the other side of the chamber continually claim they have shot holes in Jobsback. All I can say to them is that they have had to fabricate untruths to try to knock it out. Of course, in actual fact we have caught them totally off guard.
There were suggestions prior to the policy being released that we were going to scrub everything, that we were not going to have satisfactory safety nets in place—

TALK.START.PARA: —Aren't they disappointed.

—As Senator Knowles has quite rightly said, `Aren't they disappointed'. They have been caught totally off guard. The safety net is indeed significant. It is fair, it protects their position, yet at the same time it allows individuals, groups of employees or a whole workplace to make their own workplace arrangements above that minimum without interference from anybody if they so choose. In other words, it ends the dominance of big unions and coercion in the workplace in this country. That is something that is well overdue. But at the same time, it gives unions and those who want to perform the opportunity to perform, to get out there and, as I have already said publicly, to win their stripes by performance in the marketplace. The same also applies to employer organisations. They will have to win their stripes if employers are going to utilise their services in industrial matters.

PARA.TAB: I think it should be made very clear that this is not an anti-union policy; it is not an anti-employer policy. It is a policy that will ensure that those who win the competitive edge in the marketplace and look after their members are the ones that will survive and grow and that those who do not will fall by the wayside. That is how it should be.

There are two other points I want to raise. Once again, both of these caught the Government right off guard. The first one is the Office of the Employees' Advocate. The role of the Office of the Employees' Advocate will be to protect the interests of employees when in fact there has been a breach of contract by the employer. That service will be provided at no cost to the employee. If there is a dispute, for example, over payment, all that employee has to do is contact the Office of the Employees' Advocate and the matter will be dealt with. That, once again, caught this Government right off guard and left it wallowing.

The other matter relates to a breach of a workplace agreement by an employee. Employees can be fined a maximum of $5,000 under common law. It is a new thing in industrial relations in this nation. It applies only to the breach of that contract. It does not in any way reduce the powers of common law. It does not in any way reduce the powers of the Trade Practices Act. It does not in any way reduce the powers of the Crimes Act when in fact broader breaches occur or where blatant abuse of the law occurs. In that sense, it changes nothing that exists in law today, and nor should it.

In summarising my speech in the adjournment debate tonight, I emphasise once again that the Prime Minister got it wrong, Mr Willis got it wrong, Senator Childs got it wrong and, in a number of answers we have had to questions in this place from Senator Cook, he has also got it wrong. One must note when comparing our policy position to that of the failed accord of this Government that what has been delivered to the Australian work force over the years is a 2 per cent fall in real wages. That is what this Government has delivered to the Australian worker.

What our policy does is give people in the workplace real hope because they can be involved in meaningful arrangements in the workplace. It gives them real hope by giving them, together with their employers—whether they be large, medium or small—an opportunity to lift productivity and enjoy an increase in real wages.

If we do not lift productivity, there is no way that there will be an increase in real wages, unless the Government is prepared to sacrifice more people onto the dole queues or it is prepared to see more businesses go bankrupt. That is the sad history of this Government and that is what its policies have delivered. This Government has delivered one million unemployed people and an increase of 25 per cent over the last two years in the number of bankruptcies in this country. The number has gone up and up as each year has gone by and has exceeded record levels. As I have already said, this Government's failed policies have delivered a 2 per cent fall in real wages to workers or employees in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today in Question Time Senator Powell asked a question of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) and in part of that question she quoted from an article which she said appeared in the Melbourne Herald-Sun. I quote from Senator Powell's question where she said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . as Senator Bell has said, and I quote from the Melbourne Herald-Sun of 14 October, `the existing Government is not expected to be returned.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right.

—That may well be true and there may be some who have that expectation. However, nobody has been given an expression of opinion by me; nor has anybody whose opinion I respect said that to me and had that expectation. In fact, when I scoured the Melbourne Herald-Sun of 14 October, both the early and late editions, I was able to find on page 25 the place where I had been quoted.

PARA.TAB: For the benefit of the Senate I shall read part of the article by Andrew Butcher headed, `Parties plan to aid unions'. I will read the part of the article which is attributed to me and also the part which introduces that section. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Costello said. . . the Democrats had `taken up where the Socialist Left of the Labor Party left off'.
As a matter of fact, Andrew Butcher writes:
The Democrats this week set up a Senate Inquiry into Sections 45D and 45E of the Act, which deal with unions taking action against one company to put pressure on another.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats industrial relations spokesman, Senator Robert Bell, said yesterday the sections had `cast a shadow over industrial relations practice for 15 years'.
He said he wanted groups to have a chance to explain why they thought the sections should be maintained, changed or scrapped.

SPEECH.PARA: That ends the part of the article which can be attributed to me. There is no mention of any assessment I made about the Government or the election in the rest of that article. I seek leave to table the full article.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I believe the article was written with the benefit of a press release which I released from this place on 12 October. In fact, that press release contains the very words which Mr Butcher wrote. It contains several other paragraphs, none of which refer in any way to the words which have been attributed to me. In fact, the final paragraph is the only part which mentions the election, and it reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Bell said that the inquiry would become a vehicle for participants in the industrial relations debate to clearly enunciate their I.R. policies, before, during and perhaps even after the next federal election.
I seek leave to table my full press release.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the debate to refer this matter to the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, I also referred to the election debate. Of course, I referred to several other matters, but in Hansard there is a paragraph in which I do refer to the election. I said it in another context which is not worth exploring here. Honourable senators can take the time themselves to refer to Hansard if they are interested. But for the benefit of the Senate tonight I will quote from page 1601 of the Hansard of 12 October. In my speech I refer to why interested parties should take the trouble to present their case to the Committee and I state:

SPEECH.PARA: That is a responsibility which all parties affected by this legislation must recognise. It is a nonsense to suggest that they would shy away from putting that case. That case is public property and is in the forum of the election debate that will surely occur. That election debate will be running at the precise time that these positions will be being fully presented and, I suggest, will be anything but buried. I suggest that in fact it will be exposed to the fullest extent. To ignore the opportunity to expose this argument to the fullest extent possible will be at the peril of those groups, individuals and bodies that are at all affected by this issue.

That is the reference to the election that I made in the accompanying speech. If a newspaper anywhere has written that I said these words which have been attributed to me, I suggest it would be a misunderstanding of what I have said or written on this issue. I have not knowingly provided any journalist with information which could lead to that quote, unless I was misquoted, quoted out of context or completely misunderstood.

TALK.START.PARA: —I briefly wish to raise two very important issues. I was encouraged to raise the first matter as I listened with some interest to Senator Foreman's rather curious speech about the car industry in South Australia. If Senator Foreman genuinely believes what he says, why does he not stop any tariff reductions and move somewhere in this Parliament or in Caucus that there be no tariff reductions? If what he said in his rather interesting speech was correct, one wonders why he would support any tariff reductions at all. I inquire about that and invite him to elucidate at some time.

PARA.TAB: If Senator Foreman is genuinely concerned about the reduction, he might also indicate when he will get his Party and the current Government to introduce legislation to remove payroll tax, the training guarantee levy, petrol taxes and those sorts of things from the motor vehicle industry. If he were to do that, it would be a real boost to the motor vehicle industry and would certainly be a great incentive for it to continue in operation.

The other matter that I want to raise is the Government's proposal to extend the fringe benefits tax to car parking. I recently had the opportunity of visiting several local authorities in Victoria. I spoke with the City of Melbourne council and listened to its very great concern about the extension of the fringe benefits tax to include car parking. The extension of the fringe benefits tax to car parking will increase costs for businesses located in the central business district of Melbourne. This will have a real effect on that area in that it will further underutilise existing urban infrastructure in the central city areas, which is a real concern with public planning at present.

Further, the extension of the fringe benefits tax to car parking will impose significant compliance costs on many businesses throughout Australia. Employers will be required to maintain records of parking benefits provided and to calculate values and the tax payable on those values. FBT returns are due annually and employers must pay quarterly. Employers will need to keep records of car parking bays made available and their usage, which includes weekdays and weekends.

Employers will also have to keep records of the lowest fee charged by commercial parking stations within one kilometre of their parking facility. They will have to be involved in the reimbursement of parking expenses incurred by their employees. They will also have to keep records of whether the parking expenses qualify for any concessional treatment. So the compliance costs for business will be very significant.

The arbitrary one kilometre rule will also result in some suburban and fringe CBD businesses becoming liable for the FBT while some neighbouring competitors will not be liable. It will again create distortions. A number of people working in private hospitals, airports, schools and factories will have to pay the charge. This is considered very harsh. A number of night shift workers, who for security and safety reasons are provided with this facility, will be caught. There may be no negligible market rates for parking at night in contrast to daily rates.

The FBT on car parking is an impost which will predominantly hurt city businesses. In Melbourne at present, which is suffering from years of corrupt and inefficient Labor rule, $240m is already paid in property taxes by businesses in the central business district. Some taxes paid include the State Government land tax, Melbourne water rates, the Melbourne City Council rates, a special levy for commercial properties and for the underground rail loop. Most of that expenditure bears very little real relationship to the central city area. The FBT on car parking will add to this, increasing the level of imposts and reducing the viability of many CBD businesses.

The Federal Government claims that it will raise $120m from the introduction of the FBT. A third of this is likely to come from the CBD of Melbourne and the adjacent areas of south Carlton and South Melbourne. This will mean an extra burden of about $40m on city businesses on top of the $240m already levied. Quite simply, such an impost can be expected to have an impact on the decision by businesses to locate outside the CBD.

Mr Deputy President, your government professes to be putting major programs in place to stimulate economic growth, but the FBT on car parking will hinder rather than assist recovery. In fact, the weight of taxes in the CBD has been recognised. The City of Melbourne has reduced its commercial rates quite significantly by $15m, and there is pressure to reduce the State land tax. The Federal Government's decision to add costs to CBD businesses runs contrary to that approach and makes all the efforts of the Melbourne City Council to reduce costs quite illusory.

As I mentioned, the underutilisation of the inner city infrastructure is quite serious. The introduction of the fringe benefits tax will add to the already high volumes of vacant office space in the city. It will have the effect of undermining the work of city revitalisation, in which the City of Melbourne council has already been very heavily involved.

It will also create environmental problems in that there will be a decrease in public transport patronage. As businesses move out of the central business district into suburban areas—where public transport is not quite as good and where the suburban thoroughfares are not designed to handle that sort of traffic—there will be a greater increase in traffic via private cars. Some surveys show that it will lead to a substantial increase in the use of private cars.

Some survey work was done when Coles-Myer relocated out of the city area. It was found that there was an increase in private vehicle trips from 34 per cent to 76 per cent and a decline in public transport usage from 30 per cent to 10 per cent. So there are some serious environmental implications in this tax. Further, the compliance costs and unintended distortions that will be caused will be unfortunate, to say the least. The tax is very complex and the requirements it imposes on business are extremely onerous.

The City of Melbourne, along with some other interested groups, has made a submission to the Government on this matter. I urge the Government seriously to consider the very persuasive arguments of the City of Melbourne and others in this submission about the fringe benefits tax on car parking.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, upon notice, on 9 September 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the maximum education allowance paid to public servants serving in remote communities.
(2) What is the maximum education allowance paid to isolated parents.
(3) Is the assets test applied to the entitlement of public servants.
(4) Is the assets test applied to the entitlement of isolated parents.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Department of Industrial Relations (DIR) has advised that an education allowance is not paid to public servants in remote localities. Any education assistance would be via the Assistance for Isolated Children (AIC) Scheme. However, officers may be eligible for Education Costs Allowance where the welfare or scholastic progress of the child would be prejudiced seriously in the final two years of their secondary education due to an officer permanently moving to a new locality (which could be a remote locality) on promotion or transfer in the interests of the Public Service.

The DIR advice is that where an officer is eligible for Education Costs Allowance, the assistance available is in the form of Boarding Allowance up to a maximum of $6,812 per annum less a maximum officer contribution of $1,615, and/or Tuition Allowance up to a maximum of $6,718 per annum less a maximum officer contribution of $135.

If the child is already attending a fee paying school because the officer has already voluntarily made that decision, and the officer is subsequently promoted or transferred in the interest of the Service requiring a permanent move to a new locality, no Education Costs Allowance assistance is available as the officer would have incurred the education costs regardless of the move.
(2) The maximum allowance paid in 1992 to isolated parents under the Assistance for Isolated Children Scheme is $3,354 pa.
(4) A family assets test applies to AIC benefits in excess of the minimum test free level of $2,500.

However, detailed statistical information on the employment of SES officers by all agencies (ie not only departments) employing staff under the Public Service Act 1922 is contained in the Public Service Board Statistical Yearbook published annually until 1985 by the former Public Service Board; the Australian Public Service Statistical Yearbook published annually from 1986 to 1988 by the Department of Finance; the Australian Public Service Statistical Bulletin published twice yearly (Bulletin A for calendar years; Bulletin B for financial years) from 1988 to 1991 by the Department of Finance; and the Australian Public Service Staffing Statistics Report 1991 published by the Department of Finance. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 28 September 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What stage have the negotiations between the Federal and New South Wales (NSW) State Governments reached on the transfer of the Concord Repatriation Hospital to the state system.
(2) What arrangements have been made to effect the transfer once settlement has been reached.
(3) Has there been any unforeseen delay in the implementation of the transfer; if so, what is the cause of that delay.
(4) Is it the intention of the Federal Government to sell Concord Repatriation Hospital, or to close it, if the transfer to the NSW Government does not go ahead.
(5) Is the Minister aware that because of perceived uncertainties about the future of the hospital there are problems with staff recruitment.

(6) Please provide details of how the $1 billion figure promised by the Federal Government for the first five years of state control was arrived at and if it will be sufficient to cover all the costs incurred by the State Government.

(7)(a) How many veterans will eventually be using the state health systems if the transfer if completed; (b) what will be the estimated cost to the State of this transfer; and (c) please provide details of the cost benefit analysis of the use of Concord by NSW residents.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Commonwealth is awaiting a final response from NSW to a financial proposal forwarded earlier this year.
(2) There are two major aspects to this question: (a) arrangements for the treatment of veterans; (b) staffing arrangements.

In respect of (a), the Commonwealth has done considerable work to ensure the successful implementation of the Repatriation Private Patient Scheme as soon as the hospital is integrated. All eligible veterans in NSW have been informed by mail of the proposed scheme, which is already operating successfully in Tasmania.
In respect of (b), officer level negotiations on agreed arrangements for staff are well underway, and are expected to be finalised after there is agreement on financial arrangements.
(3) Yes; agreement with NSW has been more difficult to achieve than was envisaged.
(4) No decision has been made on this issue. The best outcome for veterans would be early integration of the hospital.
(5) Yes.

(6) The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, Mr Howe, issued a Press Release on 13 May 1992, advising that the Commonwealth had offered more than one billion dollars to guarantee the rights of veterans to access high quality services in New South Wales hospitals following integration of RGH Concord into the State health system.
The then NSW Minister for Health, Mr Hannaford, in a Press Release the same day referred to five years funding and an asset value of $200 million, making a total of one billion dollars.

The Commonwealth's offer is generous, and will assist NSW to rationalise its health services. However, it is not appropriate or possible for me to comment on the costs which would be incurred by the State of NSW as a result of the transfer.

(7)(a) The level of veteran bed utilisation will depend upon a number of factors including medical referral practices, changing length of stay, and underlying veteran demographic parameters. Current volume in RGH Concord and public hospitals is around 48000 admissions/separations p.a. and 340,000 bed days. Some "Medicare shift" (i.e. veterans in public hospitals not currently using their DVA entitlements due to their preference for local treatment) is expected to occur, but offsetting this may be increased use of private hospitals due to the inability of local public hospitals to provide appropriate facilities in a reasonable time. On this basis, the forecast number of public hospital bed days in the first three years after integration is estimated at:
However, there is scope for significant variation around these levels due to the volatility of the factors which influence bed demand, as outlined above.
(b) Again, it is not appropriate or possible for me to comment on the costs which would be incurred by the State of NSW as a result of the transfer.

(c) Community patients accounted for approximately 42% of bed days in RGH Concord in 1991-92. On a proportional basis, therefore, operating costs attributable to community patients would be of the order of $66.6m. However, the cost benefit to the State of the integration of Concord, and the costs attributable to it, could only be estimated by the State Government. Presumably they would be taking into account factors such as obtaining a well equipped modern teaching hospital facility at no capital cost.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 8 October 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the proposal on page 6 of the Defence Sub-committee report for the Australian Government to take over the operation of the Nurrungar establishment:
(1)What is the present state of that proposal.
(2)What negotiations have taken place with the Government of the United States of America.
(3)Has any date been set for a hand-over.
(4)What is the estimated cost to Australian taxpayers of such a hand-over.
(5)What is the estimated on-going cost to Australian taxpayers of operating the establishment when the hand-over has been completed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1)-(5)The Government has made no proposal to take over the operation of the Joint Defence Facility at Nurrungar. In November 1988 the Government signed new arrangements with the United States which extended the tenure of the Joint Defence Facility for a further ten years. The new arrangements include a termination provision that provides for a three year period of notice. (See the then Prime Minister's announcement on 22 November 1988, Hansard Representatives pages 2939-41.)

Following on from the new arrangements the Department of Defence and the United States Air Force agreed that the Deputy Commander at the Joint Facility, who is the senior Australian officer, would act as the Commander in the absence of the Commanding Officer. This is what the Defence Sub-committee was referring to when it reported that "the Deputy Commander is now fully briefed and is therefore in a position to take over fully the JDFN".

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 8 October 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware that the returning officer for the Victorian State district of Altona has suggested that approximately 400 residents may have been disenfranchised at the State election held on 3 October 1992 because of an error related to the electoral roll?
(2) Will a complaint that approximately 900 voters were also disenfranchised in the neighbouring seat of Footscray be investigated?
(3) If this has occurred, as the Commonwealth roll is the source of the State district roll, will the matter be investigated and information on the number of voters disenfranchised be provided?

(4) If residents were disenfranchised, what action will be taken to remedy the situation and will the Minister seek assurances that this situation has not arisen in other State electorates, with a view to protecting the integrity of the process for the upcoming Federal election?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) to (4) Neither the State Electoral Office nor the Australian Electoral Commission have received any complaints as described in Questions 1 and 2.
The State Commissioner has advised the Australian Electoral Commission that the Returning Officers for both Altona and Footscray deny making the suggestion of disenfranchisement.

The problem appears to be that the residents referred to were given provisional votes (for whatever reasons) and in the State nomenclature these are called "unenrolled" votes. As is normal procedure, these votes are checked by State Registrars (Australian Electoral Commission's Divisional Returning Officers), who have received no complaints, either. If these checks (by the State Registrars) reveal that such electors were in fact entitled to be enrolled for the district, their votes are counted.
